questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient is being treated for peptic ulcer disease and presents with symptoms of breast tenderness and decreased libido. His current medication includes an H2 blocker. Which of the following H2 blockers is most likely responsible for these antiandrogenic effects?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Cimetidine

Explanation:

  • Cimetidine is an H2 receptor antagonist that reduces gastric acid secretion in conditions such as peptic ulcer disease and GERD.
  • Cimetidine is known for its antiandrogenic effects, including gynecomastia, breast tenderness, and decreased libido, due to its ability to inhibit estradiol metabolism and displace dihydrotestosterone from its receptor.

Ranitidine (Option A): It has no significant antiandrogenic effects and is generally well-tolerated, with a lower risk of CNS effects and fewer drug interactions compared to cimetidine.

Famotidine (Option B): It also lacks significant antiandrogenic effects and has minimal drug interactions. It is more potent and has a longer action duration than ranitidine and cimetidine.

Nizatidine (Option D): It has no significant antiandrogenic effects and minimal drug interactions, with a similar efficacy and side effect profile to ranitidine, although it is used less frequently.

questions.text: You are asked to evaluate lab reports of patient with peripheral oedema. Serum albumin is low and serum globulin is low. Which of the following is likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is C: Protein losing enteropathy

  • Cirrhosis will have low albumin due to less production but globulin is increased due to decreased clearance.
  • Minimal change disease has selective proteinuria leading to low albumin.
  • SCID will have low globulin but protein losing enteropathy has both low albumin and low globulin due to losses via GIT

questions.text: A patient underwent genetic testing after being diagnosed with colon cancer. Testing reveals a mutation associated with Hereditary Nonpolyposis Colorectal Cancer (HNPCC). Which of the following genes is defective in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) MLH1 and MSH2

Explanation:

 

Hereditary Nonpolyposis Colorectal Cancer (HNPCC), also known as Lynch syndrome, is caused by inherited mutations in DNA mismatch repair (MMR) genes - MSH2 and MLH1.

Genes mutation

Manifestation

MLH1, MSH2 (Option D)

Results in microsatellite instability

Causes cluster of cancer: Colorectal, Endometrial, Ovarian, Pancreatic cancers

Colon cancer develops at a young age and it usually occurs in the right side

SMAD4 and BMPR1

(Option A)

Juvenile polyposis syndrome

STK11 (Option B)

Peutz-Jeghers syndrome

APC gene (Option C)

Familial Adenomatous Polyposis(FAP), sporadic colon cancer, Gardner syndrome and Turcot syndrome

MUTYH (Option C)

MUTYH-associated polyposis.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about Psychosis?

choices.text: In psychosis, contact with reality is often preserved.
Individuals with psychosis typically exhibit empathy
An organic causative factor is present.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) An organic causative factor is present.

 

Explanation:

 

Psychosis vs Neurosis

Features

Psychosis

Neurosis

1. Contact with reality

Lost

Preserved (Option A ruled out)

2. Interpersonal behavior

Marked disturbance in personality and behaviour

Preserved

3. Empathy

Absent

Present (Option B ruled out)

4. Insight

Absence of understanding of current symptoms

(insight absent)

Symptoms are recognized as undesirable

(insight present) (Option C ruled out)

5. Organic causative factor

Present 

Absent

6. Symptoms

Delusions, illusions and hallucinations

Usually physical or psychic symptoms

7. Dealing with reality

Capacity is grossly impaired

Preserved

8. Examples

Dementia, schizophrenia

Anxiety, phobia, depression, conversion disorder.

questions.text: A patient undergoing PCI for myocardial infarction suddenly develops bradycardia, hypotension, and episodes of apnoea.Which of the following reflexes is most likely mediated by chemosensitive vagal C fibers in the cardiopulmonary region?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Bezold-Jarisch reflex

 

Explanation:

Myocardial ischemia and reperfusion activates chemosensitive vagal C fibers in the cardiopulmonary region causing Bezold–Jarisch reflex leading to profound bradycardia, hypotension, and a brief period of apnea followed by rapid shallow breathing.

 

Bezold-Jarisch reflex or coronary chemoreflex:

  • Activators: Capsaicin, serotonin, phenylbiguanide, veratridine and pathophysiologic conditions like reperfusion after myocardial ischemia ( increased production of oxygen radicals and agents used as radio contrast for coronary angiography).
  • Mechanism: Activation of chemosensitive vagal C fibers (Option C) in the cardiopulmonary region (juxtacapillary region of alveoli, ventricles, atria, great veins, and pulmonary artery).
  • Causing bradycardia, hypotension, and a brief apnea period followed by rapid shallow breathing.


 

Cushing reflex (Option A): A combination of hypertension, bradycardia, and irregular respiration is known as the triad of the Cushing reflex.

Bainbridge reflex(Option B): Following vagotomy, the reflex is abolished as the responses are mediated by vagus nerves shown below.

Baroreceptor reflex (Option D) or sino-aortic reflex: It quickly adjusts heart rate and vascular tone in response to changes in blood pressure to maintain cardiovascular stability.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the ER with acute muscle weakness, double vision, and difficulty swallowing. He has a history of myasthenia gravis and has been experiencing increased fatigue over the past few days. Which of the following clinical features would best help differentiate a myasthenic crisis from a cholinergic crisis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Response to edrophonium

Explanation:

Myasthenic crisis is characterized by severe muscle weakness that responds to edrophonium administration, while a cholinergic crisis does not improve or can worsen.  The question is more from academic perspective. Clinically speaking we can use bedside pulmonary function tests, clinical judgment, and pupillary exam which will show miosis in cholinergic crisis but will be normal in M.Crisis. 

Features of a Myasthenic Crisis

  • Severe respiratory muscle weakness: Critical for ventilation; can lead to respiratory failure needing immediate support.
  • Exacerbation of existing MG symptoms: Includes worsening ptosis, diplopia, and difficulty with chewing, swallowing, and speaking.
  • Rapid progression: Unlike typical MG, a myasthenic crisis can develop quickly over a short time.

 

Myasthenic Crisis vs. Cholinergic Crisis

Feature

Myasthenic Crisis

Cholinergic Crisis

Cause

Exacerbation of MG

Excessive anticholinesterase use

Symptoms

Severe muscle weakness, respiratory failure

Fasciculations, paralysis, small pupils (Options A & B ruled out)

Other Signs

-

Pallor, sweating, excessive salivation (Option D ruled out)

Diagnosis

Response to edrophonium test (Option C)

Can confirm cholinergic origin

questions.text: Which of the following mediators is responsible for cancer cachexia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) TNF-alpha

Explanation:

TNF-alpha is responsible for cancer cachexia.

  • Cancer cachexia means weight loss in cancer patients due to the elevation of TNF-alpha mediators.
  • TNF-alpha also learned as no food appetite, because whenever TNF-alpha is raised in the body (can be due to fever or cancer), appetite of patient decreases and they stop feeling hungry.

 

IFN-gamma (Option B) is responsible for granuloma formation.

IL-8 (Option C) is for neutrophil recruitment.

TGF-beta (Option D) is the most fibrogenic cytokine.

questions.text: A 60 y/o male presents with severe pain, swelling, and a foul-smelling discharge from a wound on his leg sustained three days ago.O/E the affected area has signs of necrosis, raising suspicion of gas gangrene. Which of the following toxins is responsible for toxaemia in gas gangrene?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Alpha toxin

Explanation:

  • The alpha toxin released by C.perferingens is lethal, dermonecrotic, and hemolytic and is hence responsible for toxaemia in gas gangrene.

 

Clostridium forms 12 different toxins:

  • 4 major toxins:
    1. Alpha: It is the most important toxin, responsible for toxemia in gas gangrene, with dermonecrotic and hemolytic effects. 
    2. Beta: Lethal and necrotising properties
    3. Epsilon: Lethal and necrotising properties
    4. Iota: Lethal and necrotising properties
  • 8 minor toxins:
    1. ​​​​​​​Gamma: Minor lethal action
    2. Eta: Minor lethal action
    3. Delta: It has a lethal effect and causes hemolysis of red blood cells in even-toed ungulates (sheep, goats, pigs, cattle).
    4. Theta: Oxygen-labile hemolysin, antigenically related to streptolysin O and acts as a lethal and broadly cytolytic toxin.
    5. Kappa: Collagenase properties
    6. Lamba: Proteinase and gelatinase properties
    7. Mu: Hyaluronidase properties
    8. Nu: Deoxyribonuclease properties

questions.text: Which of the following techniques provides the highest resolution for determining the primary structure of proteins?
questions.solution:
Correct answer :Option C- Sanger’s sequencing

  • Sanger sequencing is typically used for DNA, but it can be adapted for protein sequencing in the form of Edman degradation, which determines the primary structure of proteins.
  • This method provides the exact sequence of amino acids, giving the highest resolution of the primary structure.

Protein Structure and Methods of Determination

Structure

Methods of Determination

Primary

  • Edman sequencing
  • Sanger’s sequencing (Option C)
  • Reverse sequencing

Secondary

  • Optical rotatory dispersion (Option D)
  • Ocular dichroism

Tertiary

  • X-ray crystallography (Option B)
  • UV Spectroscopy
  • NMR spectroscopy (Option A)

Quaternary
  • SDS PAGE (Sodium Dodecyl Sulfate-Polyacrylamide Gel Electrophoresis)

questions.text: Which organization is primarily responsible for developing the Health Index in India?

choices.text: Ministry of Health and Family Welfare

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) NITI Aayog

Explanation:

  • NITI (National Institution for Transforming India) Aayog is the organisation responsible for developing the Health Index in India. The Health Index is a composite measure that tracks the performance of Indian states and Union Territories on various health indicators, such as the Neonatal Mortality Rate and the Under-5 Mortality Rate.

  • NITI Aayog replaced the Planning Commission of India in 2015, and acts as a think tank to the central and state governments on policy matters, including health.
  • The Ministry of Health and Family Welfare collaborates with NITI Aayog and provides data but is not the primary organization for evaluating and releasing the Health Index. (Option A)
  • The Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR) focuses on biomedical research and is not involved in creating the Health Index. (Option C)
  • The World Health Organization (WHO) is an international body providing health-related guidelines and support but not developing the Health Index for India. (Option D).

questions.text: Comment on agarose gel electrophoresis and immunofixation reports?
questions.solution: Correct answer is d: Polyclonal

questions.text: Patient is undergoing endoscopy for epigastric pain. Report shows giant duodenal ulcer in duodenal cap and second one is noted in second part of duodenum. Which investigation should be done next in this patient
questions.solution:
Correct answer is A: Secretin study

  • Secretin study is indicated to diagnose Zollinger-Ellison syndrome, which can present with multiple or giant duodenal ulcers due to excessive gastric acid secretion. It entails fasting gastrin levels and then levels few minutes after secretin injection. 
  • Breath urea test only detects H. pylori infection, not causes of multiple/giant ulcers.
  • Somatostatin scintigraphy identifies neuroendocrine tumors but is not diagnostic for acid hypersecretion.
  • Endoscopic ultrasound visualizes lesions but does not assess gastric secretory function.

questions.text:
A patient undergoes a procedure affecting a delicate, thread-like structure extending from the conus medullaris to the coccyx as marked in the figure. Which of the following statements regarding this structure is correct?



{{caption_text}}

choices.text: It is composed mainly of dura mater and contains no nerve fibers
Distal part of it is called the coccygeal ligament.
It does not extend beyond the sacral hiatus
It measures about 50 cm in length

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Distal part of it is called the coccygeal ligament.

 

Explanation:

The marked structure in the given image is the Filum terminale and it consists of 2 parts: filum terminale internum and the distal filum terminale externum, also known as the coccygeal ligament.

Filum terminale is a thread-like extension of the pia mater (Option A) measuring about 20 cm in length. (Option D)

 

  • Location: Extends from the tip of the conus medullaris to the base of the coccyx.
    • Pathway: Pierces the dural tube, traverses the sacral canal and sacral hiatus (Option C) and attaches to the dorsal surface of the first coccygeal vertebra.

  • Segments
    • Filum Terminale Internum: Approximately 15 cm long, located within the dural sac.
    • Filum Terminale Externum: About 5 cm long, situated outside the dura mater, below the second sacral vertebra.
  • Composition:
    • Primarily pia mater, with some nerve fibers from the second and third coccygeal nerves on its outer surface.
    • The central canal of the spinal cord extends into it for about 5 mm.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents to the hospital with headaches, difficulty coordinating his movements, and memory loss over the past six months. On physical examination, his pupils are irregular and do not constrict to light but constrict during accommodation. He had a history of painless genital ulcer, which was resolved on its own a few years ago. What is the drug of choice used for this condition in this patient?

choices.text: A single dose of 2.4 million IU penicillin G
Once weekly dose of 2.4 million IU penicillin G
Once weekly dose of 24 million IU penicillin G
Continues dose of 24 million IU aqueous penicillin G

questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Continues dose of 24 million IU aqueous penicillin G

Explanation:

This patient's history of untreated painless genital ulcer (chancre) presenting with progressive neurological symptoms along with examination revealing Argyll Robertson pupils suggest neurosyphilis as the most likely diagnosis, which should be treated with a continuous intravenous infusion of Continues dose of 24 million IU aqueous penicillin G

Syphilis:

  • Sexually transmitted disease caused by Treponema pallidum.
  • Classification:

Stages of Syphilis

Treatment

Primary syphilis

Chancre (painless genital ulcer)

Single IM Benzathine penicillin 2.4 million IU (Option A)

Secondary syphilis

Spread in blood: Rash involving palms and soles, uveitis

Single IM Benzathine penicillin 2.4 million IU

Early latent syphilis

Dormant for < 1 year

Single IM Benzathine penicillin 2.4 million IU

Late latent syphilis

Dormant for > 1 year

Weekly IM Benzathine penicillin 2.4 million IU for three weeks (Option B)

Tertiary syphilis

Activation after one year and damages the organs (gummas)

Weekly IM Benzathine penicillin 2.4 million IU for three weeks (Option C)

Damage to heart: Cardiovascular syphilis (aortic aneurysm, arteritis)

Damage to the brain: Neurosyphilis (tabes dorsalis, ataxia, dementia, Argyl Robertson pupils)

Continues IV Aqueous Penicillin G 18-24 IU for 10-14 days. (Option D)

questions.text: A 21 year old female presents to the dermatology clinic with complaints of persistent acne on her face. On examination, the lesions are as shown in the image below. Based on the grading of acne vulgaris, what is the most appropriate classification for this patient's acne, and what would be the initial treatment recommendation?

choices.text: Grade I acne vulgaris; topical retinoids
Grade II acne vulgaris; topical antibiotics + topical retinoids
Grade III acne vulgaris; oral antibiotics + topical retinoids
Grade IV acne vulgaris; intralesional corticosteroid injections

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Grade III acne vulgaris; oral antibiotics + topical retinoids

Grades

Lesions

Treatment

Topical retinoids

(Tretinoin, Adapalene)

Grade III

Multiple inflammatory papules and pustules ± nodules (moderate)

(Most severe form)

questions.text: A 46-year-old male presents with intense pain in his left leg along with the following lesion. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Arterial ulcer

 

Explanation:

  • The most probable diagnosis of the given ulcer is Arterial ulcer.
  • It occurs due to severe arterial insufficiency of digital and medium sized arteries leading to ischemia and tissue death in the region.
  • They may present as painful erosions, located between the toes, dorsum of feet, on the shin and around malleoli.
  • Characteristic features of arterial ulcers:
    • Punched-out edges are seen
    • It is intensely painful
    • Distal pulses are not palpable
    • Thin, shiny skin is seen
    • Loss of hair in the area
    • Brittle nails are seen

 

 

Venous ulcer

(Option B)

Arterial ulcer

(Option C)

Neuropathic ulcer

(Option A)

Pressure ulcer

(Option D)

Site

Gaiter’s area (area between malleolus and calf)

At distal ends of limbs, such as toes, feet and legs.

Over toe joints, under the heel, over malleoli, under the metatarsal head, etc

Seen over pressure points, most common are ischium, greater trochanter, sacrum, hee, malleolus, occiput, etc

Appearance

Vertically oval with a sloping edge and will not penetrate deep fascia.

Punched-out edges are seen in this type of ulcer.

Ulcers can be associated with gangrene and abscesses; osteomyelitis can be seen here.

Punched out ulcer with bone as a base.

Cause

Caused by ambulatory chronic venous hypertension due to varicose veins.

This occurs due to severe arterial insufficiency of digital and medium-sized arteries, leading to ischemia and tissue death in the region.

It is caused due to repeated trauma and ischemia due to microangiopathy in diabetic patients.

It is tissue necrosis and ulceration due to prolonged pressure on any part of the body.

Characteristics

It is initially painful, then chronically becomes painless.

It heals on rest and treatment but reforms again.

It is intensely painful, distal pulses are not palpable, associated with shiny skin, brittle nails and loss of hair over the region.

Also known as diabetic ulcer since it is seen in diabetic patients.

It is common in bedridden patients with head injuries, neurological deficits, and comatose and stroke-ridden patients.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents with symptoms of a respiratory infection. A sputum sample is taken and cultured. The isolated organism shows pink, mucoid colonies on MacConkey agar. Biochemical tests are performed, and the organism is found to be urease-positive, indole-negative, and citrate-positive. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Klebsiella pneumoniae

Explanation:
The following tests are used to identify Klebsiella pneumoniae

  • MacConkey Agar: Pink, mucoid colonies indicate lactose fermentation and a capsule-producing bacterium, both characteristic of Klebsiella pneumoniae.
  • Urease-positive: Klebsiella pneumoniae produces urease, which breaks down urea into ammonia and carbon dioxide.
  • Indole-negative: Klebsiella pneumoniae does not produce indole from tryptophan, differentiating it from Escherichia coli, which is indole-positive.
  • Citrate-positive: Klebsiella pneumoniae can utilize citrate as its sole carbon source.

Laboratory diagnosis of Klebsiella pneumoniae:

  • Gram staining: It is short, plump, straight capsulated gram-negative rods
  • Culture: On MacConkey agar, it produces large dome-shaped mucoid (due to capsule) sticky, pink color, lactose fermenting colonies.
  • Identification: Identification of K. pneumoniae from colonies is made either by automated identification systems such as MALDI-TOF or VITEK; or by conventional biochemical tests as described below
    • It is catalase positive and oxidase negative
    • ICUT tests: Indole test (negative), citrate test (positive), urease test (positive) and TSI (triple sugar iron agar) test shows acid/acid, gas present, H2S absent.

Escherichia coli (Option A): Although it can appear pink on MacConkey agar due to lactose fermentation, E. coli is indole-positive and urease-negative, ruling it out.

 

Proteus mirabilis (Option C): Proteus species are typically non-lactose fermenting and would not appear pink on MacConkey agar. They also do not appear mucoid.

Enterobacter cloacae (Option D): While this organism is citrate-positive and a lactose fermenter, it generally lacks the mucoid, highly capsulated appearance of Klebsiella pneumoniae colonies and is urease-negative.

questions.text: A researcher is studying various sensory receptors and their responses to different stimuli. During an experiment with pacinian corpuscle, the researcher notes that the intensity of the initial electrical response in the receptor is proportionate with the mechanical pressure applied. What is the initial graded electrical response observed in sensory receptors upon stimulus application?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Receptor potential

 

Explanation:

Receptor potential is the graded depolarizing potential in a sensory receptor in response to a stimulus. Its magnitude varies with the intensity of the stimulus.

 

Receptor Potentials

  • A receptor potential is a type of graded potential that occurs in sensory receptors. It is a local, non-propagated change in membrane potential that occurs in response to a stimulus.
  • Receptor potential is not an action potential; instead, it causes the sensory neuron to fire action potentials.
  • Once the receptor potential reaches a critical threshold, it triggers an action potential at the sensory nerve's first node of Ranvier.

Receptor Potential" data-author="NA" data-hash="7858" data-license="NA" data-source="NA" data-tags="April2025" height="430" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/4dckPzu4YYs0VLdSl2ED1744015597.png" width="500" />

Factors affecting receptor potential:

  • Proportional Response: Amplitude of receptor potential is generally proportional to stimulus intensity.
  • Nature: Non-propagated, depolarizing potential in sensory receptors.
  • Threshold: When it reaches a critical level, an action potential is generated.
  • Stimulus Intensity: Stronger stimuli lead to larger receptor potentials.

 

Mechanism of receptor potential generation in Pacinian Corpuscle

 


 

 

Pacinian Corpuscle Mechanism

Mechanical Stimulation

  • Pressure deforms lamellae surrounding sensory nerve ending.

Ion Channels

  • Deformation opens mechanically-gated ion channels, mainly sodium (Na+).

Sodium Influx

  • Rapid influx of Na+ generates the receptor potential.

Graded Response

  • Larger deformation (stronger stimulus) leads to a larger receptor potential.

Action Potential

  • If the potential reaches ~10 mV, an action potential is generated at the first Node of Ranvier.

 

sensory nerve fiber" data-author="NA" data-hash="7859" data-license="NA" data-source="NA" data-tags="April2025" height="358" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/RwU5xVtZreVvDRUsznng1744015663.png" width="500" />

Action potential (Option A) is an all-or-none electrical signal that occurs after the receptor potential reaches a threshold. 

Synaptic potential (Option C) occurs at synapses between neurons, not in sensory receptors. 

Resting potential (Option D) is the baseline electrical state of a cell when it is not stimulated.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with complaints of infertility for the past 18 months. She has regular menstrual cycles, occurring every 30-35 days, with moderate flow and no significant pain. However, she reports difficulty conceiving despite trying to conceive during her fertile window. On examination, she has a normal BMI, no signs of hirsutism, and no galactorrhea. Serum prolactin, thyroid-stimulating hormone, and testosterone levels are within normal limits. Which of the following conditions in her clinical presentation indicate an anovulatory cycle?

choices.text: Serial follicular monitoring where follicle size increases from 15mm to 20mm.
Diagnostic laparoscopy showed a yellow punctum on the ovary.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Serum progesterone 1ng-2ng/ml on day 21.

 

Explanation:

  • Serum progesterone should be >3ng/ml on day 21 to suggest ovulation, and any value below 3ng/ml does not suggest ovulation.

 

  • Progesterone levels rise to 4-6 ng/mL during ovulation as the corpus luteum forms after the egg is released. During the luteal phase, progesterone levels range from approximately 5 to 20 ng/mL.
  • Serial follicular monitoring is done from the start of day 9 to assess the increase in follicle size from 15mm to 20mm.

Serial follicular monitoring where follicle size increases from 15mm to 20mm (Option B): Serial follicular monitoring is done by transvaginal ultrasonography > transabdominal sonography. It indicates ovulation when the follicle size increases from 15mm to 20mm and then shrinks.

Serum LH = 40mIU/ml (Option C): Serum LH levels in the range of 35-50 mIU/ml indicate that ovulation has occurred.

Diagnostic laparoscopy showed a yellow punctum on the ovary (Option D) indicates the presence of corpus luteum, which signifies that ovulation has occurred.

questions.text: A 65-year-old postmenopausal woman presents with a history of multiple fragility fractures. She has been previously treated for osteoporosis but continues to experience bone loss. Which medication would be most appropriate to stimulate bone formation in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Teriparatide

EXPLANATION:

  • Teriparatide is a recombinant form of parathyroid hormone (PTH) that stimulates bone formation by promoting osteoblast activity.
  • It enhances bone formation and improves bone density in patients with ongoing bone loss despite previous osteoporosis treatment.

Drugs used in Osteoporosis:

Pharmacological Agent

Mechanism of Action

Bisphosphonates (Option A)

Interfere with osteoclast activity, leading to decreased bone resorption.

Calcitonin (Option B)

Inhibits osteoclast activity, reducing bone resorption.

Denosumab (Option C)

It inhibits the RANK ligand, essential for osteoclast formation and function.

Estrogen/Raloxifene

Inhibit osteoclast activity and slow bone loss.

Cinacalcet

Indirectly reduces bone resorption by lowering PTH levels. (by stimulating CaSR receptors)

 

Teriparatide

A recombinant form of PTH stimulates osteoblast activity.

Strontium Ranelate

Dual action: It promotes bone formation by stimulating osteoblasts and decreases bone resorption by inhibiting osteoclast activity.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female radiology technician with 25 years of occupational exposure to diagnostic X-rays and fluoroscopy presents with a three-month history of increasing fatigue, unintentional weight loss, and frequent infections. Which cancer type is most likely associated with her occupational history?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Acute Myeloid Leukemia

 

Explanation:

Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML) is a type of blood cancer commonly associated with prolonged exposure to ionizing radiation, such as X-rays and γ-rays, placing affected individuals at increased risk of developing the disease

  • The most common thyroid cancer associated with ionising radiations: Papillary carcinoma thyroid
  • Cancer which is never associated with ionising radiations: CLL

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes the role of melanosomes in determining skin pigmentation?

choices.text: An increased number of melanocytes causes darker skin pigmentation.
Larger melanosomes are found in individuals with lighter skin tones.
The degradation rate of melanosomes is same across different skin types.
The arrangement of melanosomes influences skin pigmentation.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option D

 

Explanation:

 

  • Size of melanosomes influences their arrangement within keratinocytes, which in turn affects skin pigmentation.
  • Larger melanosomes, observed in darker skin tones, are typically dispersed individually.

 

Melanin Types and Production:

  • Two main types:
    • Eumelanin: Brownish-black, responsible for darker skin tones.
    • Pheomelanin: Orangish-red, found in lighter skin tones.
  • Synthesis process (Melanogenesis):

 

  • Melanosomes:
    • Melanin is stored within specialized organelles called melanosomes, which are produced by melanocytes.
    • Size and Distribution:
      • Darker skin: Larger melanosomes (Option A)
      • Lighter skin: Smaller melanosomes (Option B)
    • Degradation: (Option C)
      • Varies between skin types.
      • Lighter skin: Melanosome complexes show degradative changes due to lysosomal enzymes.
      • Darker skin: Larger melanosomes can remain intact up to the stratum corneum.
  • Melanin and Skin Color:
    • Key factors: Type of melanin, Melanosome size, Melanosome distribution (dispersed vs. aggregated),
    • Skin color is NOT solely determined by the number of melanocytes.
  • Regulation of Pigmentation:
    • UV radiation
    • Hormones: Estrogens - increase pigmentation; Melanocortins - melanin production.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about platelets are true?

choices.text: Alpha granules contain clotting factors and platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF)
Splenectomy causes a decrease in the platelet count
Interleukins IL-2, IL-4, IL-5, and IL-7 are involved in stimulating platelet production
Thrombopoietin is produced exclusively by megakaryocytes and regulates platelet production

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Alpha granules contain clotting factors and platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF)

Explanation: Alpha granules are abundant in platelets, about 50-80 granules per platelet. They contain secreted proteins like clotting factors and platelet-derived growth factor(PDGF).

 

Platelets

General Description

Small, granulated, non-nucleated discs important for hemostasis

Size

1-4 µm in diameter

Concentration in Blood

150,000 - 450,000/µL

Half-life

~4 days

Origin

Formed from megakaryocytes in the bone marrow

Distribution

60-75% in circulation; the remainder mainly in the spleen

Splenectomy Effect

Causes an increase in platelet count (thrombocytosis) (Option B)

Thrombopoietin

Produced by liver and kidneys; regulates platelet production (Option D)

Membrane Receptors

For collagen, ADP, von Willebrand factor and fibrinogen

Cytoplasmic Components

Actin, myosin, glycogen, lysosomes and granules

Granules
  • Alpha granules: Soluble coagulation proteins (vWF, Factor V, II), adhesion molecule, growth factor (IGF, PDGF, TGF-β, platelet factor 4), Integrin, Cytokines (Option A)
  • Dense granules: ADP, ATP, Calcium, Serotonin

Response to Injury

Adhere to exposed collagen and von Willebrand factor; release granule contents upon activation

Deficiency Effect

Thrombocytopenic purpura (easy bruising, multiple subcutaneous hemorrhages)

Interleukins

IL-1, IL-3, IL-6, IL-11 stimulate platelet production (Option C)

Factors increasing platelet synthesis

Inflammation, thrombopoietin and IL-1, IL-3, IL-6, IL-11

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient presents with anterior uveitis. After a detailed evaluation, the ophthalmologist considers various systemic associations and possible masquerades for the condition. Which of the following conditions is a known systemic association with anterior uveitis, but not a masquerade?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Behcet's Disease

 

Explanation:

Behcet's Disease is a known systemic association with anterior uveitis, characterized by recurrent oral and genital ulcers, and uveitis.

Anterior uveitis, also known as iritis, is an inflammatory condition of the eye, including the iris and ciliary body.

 

Systemic Associations and Masquerades of Anterior Uveitis

  • Infectious Causes:
    • Herpes Infections: Varicella Zoster, Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV)
    • Tuberculosis (TB)
    • Syphilis
    • Leprosy

 

  • Non-Infectious Causes:
    • With Systemic Association:
      • Sarcoidosis
      • Behçet's Disease
      • HLA-B27 Associated Arthritis
      • Inflammatory Bowel Disease: Ulcerative Colitis (UC) > Crohn's Disease
    • Without Systemic Association:
      • Drug-Induced: Pilocarpine, prostaglandin analogues

 

  • Masquerade Syndromes:
    • Definition: Conditions that mimic the symptoms of anterior uveitis but are not primarily inflammatory in nature.
    • Neoplastic Masquerades:
      • Lymphomas
      • Anterior Segment Melanoma
      • Retinoblastoma (Option C)
      • Metastasis
    • Non-Neoplastic Masquerades:
      • Intraocular Foreign Body (Option A)
      • Old Retinal Detachment
      • Pigment Dispersion Syndrome (Option D)
      • Coats' Disease

questions.text: A 48-year-old male presented with headache, blurring of vision, weakness and loss of balance. His radiological investigations suggested hydrocephalus and pheochromocytoma. A tumour is detected whose radiograph is given below. Which of the following genetic syndromes is most commonly associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) VHL syndrome

 

Explanation:

  • The above features suggest Hemangioblastoma and the associated genetic disorder is VHL (Von Hippel-Lindau) syndrome.
  • Hemangioblastoma is a benign vascular tumour of the central nervous system associated with VHL (Von Hippel-Lindau) syndrome, which consists of the following,
    • Cerebellar hemangioblastoma.
    • Retinal hemangioma
    • RCC(Renal Cell Carcinoma)
    • Renal cyst
    • Pheochromocytoma
    • Epididymal/ broad ligament cyst adenoma
    • Endolymphatic sac tumours
    • Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors

 

  • MRI in hemangioblastoma shows a cystic tumour with a non-enhancing wall and enhancing mural nodule, which is managed by surgical resection.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old female is brought to the emergency department after being found unconscious during a thunderstorm. On examination, she has fern-like marks on his neck (as shown in the image below). After regaining consciousness, she complains of weakness and numbness in her lower limbs.



 

What is the most likely diagnosis of her condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Keraunoparalysis

 

Explanation:

 

  • The fern-like marks in the image are Lichtenberg figures, characteristic of lightning strikes.

  • The patient's symptoms of weakness and numbness in the lower limbs, which occur after regaining consciousness after a lightning strike, indicate keraunoparalysis. This is a temporary condition resulting from lightning-induced vasospasm and neurological dysfunction.

questions.text: A 16-year-old female patient recently separated from her boyfriend presents with severe depression with suicidal ideation and has attempted self-harm by slitting her wrist. What is the best possible management care offered to the patient in this situation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Electroconvulsive Therapy (ECT)

Explanation:

Electroconvulsive Therapy (ECT) is indicated for providing rapid relief of suicidal ideation in patients experiencing severe depression. It is also effective for treatment-resistant depression that does not respond to multiple antidepressant trials. Additionally, ECT is beneficial for severe psychosis, food refusal secondary to depression, catatonia, bipolar depressive and manic patients.

 

Treatment Approaches for Depression:

Type of Therapy

Description

Indication

Combination Therapy

Pharmacotherapy + Psychotherapy

Combines medications (e.g., antidepressants) with psychotherapy for a higher response rate.

Moderate to severe depression

Single Therapy

Psychotherapy alone may be sufficient for mild cases.

Mild depression

 

Psychotherapy:

Psychotherapy Type

Description

Focus

Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) (Option A)

Evidence-based therapy focusing on correcting cognitive distortions and maladaptive behaviors.

Developing healthier thought patterns and coping strategies.

Interpersonal Therapy (IPT)

Addresses current interpersonal problems, including family dynamics and relationship issues.

Enhancing social support and resolving conflicts.

Family Therapy (Option D)

Involves family members to improve communication and resolve conflicts.

Family dynamics and relationships.

Psychoanalytically Oriented Therapy

Uncovers unconscious motivations and past experiences affecting behavior.

Insight into past influences on current behavior.

Behavior Therapy

Utilizes reinforcement techniques to modify problematic behaviors.

Behavior modification and improvement.

 

Somatic Treatments:

Treatment

Mechanism/Procedure

Indication

Considerations

Electroconvulsive Therapy (ECT)

Induces controlled seizures under anesthesia and muscle relaxant. Used to rapidly alleviate severe depressive symptoms.

Severe depression, especially with suicidal risk or psychotic features.

Safe for pregnant patients.

Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (TMS)

Uses short pulses of magnetic energy to stimulate brain nerve cells involved in mood regulation.

Patients unresponsive to at least one antidepressant.

Non-invasive, no anesthesia required.

Vagal Nerve Stimulation (VNS)

The electrodes are implanted to stimulate the left vagus nerve and regulate mood.

Chronic or treatment-resistant depression.

Considered after other treatments have failed.

Deep Brain Stimulation (DBS)

Implantation of leads in specific brain areas associated with mood regulation.

Chronic or intractable depression.

Considered after multiple treatment failures.

Phototherapy

Uses bright light (1500-10,000 Lux) from a specialized lightbox for 1 to 2 hours daily to regulate circadian rhythms.

Seasonal Affective Disorder (SAD).

Effective for seasonal mood changes.

Sleep Deprivation

Provides significant but short-lived benefits in alleviating depressive symptoms through controlled sleep loss.

Temporary relief from depressive symptoms.

Effects reverse after normal sleep resumes.

 

Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) (Option A): While CBT is effective for mild to moderate depression, it may not be sufficient alone for severe cases, particularly when there is a risk of self-harm.

 

Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors (SSRIs) (Option C): SSRIs are commonly prescribed for depression, but they may take several weeks to show effectiveness, which is not suitable for someone in acute danger of self-harm.

 

Family Therapy (Option D): Family therapy can be beneficial in the long-term management of depression but does not address the immediate safety concerns or the severity of the patient's current condition.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with recurrent episodes of supraventricular tachycardia. The electrophysiologist plans to perform catheter ablation. Which of the following structures is most likely to be found at the apex of Koch's triangle?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Atrioventricular node

Explanation:

The Triangle of Koch is situated on the right atrial aspect of the interatrial septum.

Boundaries:

  1. Opening of the coronary sinus
  2. The Tendon of Todaro - a collagenous subendocardial band - runs from the central fibrous body to the Eustachian ridge - a part of the fibrous skeleton of the heart.
  3. Septal tricuspid leaflet

Importance:

It helps to localize the AV node - present at the apex of Koch’s triangle.

Localising the AV node is important to safely perform radiofrequency catheter ablation within the right atrium in cases of AVNRT.

 

Sinoatrial node (Option A) is located in the upper part of the right atrium, near the opening of the superior vena cava, not in Koch's triangle.

 

While the bundle of His (Option C) is anatomically close to the AV node, it is not typically found at the apex of Koch's triangle.

  • It emerges from the AV node and penetrates the cardiac skeleton.

 

Right bundle branch (Option D) is a continuation of the bundle of His and is found in the interventricular septum, not in Koch's triangle.

questions.text: An 18 year old girl comes to the OPD with complaints of irregular cycles, weight gain and excessive hair growth on the face. You are suspecting PCOS. What will be the initial management for hirsutism in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) OCPs with cyproterone acetate

 

Explanation :

Acne and Hirsutism treatment in PCOS

OCPs with Anti Androgens (fourth generation combined pills are preferred)

  • Oral combined pills with cyproterone acetate (DOC)
  • Oral combined pills with spironolactone

 

Lifestyle changes

  • Weight loss eg. more than 5% of previous weight alone
  • Cigarette smoking stopped

questions.text: A 16-year-old male has had dull, aching pain in his right tibia for 6 months, with intermittent swelling and mild fever. X-ray shows cortical thickening and increased bone density. Biopsy reveals no abscess, and cultures are negative. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Garre’s osteomyelitis

 

Explanation:

It is a form of chronic osteomyelitis marked by non-suppurative inflammation, cortical thickening, and sclerosis. The lack of abscess formation and negative cultures align with this diagnosis.

 

Garre's Osteomyelitis:

  • Definition: A rare form of chronic osteomyelitis characterised by sclerosis (bone hardening) and cortical thickening.
  • Key Feature: Non-suppurative (no abscess formation); presents as diffuse bone enlargement.
  • Cause: Though cultures are mostly negative. It is usually due to staphylococcal infection.
  • Common Sites: Mandible> diaphysis of long bones (tibia, femur)
  • Typical Age: Adolescents and young adults.
  • Symptoms: Aching, mild swelling, recurrent acute pain, malaise, mild fever.
  • Radiographic Findings: Increased bone density, sclerosis, cortical thickening, potential marrow cavity obliteration.
  • Differential Diagnosis: Can resemble bone tumours (e.g., Ewing’s sarcoma, osteoid osteoma).
  • Diagnosis: Biopsy is required.
  • Treatment: Surgical excision, curettage, possibly bone grafting, bone transport, or free bone transfer.

Ewing’s sarcoma (Option A): A highly malignant tumour with systemic symptoms, such as fever, mass, and often aggressive radiographic findings, not just cortical thickening.

Osteoid osteoma (Option B): A benign tumour usually presenting with localised pain, commonly relieved by NSAIDs, and a radiologically distinct nidus.

Chronic osteomyelitis (Option D): Typically presents with suppuration (pus formation) and often abscess formation, which is absent in this case.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient presents with a 2.5 cm ulcerative lesion on the right side of his lower lip confirmed as squamous cell carcinoma. Which of the following statements is correct regarding the primary lymphatic drainage and surgical management of this lesion?

choices.text: Drains to submental nodes; level I neck dissection is sufficient.
Drains to ipsilateral submandibular nodes; levels I-III neck dissection is recommended.
High risk of contralateral metastasis; bilateral neck dissection is needed.
Drains to preauricular and parotid nodes; requires superficial parotidectomy.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Drains to ipsilateral submandibular nodes; levels I-III neck dissection is recommended.

 

Explanation:

  • The lymphatic drainage of the lower lip is primarily to the submental (level IA) and submandibular (level IB) nodes.
  • There's a significant risk of occult nodal metastasis for a lesion of this size, especially one close to the commissure.
  • Therefore, a selective neck dissection, including levels I-III on the ipsilateral side, is typically recommended even in N0.

 

 

 

Management

1. Early Stage (T1-T2N0):

  • Wide local excision with 1 cm margins
  • Consider elective neck dissection for tumors >2 cm or >4 mm depth
  • Reconstruction: Primary closure, local flaps, or skin grafts

 

2. Advanced Stage (T3-T4 or N+):

  • Wide local excision with ≥1 cm margins
  • Neck dissection (comprehensive or selective based on nodal status)
  • Complex reconstruction (local/regional flaps, free tissue transfer)
  • Adjuvant radiotherapy or chemoradiotherapy based on pathological findings
 

3. Management of the Neck:

  • Elective neck dissection for high-risk tumors (>2 cm, >4 mm depth)
  • Therapeutic neck dissection for clinically positive nodes
  • Levels typically addressed: I-III for N0 neck, I-V for N+ neck

questions.text: A 16-year-old patient presents with progressive vision loss. On examination, the ophthalmologist notes a central scotoma and yellowish-white flecks in the macular region of the retina. A diagnosis of Stargardt disease is made. All of the following are true statements about Stargardt disease, except:

choices.text: It is also known as juvenile macular dystrophy
Vitamin A supplementation should be avoided

questions.solution:
Answer: (B) Fundus examination showing flame-shaped hemorrhages

 

Explanation:

Fundus examination showing flame-shaped hemorrhages is seen in hypertensive retinopathy.

All other options are true regarding Stargardt disease.

 

Stargardt disease, also known as juvenile macular dystrophy, is the most common macular dystrophy. (Option A)

 

Investigations:

  • FFA: A dye is injected, and there is a dark background choroid fluorescence due to dense deposition of lipofuscin on retinal pigment epithelium.
  • Since there's no choroidal background fluorescence seen, it is called "dark choroid syndrome" or "silent choroid syndrome".
  • Fundus autofluorescence: No dye is seen, and all lipofuscin deposits are shining. (Option D)
  • EOG abnormality.
  • ERG: Late stages may affect the ERG, mainly photopic ERG abnormality.

 

Treatment

  • Avoid bright sunlight. Use sunglasses
  • Avoid vitamin A, as it promotes lipofuscinosis. (Option C)

questions.text: All the following findings are seen in vitamin B12 deficiency except?

choices.text: Sieve-like chromatin on bone marrow smear

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Myeloid/erythroid ratio is 3:1

Explanation:

The normal myeloid: erythroid ratio is 3:1. In vitamin B12 deficiency, a reversal of myeloid: erythroid ratio is seen (1:3).

Important Laboratory findings associated with Vitamin B12 deficiency:

Bone Marrow

Biochemical Tests
  • Hypercellular bone marrow
  • Erythroid Hyperplasia
  • Sieve-like chromatin (Option: B).
  • Hypersegmented neutrophils
  • Reversal of myeloid: erythroid ratio 1:1 or less (Normal: 3:1) (Option A)
  • Nuclear-cytoplasmic asynchrony
  • Serum bilirubin: Increases (Option: D).
  • Serum LDH: Increases (Option: C).
  • Vitamin B12: Decreases
  • Folic acid: Decreases
  • Anti-Intrinsic Factor (IF) antibody: Present (Pernicious anemia)
  • Methylmalonyl CoA: Increases
  • Homocysteine: Increases
  • Schilling Test: Assess cause of B12 deficiency.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman visits the clinic after experiencing persistent sadness, increased anxiety, and sleep disturbances for the past month. She recently went through a traumatic event involving the loss of a loved one. She reports feeling overwhelmed and unable to cope with her emotions. What type of depression is she most likely experiencing?

choices.text: Major Depressive Disorder with Psychotic Features

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B)Exogenous Depression

 

Explanation: Symptoms are triggered by a specific life event (the loss of a loved one), aligning with the characteristics of Exogenous (reactive) depression.

 

Endogenous Depression and Exogenous (Reactive) Depression

Feature

Endogenous Depression

(Option A)

Exogenous (Reactive) Depression

(Option B)

Definition

Primarily caused by biological factors.

Arises due to psychological or environmental factors.

Precipitating Events

Manifests without identifiable precipitating events.

Triggered by specific life events (e.g., loss, trauma).

Symptoms

Characterized by melancholic or psychotic features.

Exhibits multiple somatic complaints and emotional distress.

Mood Regulation

Linked to genetic or neurochemical factors affecting mood.

Relates to an individual's emotional response to their circumstances.

Treatment Response

Often requires pharmacological treatment (e.g., antidepressants).

May respond well to psychotherapy and counseling focused on coping strategies.

Duration

Symptoms can be persistent and chronic.

Symptoms may be more acute and linked to the duration of the triggering event.

 

Persistent Depressive Disorder (Option C) requires symptoms to persist for 2 or more years without symptom-free periods lasting longer than 2 months, whereas the patient’s symptoms are acute and linked to a specific recent triggering event.

 

Major Depressive Disorder with Psychotic Features (Option D) requires the presence of psychotic symptoms (such as delusions or hallucinations) alongside major depressive symptoms. The patient's symptoms do not indicate psychosis, making this option inappropriate.

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her parents after they found her unresponsive. They report that her younger sister sprayed the patient with a bottle filled with pesticide. On examination, the patient is lethargic and salivating. The patient’s blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg, pulse is 58/min, and respirations are 42/min. Which of the following medications should be administered first during treatment of this patient's current condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Atropine

Explanation: 

Mechanism: Organophosphates are irreversible acetylcholinesterase inhibitors causing cholinergic excess by overstimulating muscarinic (DUMBBELSS) and nicotinic receptors (muscle weakness, fasciculations, paralysis).

Organophosphate poisoning

Common exposures

Pesticide: farmer/field worker, pediatric ingestion, suicide attempt

Nerve agent: multiple patients presenting with similar symptoms

Manifestations

Muscarinic (DUMBBELSS) :

  1. D-Diarrhea
  2. U-Urination
  3. M-Miosis
  4. B-Bronchospasms, bronchorrhea, bradycardia
  5. E-Excitation, Emesis
  6. L-Lacrimation
  7. S-Salivation, sweating

Nicotinic:

  1. Muscle weakness, paralysis, and fasciculations.

Management
  1. Decontamination
  2. Atropine reverses muscarinic symptoms
  3. Pralidoxime (post atropine) reverses nicotinic and muscarinic symptoms (reactivates cholinesterase)

 

 

Neostigmine (Option A), another acetylcholinesterase inhibitor used to treat myasthenia gravis

Naloxone (Option C) is used to treat opioid intoxication

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with new-onset headaches, seizures, and progressive unilateral weakness. Brain MRI reveals a cerebral mass with irregular borders and heterogeneous contrast enhancement. Biopsy shows GFAP-positive glial cells. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Astrocytoma

Explanation:

The clinical presentation and biopsy showing GFAP (Glial Fibrillary Acidic Protein) positivity indicates a Glial cell tumor, Astrocytoma, the most common primary brain tumor in children.

 

Classification of Brain tumors based on origin

Origin

Tumors

Glial Cell

Astrocytoma (Option A), ependymoma, oligodendroglioma

Undifferentiated Cell

Medulloblastoma (Option C)

Neuronal Cell

Neurocytoma (Option B), Ganglioglioma, Ganglioneuroma

Meningeal Cell

Meningioma (Option D)

questions.text: A patient underwent unilateral orchiectomy for a swelling in the right testis. The specimen is sent for histopathological examination, and its microscopic appearance is depicted in the image below. Which of the following statements is true regarding the diagnosis?

choices.text: 3 different sizes of tumour cells are seen
Tumor cells are arranged in sheets
Tumor cells have a watery-clear cytoplasm

questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Tumor cells have a watery-clear cytoplasm

Explanation:

The given histopathological image shows features suggestive of testicular seminoma.

Histology of seminoma:

  • The tumor shows cells with watery, clear cytoplasm (described as a “fried-egg” or clear cell appearance) due to glycogen accumulation, which is PAS positive.
  • The tumor cells are arranged in nests separated by fibrous septa, and within these septa there is lymphocytic and plasma cell infiltration.
  • This triad of clear cytoplasm, nests of tumor cells, and lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate is characteristic of seminoma.

 

3 different sizes of tumour cells (small, medium and giant cells) are seen in a case of spermatocytic seminoma. (Option A)

Endodermal sinuses-like structures called Schiller-Duval bodies are present in the case of a yolk sac tumour. (Option B)

Tumor cells arranged in sheets are typical of embryonal carcinoma, whereas in seminoma, tumor cells are arranged in nests with intervening fibrous septa. (Option C)

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents with short stature and disproportionate body proportions. His parents are concerned about his height, which falls well below the 3rd percentile for his age. The child has a normal-sized trunk but exhibits a disproportionately large head and short limbs. X-ray findings show shortening of the long bones and normal bone mineralization. Genetic testing reveals a specific FGFR3 mutation. What is the most likely diagnosis for this child's short stature?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Achondroplasia

Explanation:

  • Disproportionate short limb dwarfism along with normal bone mineralization and specific FGFR3 genetic mutation is likely to be achondroplasia.
  • Achondroplasia is characterized by disproportionate short stature, with a normal-sized trunk and shortened long bones.
  • The genetic mutation commonly associated with achondroplasia is in the FGFR3 gene.
  • Achondroplasia is usually diagnosed through physical examination and confirmed with genetic testing to identify mutations in the FGFR3 gene.
  • Management focuses on addressing associated health issues and improving quality of life.
  • This includes regular monitoring for complications like spinal problems or ear infections, physical therapy to enhance mobility and strength, and sometimes surgical interventions to address skeletal deformities.
  • Growth hormone therapy is not effective for achondroplasia.

Turner Syndrome (Option A) Short stature with additional features like a webbed neck and low-set ears; affects females and involves a missing X chromosome.

Growth Hormone Deficiency (Option C) causes proportionate short stature, not disproportionate; treated with growth hormone therapy, which is ineffective for achondroplasia.

Hypothyroidism (Option D) causes growth delays but with other symptoms like dry skin and fatigue; does not lead to disproportionate body proportions.

questions.text: The patient is started on blood transfusion in a post operative room and within 5 minutes you notice that the patient develops a rash all over the body with cold clammy extremities. pulse is 120/min, BP is 80/60 mm Hg with inspiratory rhonchi in bilateral lungs The blood group of the patient is 0+ and the patient was given 0+ blood as verified by the blood bank. Which of the following is the first differential diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is b: Anaphylaxis

Some IgA-deficient individuals develop anti-IgA antibodies (often IgE type).

This happens because their immune system sees IgA as a foreign antigen — they’ve never been tolerized to it.

Development of rash + Hypotension + Bronchospasm indicates anaphylaxis.

questions.text: A 30 year old woman, G2P1, presents in active labour at 40 weeks of gestation. Examination reveals the fetus is malpositioned at an occiput posterior position. If the fetus has a flexed neck and is of normal size, the maternal pelvis is adequate and has strong uterine contractions. What is the most likely outcome of the labour?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Normal progression of labour

Explanation:

In favourable conditions, the occiput posterior (OP) position usually progresses to normal labour and results in a normal vaginal delivery.

  • Strong uterine contractions promote good flexion of the fetal neck, aiding in the descent of the fetus.
  • The fetal head undergoes an internal rotation by 3/8th of a circle, positioning the occiput behind the pubic symphysis.
  • Shoulders rotate by 2/8th of a circle to occupy the oblique diameter.
  • The fetus descends further down in the pelvis, similar to the occiput anterior (OA) position.
  • Head restitutes by 1/8th of a circle in the opposite direction of the internal rotation.
  • The delivery process then proceeds like a normal vaginal delivery in the occiput anterior position.

Occipitosacral arrest (Option A) occurs when the fetal occiput mal-rotates posteriorly towards the sacral hollow. Although spontaneous delivery can sometimes happen in this position, if labour stops progressing, it is termed occipitosacral arrest.

Deep transverse arrest (Option C) occurs when the occiput rotates 1/8th of a circle anteriorly, causing the sagittal suture to lie in the oblique diameter of the pelvis and then become arrested in that position.

  • DTA seen in android >> anthropoid

Oblique posterior arrest (Option D) due to nonrotation occurs when the sinciput and occiput simultaneously contact the pelvic floor because of fetal head deflexion. This results in the sagittal suture lying in the bispinous diameter of the pelvis, leading to arrest in that position.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman at 16 weeks of gestation presents to her obstetrician. The quad test had shown an elevated risk for Down’s syndrome. How to make a definitive diagnosis of Down’s syndrome in the fetus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Amniocentesis

Explanation:

  • Amniocentesis is a diagnostic test for genetic diseases done after 15 weeks of pregnancy.
  • Done when the screening tests are positive.

Prenatal genetic screening:

 

First trimester

Second trimester

Timing

11 - 14 weeks

15 - 22 weeks

Screening test

(Option A and B ruled out )
  • PAPP-A (Pregnancy Associated Plasma Protein-A)
  • Free beta-hCG
  • Ultrasound measurement of Nuchal translucency (NT) and nasal bone
  • Quad test:
    • Maternal Serum Alpha Fetoprotein (MSAFP)
    • Unconjugated estriol (uE3)
    • Dimeric inhibin-A
    • hCG
 
  • If NT is ≥ 3 mm in the first trimester - ultrasound and fetal echocardiography

 

Note: The best screening procedure is to combine the first and second-trimester tests.

 

Prenatal genetic diagnostic tests (done when the screening tests are positive):

 

Chorionic Villus Sampling

Amniocentesis

Cordocentesis

Timing
  • Transcervical:10–13 weeks
  • Transabdominal:10 weeks to term

After 15 weeks

(Option C)

18–20 weeks

(Option D ruled out)

Materials for study

Trophoblast cells

Fetal fibroblasts

Fetal white blood cells

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presents with gradually progressive vision loss. On examination, her intraocular pressure (IOP) is elevated, and a cup-to-disc ratio of 0.7 is noted in both eyes. She is prescribed a prostaglandin analog as first-line therapy. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of action and a common side effect of this medication?

choices.text: Reduces aqueous humor production; Lid retraction
Decreases aqueous humor secretion; Allergic blepharoconjunctivitis

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Increases uveoscleral outflow; Iris pigmentation

 

Explanation:

 

Anti-Glaucoma Drugs:

1. Prostaglandin F2α Agonists (Option C)

  • Examples: Latanoprost, Bimatoprost, Travoprost, Tafluprost
  • Mechanism: Increases uveoscleral outflow
  • Uses: First-line for primary open-angle and angle-closure glaucoma
  • Side Effects: Sandy eyes, orbital fat atrophy, anterior uveitis, cystoid macular edema, heterochromia iridis, hypertrichosis
  • Contraindications: Cystoid macular edema, diabetes mellitus

 

2. Beta Blockers (Option D)

  • Non-Selective: Timolol, Levobunolol, Carteolol, Metipranolol
    • More effective but contraindicated in asthma
  • Selective: Betaxolol (retinoprotective), Levobetaxolol
    • Safer in asthma
  • Mechanism: Reduces aqueous secretion from ciliary epithelium
  • Side Effects: Allergic blepharoconjunctivitis, dry eyes, corneal hypoesthesia

 

3. Alpha-2 Agonists (Option A)

  • Examples: Brimonidine (long-term use), Apraclonidine (IOP spikes)
  • Mechanism: Reduces aqueous production, increases uveoscleral outflow
  • Side Effects: Lid retraction, respiratory depression (Brimonidine), allergic blepharoconjunctivitis
  • Contraindications: Children <2 years
  • Brimonidine: Safest during pregnancy (Category B)

 

4. Miotics (Option B)

  • Examples: Pilocarpine, Physostigmine, Echothiophate
  • Mechanism: Stimulates M3 receptors, increasing trabecular outflow
  • Side Effects: Brow pain, miosis, cataract (Echothiophate), retinal tears

 

5. Carbonic Anhydrase Inhibitors

  • Examples: Acetazolamide (systemic), Brinzolamide, Dorzolamide (topical)
  • Mechanism: Inhibits aqueous secretion from ciliary epithelium
  • Uses: Acute congestive glaucoma (with IV mannitol)
  • Side Effects: Ciliary edema, secondary angle-closure glaucoma (Topiramate, Zonisamide)

 

6. Newer Drugs

  • Netarsudil (Rho kinase inhibitor): Increases trabecular outflow; Side effect - vortex keratopathy
  • Omidenepag (PGE2 agonist): Increases both trabecular and uveoscleral outflow

questions.text: An X-ray image shows multiple large chondromas in the hands and feet of a 28-year-old female patient. Based on this radiological finding, which of the following statements is false regarding her condition?

choices.text: The presence of large chondromas may indicate a higher risk of malignant transformation.
These chondromas can lead to bone expansion and thinning of the cortex.
Surgical excision of all chondromas is the standard treatment to prevent malignant transformation.
Patients with multiple chondromas have an increased risk of extra-skeletal malignancies

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Surgical excision of all chondromas is the standard treatment to prevent malignant transformation.

 

Explanation:

It is a case of Multiple Enchondromatosis associated with Maffucci syndrome.

Surgical excision may be indicated for symptomatic chondromas or those showing signs of malignant transformation, it is not necessary to excise all chondromas as a preventive measure.

 

Multiple Enchondromatosis

  • Definition: Condition characterized by numerous benign cartilaginous tumors (chondromas).
  • Associated Conditions:
    • Ollier's disease- only enchondromas
    • Maffucci syndrome- enchondromas + hemangiomas

Ollier's Disease

Feature

Details

Clinical Presentation

Usually diagnosed in childhood

Most chondromas found in phalangeal bones

Common findings:

Asymmetric limb shortening

Swelling of fingers/toes

Impaired movement of interphalangeal joints

Distribution

Can be unilateral or bilateral

Progression

New chondromas typically stop after puberty

Tumor growth in adulthood may indicate malignancy

Risk of pathological fractures

Malignant Transformation

20-30% risk of secondary chondrosarcoma

Transformation usually occurs in the 30s or 40s

Warning signs:

Increase in size of existing chondroma

New symptoms

Maffucci Syndrome

General Features of Multiple Chondromas

Feature

Details
   

Clinical Presentation

Multiple chondromas with hemangiomas



 

Symptoms can appear at birth or later

Radiographic Features

X-rays show large chondromas


 

Possible bone expansion and cortex thinning (Option B ruled out)

Malignant Transformation

Risk of secondary chondrosarcoma > 50% (Option A ruled out)

Similar timing for malignant transformation as Ollier's disease

Increased risk for carcinomas (breast, liver, ovary) (Option D ruled out)

 

Radiographic Appearance

Large chondromas visible on X-rays

Histological Features

Higher cellularity and proliferative potential compared to solitary chondromas


 

Feature

Details

Malignant Transformation

Concern for secondary sarcoma in both conditions

Signs:

Increase in lesion size

New symptoms (e.g., pain)

MRI evidence of new soft-tissue mass

Histological permeative growth pattern

Extra-skeletal Malignancies

Higher risk for tumors in breast, liver, ovaries, CNS
  • Etiology: No definitive cause identified; emphasis on clinical and radiographic findings and risk of malignancy.
