questions.text: A 9 year old boy frequently argues with his parents and teachers, often refuses to follow rules, and deliberately annoys his classmates. He seems angry most of the time but has no history of physical aggression or breaking the law. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Oppositional Defiant Disorder

 

Explanation:

The clinical scenario of frequent arguments, refusal to follow rules, and deliberate annoyance, without severe aggression or rule violations, point to a diagnosis of Oppositional defiant disorder.

 

Disorder

Oppositional Defiant Disorder (ODD)

Conduct Disorder

Definition

The persistent pattern of negativistic, defiant, disobedient, and hostile behaviour toward authority figures.

A persistent pattern of behaviour involving aggression, violating others' rights, and disregarding social norms.

Diagnostic Criteria (DSM-5)
  • Duration: ≥6 months.
  • Symptoms (≥4):
  • Losing temper.
  • Easily annoyed/sensitive.
  • Angry/resentful.
  • Argues with authority figures.
  • Refuses requests/rules.
  • Deliberately annoys others.
  • Blames others for their own mistakes/behaviors.
  • Spiteful/vindictive (at least 2x in 6 months).
  • No severely aggressive or delinquent behaviours.
  • Duration: ≥12 months, with 1 symptom present in the last 6 months.
  • Symptoms (≥3):
  • Physical aggression or threats.
  • Destruction of property.
  • Deceitfulness or theft.
  • Harming animals.
  • Violation of rules (e.g., truancy, running away).

Types (DSM-5)
  • Angry/Irritable Mood: Frequent temper loss, persistent irritability.
  • Argumentative/Defiant Behavior: Argues, refuses to comply, blames others.
  • Vindictiveness: Spiteful/vindictive actions ≥2x in 6 months.
  • Childhood-onset: Symptoms before age 10.
  • Adolescent-Onset: Symptoms after age 10.
  • Unspecified-Onset: Age of onset unknown

Severity Specifiers
  • Mild: Symptoms in 1 setting.
  • Moderate: Symptoms in 2 settings.
  • Severe: Symptoms in ≥3 settings.
  • Mild: Few conduct problems, minor harm.
  • Moderate: Intermediate symptoms.
  • Severe: Many symptoms, significant harm caused.

Treatment
  • Family Interventions: Parent training in child management, reinforcing positive behaviour.
  • Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT): Parents are taught to discourage the child's oppositional behaviour by not paying much attention to it.
  • Parenting Techniques: Focus on reducing harsh punishment, and increasing positive interactions.
  • Psychosocial Interventions: Early intervention, CBT, school-based programs.
  • Pharmacologic Interventions: Antipsychotics (risperidone, quetiapine), SSRIs for impulsivity/irritability, sodium valproate.

Conduct Disorder (Option A): Does not fit, as there is no evidence of severe aggression or serious rule-breaking behaviour.

 

Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder (Option C): No signs of inattention or hyperactivity are mentioned, which are key in ADHD.

 

Disruptive Mood Dysregulation Disorder (DMDD) (Option D): Lacks the severe, recurrent temper outbursts and mood dysregulation typical of DMDD.

questions.text: The logo shown above represents a health scheme launched by the Government of India. What is the primary objective of this program?

choices.text: To provide comprehensive outbreak response essential drugs and diagnostic services.
To offer health insurance coverage to the economically disadvantaged
To reduce morbidity due to vaccine-preventable diseases in children
To promote accessible, affordable, and quality healthcare to the rural population

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) To offer health insurance coverage to the economically disadvantaged

Explanation:

The logo represents Ayushman Bharat-Pradhan Mantri Jan Arogya Yojana (PMJAY), a scheme of the Government of India designed to provide health insurance coverage to economically disadvantaged families.

 

Ayushman Bharat - Pradhan Mantri Jan Arogya Yojana (PMJAY):

  • An initiative launched in 2018 by Govt. of India to achieve UHC
  • Provides all the elements, including NCDS, in primary care.
  • Benefits:
    • Coverage: up to INR 5 lakh per family per year for secondary and tertiary care hospitalization.
    • There is no restriction on the number of family members.
    • Cashless access across the country
    • All pre-existing conditions covered
    • Covers the cost of treatment, up to 3 days of pre-hospitalization and 15 days of post-hospitalization follow-up care.
  • Beneficiaries: Vulnerable and poor populations based on the Socio-Economic Caste Census (SECC) database.

Option A: Health and Wellness Centre, established under the National Health Policy in 2017, offers comprehensive health care, including maternal and child health, communicable disease, and non-communicable disease services, as well as free essential medications and diagnostics.

Option C: Mission Indradhanush aims to achieve more than 90% full immunization coverage and reduce child mortality and morbidity due to vaccine-preventable diseases.

Option D: The National Rural Health Mission (NRHM) provides accessible, affordable, and quality healthcare to the rural population, reducing mortality rates and disease transmission.

questions.text:
Match the following male reproductive organs with their homologous female reproductive organs.


	
		
			
			1. Testes
			
			
			A. Bartholin's glands
			
		
		
			
			2. Penis
			
			
			B. Ovaries
			
		
		
			
			3. Scrotum
			
			
			C. Clitoris
			
		
		
			
			4. Bulbourethral glands
			
			
			D. Labia majora
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1-B, 2-C, 3-D, 4-A

 

Explanation:

Homologous structures in male and female reproductive systems are those that share a common embryologic origin despite their different functions in adulthood.

Homologous Structures

Testes - Ovaries
  • Derived from the undifferentiated gonadal ridge in the embryo.
  • Function as the primary reproductive organs, producing gametes and hormones.

Penis - Clitoris
  • Develops from the genital tubercle.
  • Sensitive erectile tissues involved in sexual arousal.

Scrotum - Labia majora
  • Develops from the labioscrotal swellings from mesoderm layer.
  • Serve as protective structures for the reproductive organs.

Penile urethra - Labia minora

Develops from the urethral folds.

Bulbourethral glands - Bartholin's glands
  • Develops from the urogenital sinus, which is part of the endodermal tissue.
  • Both glands secrete mucus to lubricate.

questions.text: 40-year-old female patient presents with dysphagia for past one year to solid food items . On examination, she has pallor with cheilosis and koilonychia. The diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is A: Plummer Vinson syndrome

  • Plummer Vinson syndrome is characterized by the classical triad of dysphagia, iron deficiency anaemia, and oesophageal webs.
  • Dysphagia in PVS is due to esophageal webs leading to difficulty swallowing, typically solids.

questions.text: A 72-year-old patient undergoing hemodialysis suddenly develops symptoms of dizziness, significant leg cramps, and chest pain during the treatment session. Which of the following is the most common acute complication occurring in patients undergoing dialysis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hypotension

 

Explanation:

  • Hypotension is the most common acute complication during hemodialysis. It often results from rapid fluid shifts and changes in blood volume during the dialysis session.
  • While cardiac arrhythmias (Option A), Anaphylactoid reactions (Option C) and muscle cramps (Option D) are also potential complications, they are less frequently encountered than hypotension.

 

Types of Hemodialysis

Intermittent Hemodialysis

Continuous Hemodialysis
  • Commonly used for acute kidney injury (AKI).
  • Blood is on one side of the dialysis machine, and dialysate is on the other side.
  • Transfer of substances occurs by diffusion and ultrafiltration.
  • Common complication: Hypotension.

 
  • Used in hemodynamically unstable patients.
  • Types:
    • Convective Clearance: Water and dissolved solutes pass through a semipermeable membrane; physiologic crystalloid solution is added to circulation.
    • Diffusive Clearance: Dialysis with a lower flow rate.
    • Hybrid Therapy: Combines both convective and diffusive clearance.

 

Complications associated with Hemodialysis

During treatment

Between treatment
  • Hypotension: The most common acute complication during hemodialysis, especially in patients with diabetes mellitus.
  • Muscle cramps.
  • Anaphylactoid reactions: These reactions, particularly to the dialyser, are most common during its first use and are often associated with bio incompatible cellulosic-containing membranes.
  • Cardiac arrhythmias: D/t potassium & acid-base shifts.
  • Hemorrhage: D/t anticoagulation & venous needle disconnection.
  • Air embolism: D/t faulty lines & equipment malfunction.
  • Pulmonary oedema (D/t fluid overload).
  • Systemic sepsis: Usually involves vascular access devices (catheter or fistula).
  • Dialysis disequilibrium syndrome typically occurs during or after a patient's first dialysis session. It presents with confusion, restlessness, headache, and muscle twitching. It is caused by a urea gradient between the CSF and blood that raises intracranial pressure.
  • Amyloidosis (D/t beta 2 microglobulin)
  • Carpal tunnel syndrome (due to amyloid deposition in the flexor retinaculum).
  • Peripheral neuropathy

questions.text: Analyse the structure of the mucopolysaccharide shown below: Which mucopolysaccharide is represented in this image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Keratan sulfate

Explanation:

The image depicts Keratan sulfate, identifiable by its unique composition of galactose and N-acetylglucosamine, along with possible sulfate groups. It is unique among glycosaminoglycans (GAGs) because it lacks uronic acid​. It is primarily found in the cornea and cartilage, contributing to their structural properties​.

Identification Tips:

  • Look for the presence of galactose as one of the primary sugars in the disaccharide unit.
  • N-acetylglucosamine can be identified by the presence of the N-acetyl group (CH₃CONH).
  • Sulfate groups may be attached to either of the sugar moieties, contributing to the molecule's negative charge.

Mucopolysaccharide (MPS)

Components

Keratan Sulfate

Galactose and N-acetylglucosamine

Heparan Sulfate (Option A)

Glucuronic acid (or iduronic acid) and N-sulfated glucosamine

Dermatan Sulfate (Option D)

Iduronic acid and N-acetylgalactosamine

Chondroitin Sulfate (Option C)

Glucuronic acid and N-acetylgalactosamine

Hyaluronic Acid

Glucuronic acid and N-acetylglucosamine

questions.text: A 58-year-old patient with chronic renal failure presents with symptoms of fatigue, fluid retention, and low serum potassium levels. On examination, the patient shows signs of hypertension and oedema. Which of the following types of cells being defective in the renal tubules is responsible for the following condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Principal Cells

 

Explanation

 Principal cells 

               Sodium reabsorption and potassium secretion by the principal cells depend on the activity of a Na+-K+ ATPase pump in each cell’s basolateral membrane  This pump maintains a low sodium concentration inside the cell and, therefore, favors sodium diffusion into the cell through special cheannels . The principal cells are the primary sites of action of the potassium-sparing diuretics, including spironolactone, eplerenone, amiloride, and triamterene.

Cell Type

Functions

Characteristics

Principal Cells

(Option A)
  • Sodium reabsorption
  • Potassium secretion
  • Water reabsorption
  • Responsive to aldosterone
  • ADH receptors
  • Columnar epithelium

Alpha Intercalated Cells

(Option B)
  • Secrete H⁺ ions
  • Reabsorb bicarbonate
  • Apical H⁺-ATPases
  • Cuboidal epithelium

Beta Intercalated Cells

(Option C)
  • Secrete bicarbonate
  • Reabsorb H⁺ ions
  • Apical bicarbonate transporters
  • Cuboidal epithelium

 

Juxtaglomerular Cells (Option D):

  • They are located in the juxtaglomerular apparatus and are responsible for the secretion of renin, which plays a role in the regulation of blood pressure and the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system.
  • They are not directly involved in sodium reabsorption, potassium secretion, or water reabsorption.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with severe, chronic diarrhoea, failure to thrive, and a rash. His medical history includes a diagnosis of type 1 diabetes mellitus and thyroiditis. Laboratory tests show elevated levels of anti-enterocyte antibodies. Based on these findings, which mechanism is most likely impaired in this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Peripheral tolerance

Explanation:

The clinical scenario likely describes IPEX (immune dysregulation, polyendocrinopathy, enteropathy, X-linked) due to defective peripheral tolerance.

  • IPEX is an X-linked immune dysregulation disorder that presents in childhood. It occurs due to defects in the FOXP3 gene, which plays a crucial role in peripheral tolerance mediated by CD4+ T regulatory cells.
  • Defects in FOXP3 lead to dysfunctional CD4+ T regulatory cells, impairing their ability to maintain immune tolerance and resulting in autoimmune reactions against various tissues, particularly within the gastrointestinal tract.

questions.text: A 60 y/o jaundiced patient presents with upper abdominal pain. Ultrasound reveals a dilated bile duct, but the cause of obstruction is unclear. What would be the next best non-invasive imaging technique to evaluate this condition?
questions.solution:
MRCP is a non-invasive imaging method that provides a detailed view of the biliary system and is particularly effective for diagnosing bile duct obstructions. It also does not rely on the excretion of contrast agents. It is the preferred next step when further non-invasive evaluation is needed after ultrasound, as it can detect stones, strictures, or masses causing the bile duct dilation.

MRCP showing common bile duct dilation

USG showing double barrel sign

 

 

Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) (Option B): While ERCP is highly effective for diagnosing and treating bile duct obstructions, it is an invasive procedure. It involves the insertion of an endoscope and contrast injection into the bile ducts, which carries risks like pancreatitis and infection. Though very useful when intervention is required, ERCP is not considered a non-invasive technique, making it less appropriate.

 

ERCP showing dilation of the common bile duct (white arrow)

 

Ultrasound with colour Doppler (Option C): Although a repeat ultrasound with colour Doppler can help distinguish bile ducts from blood vessels by detecting blood flow, it does not provide detailed information on the cause of the dilation. 

 

Plain radiography (Option D): Plain X-rays provide minimal information about the biliary system. They may show calcifications, but they cannot assess soft tissues or provide detailed views of the bile ducts

questions.text: A 35 y/o male presents with milky urine and abdominal pain after a fatty meal. He reports weight loss and frequent urinary infections. Urinalysis shows chyluria. What is the most likely underlying cause of chyluria in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Filarial infection

Explanation:
Filarial infection is the most common cause of chyluria, as it can obstruct intestinal lymphatics, leading to lymph leakage into the urine.

Chyluria

  • Passage of milky white chylous urine, aggravated after fatty meals.
  • Causes:
    • Most Common: Filarial infections (2% of cases).
    • Other Causes: Tumors, tuberculosis, malaria, and ascariasis infestation.
  • Mechanism: Obstruction of intestinal lymphatic vessels leads to high lymphatic pressure, causing lymph to enter the renal lymphatics, or rupture of intestinal lymphatics into the renal pelvis/ureter, forming a lympho-urinary fistula.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Symptoms mimic bacterial or tuberculous pyuria and may include urinary infections and protein loss.
    • Possible presentation of colic due to lymph clots in the urinary system.
  • Diagnostic Tools: Urine study, culture, intravenous urogram (IVU), lymphangiography, and abdominal ultrasound.
  • Management:
    • Dietary changes (low-fat, protein-rich diet).
    • Antibiotics and diethylcarbamazine (DEC).
    • Increase oral fluid intake.
    • Surgical options include ligation of dilated lymphatics or sclerosing lymph vessels.

Renal stone disease (Option A): While renal stones can cause urinary symptoms, they do not typically lead to chyluria or milky white urine.

Tuberculosis (Option C): Although tuberculosis can cause urinary symptoms, it is not the most common cause of chyluria compared to filarial infections & also the history is not pointing towards TB.

Diabetes mellitus (Option D) can lead to various urinary symptoms but is not associated with the development of chyluria.

questions.text: What is the main focus of the Pradhan Mantri Poshan Scheme launched by the Government of India?

choices.text: Empowering women through nutrition development programs
Providing financial assistance for rural agricultural development

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Improving nutritional outcomes among children

Explanation:

Pradhan mantri Poshan Sheme

  • Formerly known as mid-day meal scheme
  • Under the ministry of education
  • Aims to prevent school dropouts and provide nutrition for children
  • Rolled out in government schools
  • For preschoolers up till class 8
  • Primary- 450 kcal, 12 gm protein
  • Upper primary- 700 kcal, 20 gm protein

POSHAN Abhiyan:

  • PM's Overarching Scheme for Holistic Nourishment
  • Also known as the National Nutrition Mission
  • Launched in 2018 by the Ministry of Women & Child Development.

Targets:

  • Reduce low birth weight (<2.5 kg) by 2% annually.
  • Decrease stunting (chronic malnutrition) by 2% annually.
  • Lower underweight (acute on chronic malnutrition) by 2% annually.
  • Reduce anemia by 3% annually.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman presents with intermittent flank pain and occasional gross hematuria. Physical examination is unremarkable. Laboratory tests show normal renal function. A renal biopsy of a mass lesion reveals a mixture of mature adipose tissue, thick-walled blood vessels, and bundles of smooth muscle cells. All are true regarding this condition except?

choices.text: It is commonly associated with tuberous sclerosis.
It is more prevalent in males than females.
It is mostly a benign tumor.
It has a high susceptibility to spontaneous hemorrhage.

questions.solution:
CORRECT ANSWER:  B)It is more prevalent in males than females.

 

EXPLANATION:

 

Renal angiomyolipoma:

 

  • A benign neoplasm consisting of vessels, smooth muscle, and fat originating from perivascular epithelioid cells. (Option C)
  • It is most often detected incidentally and has a female preponderance. (Option B)
  • They are present in 25% to 50% of patients with tuberous sclerosis. (Option A)
  • It has a high susceptibility for bleeding (can present as loin pain).
  • Morphology:

Histology: Circular blood vessels, muscles, and fat; perivascular epithelioid cells with dense eosinophilic cytoplasm and mitotic figures.

questions.text: A 45 y/o man from a tropical region presents with a painful red eye, significant watering, and sensitivity to light after working in a garden with decaying plant material. The patient is diagnosed with keratomycosis. Which of the following is not an examination finding in keratomycosis?

choices.text: Feathery extensions at the margins of the corneal ulcer

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Extensive corneal vascularization

 

Explanation:
Extensive corneal vascularization is generally absent in pure fungal keratitis, which distinguishes it from bacterial infections where vascularization is more common.

Keratomycosis

 

Clinical Features

  • Pain & Foreign Body Sensation
  • Watering of the eye
  • Photophobia
  • Blurred Vision
  • Redness.

Examination Findings

  • Corneal Ulcer: Greyish-white, dry-looking with elevated, rolled-out margins.
  • Pigmented Ulcer: Brownish appearance, possible with dematiaceous fungi.
  • Feathery Extensions (Option A ruled out): Delicate, finger-like projections into the surrounding stroma.
  • Sterile Immune Ring (Option C ruled out): Yellow line of demarcation where fungal antigen and host antibodies meet.
  • Satellite Lesions: Multiple small lesions around the main ulcer.
  • Hypopyon: Large, non-sterile, even with a small ulcer.
  • Endothelial Plaque (Option D ruled out): Located under the stromal lesion, made of fibrin and leucocytes.
  • Corneal Vascularization: Typically absent in pure fungal ulcers.
  • Perforation: Rare but possible.

Investigations

  • Corneal Scraping: Performed under topical anaesthesia for microbiological examination.
  • Wet KOH Mount: Reveals filamentous fungi (branched, septate hyphae) or non-filamentous yeast-like fungi (Candida).
  • Gram's & Giemsa Stains: To detect fungal hyphae and inflammatory cells.
  • Culture: Sabouraud's agar medium is used for fungal culture.
  • PCR: Recommended for rapid identification of fungal pathogens.
  • Anterior Chamber Paracentesis: Considered if there is an intraocular extension.
  • Corneal Biopsy: Indicated for deep stromal abscess or when cultures are negative.
  • Confocal Microscopy: Used for identifying actual fungi within the cornea.

questions.text: A 36 y/o woman, G3P2, delivered via C-section 4 hours ago and is now experiencing severe PPH unresponsive to uterine massage and uterotonics. Her vital signs show tachycardia and hypotension. The medical team opts for surgical intervention to avoid a hysterectomy. What is the principle behind performing bilateral internal iliac artery ligation to control her PPH?

choices.text: To apply direct pressure on the bleeding site
To reduce distal blood flow and convert arterial pressure to venous-like pressure
To increase uterine contractility and reduce bleeding
To promote rapid healing of uterine tissues

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) To reduce distal blood flow and convert arterial pressure to venous-like pressure

 

Explanation:

The principle of bilateral internal iliac artery ligation is to reduce blood flow to the uterus and pelvis, significantly lowering pulse pressure (85% reduction) in arteries distal to the ligation. This reduction in pressure makes the blood vessels more conducive to hemostasis through clot formation, similar to venous circulation.

 

Considerations:

  • Ligation of the internal iliac artery is to be done at 5cm distal to common iliac bifurcation - this avoids the posterior division branches of the internal iliac artery.
  • Should not perforate continuous large veins, esp. Internal iliac vein.
  • Non-absorbable sutures are used.

Direct pressure on the bleeding site (Option A) is not the principle behind internal iliac artery ligation. This option refers more to methods like uterine tamponade or manual compression, which aim to directly compress the bleeding area to stop hemorrhage.

 

Increasing uterine contractility is achieved with uterotonic agents like oxytocin, not through surgical ligation of arteries. Internal iliac artery ligation does not affect uterine muscle contraction directly. (Option C)

 

Promoting rapid healing of uterine tissues (Option D) is not the aim of internal iliac artery ligation. The procedure focuses on reducing blood flow to control hemorrhage, not on directly promoting tissue healing.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a recent dental infection presents with persistent headaches, fever, and confusion. He exhibits focal neurological deficits and seizures. The radiological findings are provided. Given his clinical presentation and imaging, what is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Initiate IV antibiotics and immediate surgical drainage
Start oral antibiotics and monitor with CT every 48 hours
Administer high-dose corticosteroids and supportive care
Begin antiepileptic medications and refer for op follow-up.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Initiate IV antibiotics and immediate surgical drainage

 

Explanation:

  • Given the history of a recent dental infection, along with imaging showing a ring-enhancing lesion in the frontal lobe and symptoms of fever, confusion, and seizures, the most likely diagnosis is a Brain abscess.
  • The mainstay treatment includes both surgical intervention and antibiotic therapy.

Brain Abscess:

  • Pathology:
    • Direct Spread: From air sinus infections or following brain surgery.
    • Hematogenous Spread: Typically associated with respiratory infections, endocarditis, or dental infections.
  • Symptoms include fever, confusion, seizures, focal neurological deficits and raised ICT.
  • Most common in the frontal lobe, but are also frequently found in the parietal lobe, particularly in cases of hematogenous spread.
  • Imaging:
    • CT Scan (Initial Choice): Shows hypodense oedema initially, progressing to a ring-enhancing mass as the abscess matures.
    • MRI (IOC): Identifies restricted diffusion
  • Management: (Mainstay: Surgery + Antibiotics)
    • Early Surgical Drainage: Essential for effective treatment.
    • Antibiotics: IV antibiotics are administered for approximately 6 weeks.
    • Prophylactic Anticonvulsants: Considered due to a high risk of seizures.
    • Multiple smaller abscesses: IV Antibiotics.
    • Steroids: Reduce oedema and alleviate symptoms of mass effect.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man, two months post-kidney transplant, presents with sudden oliguria, fever, and graft site swelling. Biopsy shows glomerular and peritubular capillary inflammation with complement deposition. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Acute humoral rejection

 

Explanation:

Acute humoral rejection, also known as acute antibody-mediated rejection (ABMR), is the most likely diagnosis.

  • Acute rejection occurs weeks to months after transplant. It is of 2 types:

    • Acute humoral rejection → mediated by antibodies.

    • Acute cellular rejection → cell-mediated by T-lymphocytes.

  • Acute humoral rejection: Newly formed antibodies cause damage to kidneys leading to inflammation.

    • This damage to kidneys activates the complement system and the C4d complement gets deposited around the peritubular capillaries.
    • C4d complement is the marker of acute humoral rejection.

questions.text: You are provided with results of receptor status from the biopsy obtained from a patient’s breast lump. You realize that her molecular subtype carries a low proliferative rate and a better prognosis. Which of the following will not be the likely histological subtype in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer : B) Medullary carcinoma

 

Explanation :

The biopsy results obtained from a patient’s breast lump carrying a low proliferative rate (better prognosis) is indicative of a luminal type A malignancy. Among the given options, medullary carcinoma of the breast does not belong to luminal type A; rather it is a luminal type B malignancy.

Molecular classification of breast cancer is based on the results of receptor status such as ER, PR and HER2.

Molecular classification of breast cancer :

Classification

Hormone receptor

HER2/Neu

 Proliferative marker

Luminal A

Positive (either or both ER/PR)

Negative

Ki-67 <14% (low)

Luminal B (triple +ve)

Positive (either or both ER/PR)

Negative / Positive

Ki-67 >14% (high)

Basal type (triple -ve)

Negative

Negative

Ki-67 usually high

HER2/neu enriched

Negative

Positive

Ki-67 high

Claudin low (triple -ve)

Negative

Negative

Claudin low

 

Luminal A (Low proliferation rate)
  • Tubular carcinoma (Option A ruled out).
  • Papillary carcinoma (Option C ruled out).
  • Mucinous carcinoma (Option D ruled out).
  • Low-grade ILC.

Luminal B (High proliferation rate)
  • High-grade ILC.

HER2/Neu rich
  • Apocrine carcinoma.
  • Micropapillary carcinoma.

Triple-negative
  • Medullary carcinoma. (Option B)
  • Metaplastic carcinoma.
  • Secretory carcinoma.
  • Adenoid cystic carcinoma.

questions.text: A 12-year-old child presents with headaches, visual disturbances, and delayed growth. An MRI of the brain reveals a 3 cm cystic mass with calcifications. The growth was found to be encapsulated and multiloculated. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Craniopharyngioma

Explanation:

Craniopharyngioma: 

  • Craniopharyngiomas are benign tumours arising from vestigial remnants of the Rathke pouch
  • They commonly occur in the suprasellar region and often present as encapsulated and multiloculated cystic masses with calcifications. 
  • The cysts contain cholesterol-rich, thick brownish-yellow fluid (compared to machine oi)l
  • It has 2 histological variants: Adamantinomatous and papillary. 

Feature

Adamantinomatous

Papillary

Age group

Children

Adults

Epithelium

Stratified squamous

Stratified squamous

Wet keratin

+

-

Calcifications

+

-

Cysts

+

-

Stellate reticulum

+

-

 

  • Common presentations include headaches and visual disturbances like bitemporal hemianopia due to optic chiasma compression, while children present with growth retardation due to pituitary hypofunction and GH deficiency.

 

Oligodendroglioma (Option A): Typically affects adults (30–50 years old). Commonly located in cerebral hemispheres, not suprasellar. Calcifications can be present, but they are intra-axial and not cystic or multiloculated. Endocrine symptoms are rare. Age and symptom mismatch

Meningioma (Option B):Rare in children; typically seen in middle-aged to older adults. Usually extra-axial, solid, may calcify but are not cystic or multiloculated. Often incidentally found unless very large. Does not cause hormonal dysfunction in children. Age and imaging mismatch

Pituitary Adenoma(Option D): Unlikely in a child .Pituitary adenomas are rare in children. Typically cause endocrine symptoms, but visual changes in children from adenomas are uncommon. Less likely to be calcified or multiloculated. Usually solid tumors, not cystic. Age, imaging, and morphology mismatch

questions.text:
A hospital conducted a study on the recovery times (in days) of patients after a specific surgical procedure. The data was summarized using a box and whisker plot as shown below:



Which of the following statements best describes the skewness of the recovery time data shown in the plot above?

choices.text: The data is both positively and negatively skewed.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) The data has no skewness.

Explanation:
In the given box and whisker plot, the right whisker is equal to the left whisker indicating Symmetrical distribution or no skewness.

  • It is used to show the distribution of data based on a five-number summary [minimum, first quartile (Q1), median, third quartile (Q3), and maximum].
  • It comments on the type of distribution i.e., normal or skewed.

Components of a Box and Whisker Plot:

  • Q1 - the lower edge of the box - denotes 25th percentile
  • Q3 - the upper edge of the box - denotes - 75th percentile
  • Q2 - Median - indicates the middle value of the dataset when arranged in ascending order.
  • The lower whisker (or left end) extends from the minimum data point up to Q1
  • The upper whisker (or right end) extends from Q3 to the maximum data point.

 

Interpretation of a Box and Whisker Plot:

  • Skewness: A longer whisker on one side suggests that the data is skewed towards that direction (positive skew for a longer right whisker, negative skew for a longer left whisker).
  • Central Tendency: The median (Q3) provides a measure of central tendency. Its position within the box indicates whether the data is symmetrically distributed around the median or skewed (long gap suggests skew in that direction).

 

Right skew (Option B):

i) Gap is more on the right side

ii) Rotate the image clockwise and interpret - gap on the right is longer - right sided skewness

Left skew (Negatively skewed): (Option C)

i) Gap is more on the left side - Mean

 

ii) Normal gap but left whisker is longer - left-sided skewness

 

Normal distribution: It represents symmetrically distributed data or that the data has no skewness (Option A)

i) Horizontal box

 

ii) Vertical box

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents to the emergency department following an alleged sexual assault by a man. The victim recalls that the assault occurred approximately 4 hours ago. Which of the following examination findings would least likely support evidence of the current sodomy assault?

choices.text: Linear abrasions or contusions in the perianal region
Paradoxical dilatation of anus during bimanual traction of buttocks

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Paradoxical dilatation of anus during bimanual traction of buttocks

 

Explanation:

 

  • Also called reflex anal dilatation (RAD), this refers to the reflexive opening of the anus when the buttocks are parted.

  • Not specific for sexual assault — it can occur in:

    • Children or adults with chronic constipation

    • Neurological conditions

    • Healthy individuals during examination (especially under stress)

  • Its presence does not confirm sodomy and is not considered reliable forensic evidence in the context of recent assault.

Therefore, it is the least supportive finding in the context of recent sodomy (within 4 hours).

Among the listed options, paradoxical anal dilatation is least likely to support recent sexual assault, especially in the absence of other corroborative signs. Its presence alone has low forensic value and can occur in non-abuse contexts.

Feature Habitual Passive Agent Non-Habitual Passive Agent
Anal sphincter tone Decreased or lax Normal or tight
Paradoxical anal dilatation Common (Option C) May be absent or mild
Perianal scars Frequently present (due to repeated trauma) Absent or rare
Radial mucosal folds Effaced or obliterated due to repeated stretching Usually well preserved
Rectal mucosa  May show signs of prolapse or eversion Normal unless recent severe trauma (Option D ruled out)
Local injury (abrasion/laceration) Usually absent (tissues adapted over time) Common after recent assault (Option A ruled out)
Pain/tenderness Often absent Typically present post-assault
Sphincter contraction on touch May be absent or weak Present (normal reflex)
Medical history May include chronic constipation or previous assaults Often no relevant history

 

  • These findings are not diagnostic in isolation and should always be interpreted in the context of history, time since assault, and forensic standards.

  • The presence of chronic changes (like loss of radial folds, laxity, and scarring) supports the possibility of habitual anal intercourse.

  • In contrast, acute traumatic signs such as abrasions, contusions, and fresh lacerations point toward non-habitual (recent) assault.

 

Dried semen around the anus (Option B):

  • Semen can dry within a few hours but still be detectable by forensic tests like:

    • Acid phosphatase test

    • PSA test

    • Sperm detection under microscope

  • Strongly supports recent penetration and ejaculation.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman with a history of chronic constipation visits her primary care physician. She has been prescribed bisacodyl, a stimulant laxative, to help with her bowel movements. The physician advises her to take the medication before bedtime.

What is the BEST explanation for prescribing bisacodyl before bedtime?

choices.text: Bisacodyl takes 6-8 hours to reach the small bowel, thus needs to be given at bedtime for morning evacuation.
Bisacodyl has an associated sedative effect, thus needs to be prescribed before sleep.
The drug requires hydrolysis by endogenous esterases in the bowel for activation, which takes 6–10 hours on oral dose.
Bisacodyl mechanism of action involves the process of fermentation, which needs 6-8 hours to take place.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) The drug requires hydrolysis by endogenous esterases in the bowel for activation, which occurs after 6–10 hours on oral dose.

Explanation:

Bisacodyl and other Stimulant laxatives require hydrolysis by endogenous esterases in the bowel for activation, so the Bisacodyl effects are seen after 6–10 hours of an oral dose.

However, Bisacodyl can also be given via rectal suppositories which act within 15-60 mins.

 

  • Bisacodyl acts by causing low grade inflammation in small and large bowel, stimulating intestinal motility and promoting accumulation of water and electrolytes. Hence, there’s no relation with the drug reaching the colon to act. (Option A ruled out)
  • Bisacodyl does not have any sedative or sleep inducing effect. (Option B ruled out)
  • Bisacodyl does not involve fermentation. It is activated by the process of hydrolysis by endogenous esterases. (Option D rule out)

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with double vision, drooping of the right eyelid, and difficulty moving his right eye in multiple directions. On examination, the patient has normal visual acuity, ptosis, restricted eye movement, decreased sensation over the forehead, and absent corneal reflex on the same side. What is the most likely diagnosis and which cranial nerve is/are most likely affected in this condition?

choices.text: Superior orbital fissure syndrome; III, IV, V, and VI nerves
Tolosa Hunt syndrome; II, III and IV nerves

questions.solution:
Superior orbital fissure syndrome typically involves cranial nerves III (oculomotor), IV (trochlear), V1 (ophthalmic branch of the trigeminal nerve), and VI (abducens), which pass through the superior orbital fissure. Clinical manifestation of ptosis (III), ophthalmoplegia (III, IV, VI), sensory loss over the forehead, and absent corneal reflex (V1) points towards the diagnosis of this syndrome.

 

Superior orbital fissure syndrome:

  • Also known as the Rochon-Duvigneaud syndrome. (Option D ruled out)
  • It is caused by compression of structures anterior to the orbital apex.

 

Etiology:

  • Most common cause is trauma
  • Idiopathic
  • Neoplasias
  • Meningitis, syphilis, sinusitis, herpes zoster
  • Inflammation - Lupus, sarcoidosis, Tolosa-Hunt syndrome (Episodes of unilateral orbital pain, cranial nerve involved and granulomatous inflammation)
  • Vascular phenomena - carotid-cavernous fistulas, retro-orbital hematoma, and carotid aneurysms

 

Pathophysiology: Involvement of the structures passing through the superior orbital fissure (III, IV, VI, and the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve). (Option A)

 

Clinical features:

  • Pain (retro-orbital ache)
  • Sensory loss in the distribution of ophthalmic division of the 5th cranial nerve
    • Absent corneal reflex
    • Decreased sensation over the forehead
  • Ipsilateral ophthalmoplegia due to 3rd, 4th, and 6th cranial nerve involvement
  • Ptosis due to 3rd nerve paralysis

 

Investigations:

  • CT, MRI
  • Angiography- vascular causes of the syndrome

 

Orbital apex syndrome; optic nerve (Option B):

  • It is a symptom complex due to the involvement of structures present at the apex of the orbit (structures passing through the superior orbital fissure and the optic canal)
  • So the cranial nerves involved are II, III, IV, V, and VI
  • Optic nerve (II) involvement causes visual loss and afferent pupillary defect

 

Tolosa Hunt syndrome; II, III, and IV nerves (Option C):

  • It is idiopathic nonspecific granulomatous inflammation involving the cavernous sinus and orbital apex causing compression of surrounding nerves.
  • Commonly manifests as painful ophthalmoplegia and presents as superior orbital fissure syndrome or orbital apex syndrome depending upon the extent of involvement
  • Clinical manifestations in this scenario suggest there is no involvement of the optic nerve (II)

questions.text: A 45 y/o male patient presents with abdominal pain and distension. A CT scan reveals multiple appendices epiploicae, particularly prominent in the sigmoid colon. Which of the following statements regarding the anatomy of the large intestine is false?

choices.text: The caecum is typically 8-10 cm long and is a common site for appendices epiploicae.
The sigmoid colon, which is S-shaped, leads directly into the rectum.
The total length of the large intestine in adults ranges from 1 to 1.5 meters.
Appendices epiploicae are more common in the distal colon.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) The caecum is typically 8-10 cm long and is a common site for appendices epiploicae.

 

Explanation:

The caecum is not typically 8-10 cm long, and appendices epiploicae are more prevalent in the sigmoid colon and distal colon.

 

Length of the Large Intestine and Its Components:

 

Total Length of the Large intestine length in a living adult: 1 to 1.5 metres (Option C ruled out)

Components of the Large Intestine:

 

Component

Description

Caecum (Option A)

Blind pouch at the beginning of the large intestine and is approximately 6 cm long

Vermiform Appendix

Narrow tube, 6-10 cm long, attached to the caecum

Ascending Colon

Travels upward from the caecum (20-25cm long)

Right Colic Flexure

Bend between ascending and transverse colon

Transverse Colon

Crosses the abdomen horizontally

Left Colic Flexure

Bend between transverse and descending colon

Descending Colon

Travels downward from the left colic flexure (10-15 cm long)

Sigmoid Colon

S-shaped segment leading to the rectum (Option B ruled out)

Rectum

Final straight portion, ~15 cm above the anal canal

 

Appendices Epiploicae:

 

Feature

Details

Description

Small, fat-filled pouches of peritoneum on the colon's surface.

Location

Few or absent on caecum and ascending colon (Option A).

More common on the distal colon (Option D ruled out).

Numerous on the sigmoid colon; can enlarge with obesity.

Absent on rectum.

 

Taeniae Coli

  • They are are three distinct longitudinal bands of smooth muscle found in the colon.
  • They help in peristalsis in the colon.
  • The arrangement of Taenia coli allows for the characteristic haustra or pouches of the colon, contributing to its segmented appearance.
  • There are 3 types:

 

Type of Taeniae Coli

Position

Free Taenia

Located on the antimesenteric aspect, opposite the mesentery.

Omental Taenia

Positioned posterolaterally.

Mesocolic Taenia

Positioned posteromedially, between the free taenia and the mesentery.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female slipped while demonstrating an exercise in a fitness class, landing on her outstretched right arm. She arrives at the emergency department with severe pain in her right wrist and forearm. Upon examination, her wrist appears unstable. Based on the X-ray findings, which of the following statements is true regarding her condition?

choices.text: Posterior interosseous nerve is commonly involved

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Fracture of necessity

 

Explanation:

The presented scenario with the radiograph indicates a Galeazzi fracture, also known as a Piedmont fracture, a fracture of necessity (requiring surgery), and a reverse Monteggia fracture, characterised by the distal third of the radius associated with a dislocation of the distal radioulnar joint.

Galeazzi fracture

Aetiology

  • It is more common in adults.
  • Three times more common than Monteggia fracture (Option C)

Mechanism

  • Fall on an outstretched hand (marked pronation of the forearm).
  • Direct blow on the dorsolateral side of the forearm

Clinical features

  • Prominence and tenderness at the distal end of the ulna (main feature).
  • Piano key sign: It is a deformity where the ulnar styloid moves up and down when pressure is applied, resembling a piano key. This movement indicates subluxation or dislocation of the joint.

X-ray

Reveals a fracture of the distal third of the radius and a dislocation of the distal radioulnar joint.

Treatment

Surgery is necessary (fracture of necessity) (Option A): ORIF with long plate and screw (treatment of choice).

 

Complications

  • Nerve injury
    • Ulnar nerve injury.
    • Anterior Interosseous nerve injury (Option D)
  • Entrapment of Extensor carpi ulnaris tendon (rare).

Galeazzi sign (Option B), also known as the Allis test, is primarily associated with hip conditions, particularly in assessing developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH) in infants, and is unrelated to the Galeazzi fracture.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male was shot during a robbery while walking home at night. The weapon used was identified as a firearm, and forensic investigators recovered a bullet from the scene, as shown in the image below. Identify it.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Dum dum bullet

 

Explanation:

The image depicts a Dum Dum bullet, which is a type of semi-jacketed bullet.

 

Types of Bullets

 

Type

Description

Images

Dum-dum bullet

(Option D)

A jacketed bullet that leaves an area near the nose uncovered to expose the core.

Hollow point bullet

(Option A)

The modern Dum Dum bullet features a pit at the nose. Upon impact, pressure in the pit causes the lead ring to expand into a mushroom shape, resulting in increased soft tissue damage and a higher incapacitation index.

Soft point bullet

A jacketed bullet with an open tip that exposes some lead inside expands upon impact but more slowly than a hollow-point bullet.

Tandem bullet (Piggyback bullet)

Bullets eject one after another when the first bullet fails to exit the barrel and is pushed out by a subsequently fired bullet (faulty ammunition or a firearm that hasn't been used for years).

Duplex bullet

It contains two projectiles by design (used in military rifles) and enters a target at different points.

Frangible bullet

Designed to fragment or disintegrate upon impact, made of copper, powdered tungsten, lead, or iron. They do not ricochet.

Souvenir or sleeping

Bullet (Option B)

A bullet remains in the body for a long time without fresh bleeding, surrounded by a dense fibrous tissue capsule. It can result in lead poisoning.

  

Armour-piercing bullet

A jacketed bullet (penetrates armour) with an inner core of hard, high-density metal like tungsten, tungsten carbide, depleted uranium, or steel, featuring a truncated cone.

Incendiary bullet

(Option C)

A type of military bullet designed to ignite a fire in the target.

Tracer bullet

It leaves a visible mark or "trace" during flight, allowing the shooter to see where the shot impacts.

Nontoxic shot or Green bullet

It replaces the copper-jacketed lead core with a copper-jacketed tungsten, steel, bismuth, tin, or nylon core. It does not release toxic lead (lead-free) into the environment (green bullet).

Exploding bullet

A bullet designed to detonate or break apart uses an explosive or deflagrant, causing extensive damage to the victim. These bullets pose a risk to medical personnel, as they may explode during procedures if they fail to detonate in the body.

Boat tail bullet

The cartridge's rear end is tapered rather than squared off to stabilise the projectile in flight.

Poisoned bullets

Contains curare, ricin or aflatoxin.

  

Wadcutter

Specifically designed for shooting paper targets at close range and high velocities.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with a history of bloody diarrhea followed by decreased urine output, lethargy, and paleness. Laboratory tests reveal hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and elevated creatinine levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Typical Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS)

Types and Causes
  • STEC-HUS: Caused by E. coli O157 (Shiga toxin)
  • Atypical HUS: Caused by genetic mutations, immune issues, pregnancy, cancers, medications

Pathophysiology and Pathology
  • Shiga toxin damages blood vessels in kidneys and brain

Clinical Features
  • Typical HUS: Bloody diarrhea, decreased urine output, paleness, lethargy, seizures
  • Atypical HUS: No bloody diarrhea, High blood pressure, mild breathing difficulties (Option C).

Diagnosis and Laboratory Investigations

Triad:

  • Hemolytic anemia
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Acute kidney injury
 

Blood tests: Anemia, low platelet count, elevated creatinine

Stool cultures for E. coli O157 in STEC-HUS

Complications
  • Acute: Seizures, stroke, heart failure, death
  • Chronic: Chronic kidney disease (CKD)

Differential Diagnosis
  • ITP: Affects platelets only, lacks hemolytic anemia and kidney injury (Option A).
  • DIC: Widespread clotting and bleeding, different clinical features (DIC) (Option B)

Treatment
  • Supportive care
  • Plasma exchange for aHUS
  • Antibiotics not recommended for STEC-HUS

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presents with right lower quadrant pain for the past 24 hours. On examination, the surgeon demonstrates cutaneous hyperesthesia in an area bounded by a line joining the anterior superior iliac spine, the umbilicus, and the pubic symphysis. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding this clinical sign?

choices.text: This sign is known as Sherren's triangle and indicates retro-cecal appendicitis
The hyperesthesia is due to irritation of the T10-L1 nerve roots by the inflamed appendix
This sign is highly specific for appendicitis and rules out other causes of right lower quadrant pain
The presence of this sign contraindicates the use of laparoscopy for appendectomy

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) The hyperesthesia is due to irritation of the T10-L1 nerve roots by the inflamed appendix

 

Explanation:

 

Sherren's triangle:

  • It is a clinical sign in acute appendicitis characterized by cutaneous hyperesthesia in the right lower quadrant.
  • The area is roughly triangular, bounded by lines joining the anterior superior iliac spine, umbilicus, and pubic symphysis.
  • It is caused by irritation of the nerves supplying the anterior abdominal wall (T10-L1) by the inflamed appendix.

Clinical features of appendicitis

Symptoms

Pain

Initial: Vague, dull pain around the umbilicus.

Progression: Pain localizes to the right lower quadrant (RLQ) due to parietal peritoneum involvement.

Nausea and Vomiting

Due to abdominal inflammation.

Anorexia

Loss of appetite.

Signs

Tenderness

Tenderness at McBurney's point (one-third of the distance from the anterior superior iliac spine to the umbilicus on the right side).

Rebound Tenderness

Increased pain upon sudden release of pressure on the abdomen, indicating peritoneal irritation.

Rovsing's Sign

Positive when palpation of the left lower quadrant causes pain in the right lower quadrant, suggesting peritoneal irritation.

Psoas Sign

Pain on passive extension of the right hip, indicating irritation of the iliopsoas muscle group.

Obturator Sign

Pain elicited by internal rotation of the right thigh while supine, suggesting irritation of the obturator internus muscle.

Dunphy's Sign

Increased pain in the RLQ with coughing, indicating peritoneal irritation.

Aaron's Sign

Referred pain in the epigastrium upon pressure over McBurney's point.

Ten Horn Sign

Increased pain during gentle traction or pulling of the right testicle in male patients, suggesting an inflamed appendix close to the right spermatic cord.

 

While this sign is indeed known as Sherren's triangle, it is not specific to retrocecal appendicitis (Option A). It can be present in various positions of the inflamed appendix.

 

While Sherren's triangle is associated with appendicitis, it is neither highly specific nor does it rule out other causes of right lower quadrant pain (Option C). Other conditions like mesenteric adenitis or gynecological issues can sometimes produce similar findings

 

The presence of Sherren's triangle does not contraindicate any specific surgical approach (Option D). The choice between open and laparoscopic appendectomy depends on various factors including surgeon preference, patient characteristics, and available resources

questions.text: Determine which syndrome linked to atrial septal defect is accurately paired with its corresponding gene.

choices.text: Familial ASD without heart block- NKX2.5

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Holt-Oram- TBX5

 

Explanation:

Genetic Conditions Associated with ASD:

 

Syndrome

Associated Genes

Cardiac Defects

Holt-Oram (Option D)

TBX5

ASD, VSD, TOF, left isomerism

Down Syndrome

-

ASD, AV septal defects

Patau Syndrome

-

ASD, VSD, PDA, valve abnormalities

Edwards Syndrome

-

ASD, VSD, PDA, valve abnormalities

CHARGE Association

CHD7

ASD, VSD, PDA, TOF

Kabuki Syndrome

MLL2

ASD, VSD, TOF, aortic coarctation, TGA

Ellis–van Creveld syndrome

EVC, EVC2

ASD, common atrium

Noonan Syndrome (Option B ruled out)

PTPN11
