Cri du chat syndrome

(Option A ruled out)

CTNND2

ASD, VSD, PDA, TOF

Familial ASD

NKX2.5 (with heart block), GATA4 (without heart block) (Option C ruled out)

ASD

questions.text: 32-year-old man presents with generalized oedema and frothy urine. Laboratory results show 24-hour urine protein: 8 g/day, serum albumin: 2.2 g/dL, serum cholesterol: 310 mg/dL and creatinine is 1.3 mg/dl. USG guided kidney biopsy was done and H and E image is shown. Electron microscopy shows widespread effacement of podocyte foot processes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis:

  • The Light microscopy image shows segmental sclerosis and obliteration of normal histology of glomerulus seen in FSGS. The electron microscopy findings and age group align with this presentation. Option A is seen in children commonly and has normal glomerular appearance on histological examination.

Disease

Typical Age

Light Microscopy (LM)

Electron Microscopy (EM)

Special stain/Notes

Minimal Change Disease

Children (Peak: 2–6 yrs.); also adults

Normal glomeruli

Diffuse podocyte foot process effacement

IF: negative

Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis

Young adults; common in African ancestry; secondary to HIV, heroin, obesity

Focal, segmental sclerosis & hyalinosis

Foot process effacement (patchy, segmental)

Poor steroid response

Membranous Nephropathy

Adults (40–60 yrs.)

Diffuse GBM thickening; ‘spikes’ on silver stain

Subepithelial immune deposits called ‘spike and dome’ appearance

IF: granular IgG & C3

Renal Amyloidosis

Older adults; often with chronic inflammatory diseases (RA, TB, FMF, MM)

Amorphous, acellular mesangial & capillary wall deposits

Non-branching fibrils (8–10 nm) randomly arranged

Congo red stain: apple-green birefringence under polarized light

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department with palpitations and shortness of breath. Upon assessment, he is found to have narrow-complex tachycardia at a rate of 180 beats per minute. He reports no chest pain or hypotension. What is the most appropriate initial management for this stable patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Administration of adenosine

 

Explanation:

  • Administration of adenosine because it is the first-line treatment for stable narrow-complex tachycardia. Adenosine acts quickly to potentially terminate the arrhythmia by interrupting the reentrant pathways, making it the most appropriate choice in this scenario.

 

Adult Tachycardia Algorithm

  • Management follows the Advanced Cardiac Life Support (ACLS) guidelines.
  • Treatment decisions depend on patient stability and tachycardia characteristics.

Key Steps

  1. Initial Assessment:
    • Check for signs of tachycardia.
    • Determine stability:
      • Signs of instability:
        • Chest pain
        • Shortness of breath
        • Altered mental status
        • Hypotension
        • Pulmonary edema
        • Ischemic changes on ECG
  2. Rhythm Type Identification:
    • Classify based on QRS complex "list-style-type:square" aria-level="3">Narrow-complex: QRS < 0.12 seconds
    • Wide-complex: QRS ≥ 0.12 seconds
  3. Management Based on Stability:

Stability

Narrow-Complex Management

Wide-Complex Management

Stable

Pharmacological options:

  • Adenosine
  • Beta-blockers
  • Calcium channel blockers

Antiarrhythmics, e.g., amiodarone (Option B ruled out)

Unstable (Option C ruled out)

Synchronized cardioversion

Synchronized cardioversion
  1. Synchronized Cardioversion:
    • Start at 50 joules, increase if needed.
    • Ensure synchronization with R wave to prevent ventricular fibrillation.
  2. Post-Resuscitation Care:
    • Monitor for complications after cardioversion or stabilization.

Observation and reassurance (Option D):

  • This is insufficient management for a tachycardic patient, even if stable.
  • Immediate treatment is warranted.

questions.text: A 70 kg patient is scheduled for elective open-heart surgery that is expected to last over 4 hours. According to fluid replacement guidelines, which of the following is the most appropriate additional fluid replacement rate to compensate for the third space volume loss for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 560 mL/hr

 

Explanation:

  • For major surgery, such as open-heart surgery, the fluid replacement guideline recommends a rate of 6-8 mL/kg/hr.
  • For a 70 kg patient: Minimum rate: 70 kg×8 mL/kg/hr=560 mL/hr

Fluid Replacement Based on Type of Surgery

  • Minor Surgery:
    • Eg. Herniorrhaphy
    • Fluid replacement: 2-4 ml/kg/hr
    • Duration: 45 minutes to 1 hour
  • Moderate Surgery:
    • Eg. Cholecystectomy
    • Fluid replacement: 4-6 ml/kg/hr
    • Duration: Up to 2 hours
  • Major Surgery:
    • Eg. Bowel resection
    • Eg. Fluid replacement: 6-8 ml/kg/hr
    • Duration: Usually more than 4 hours

Types of Fluids and Volume Replacement

Crystalloids

Colloids
  • Small molecules
  • Less effective than colloids at stabilizing hemodynamic endpoints
  • Higher volumes are needed in the ICU compared to colloids (3:1)
  • Larger molecules
  • More effective at stabilizing hemodynamic endpoints
  • Advantages:
    • Cost-effective
    • Easy to use
    • Provide immediate fluid resuscitation
  • Advantages:
    • May provide a more swift volume expansion in the intravascular space (1:1)
  • Disadvantages:
    • May increase edema
  • Disadvantages:
    • Expensive
    • Risk of allergic reactions.
    • Potential for blood clotting disorders
    • Risk of kidney failure
  • Examples:
    • Normal saline
    • Balanced electrolyte solutions (e.g., Lactated Ringer's, PlasmaLyte)
    • 5% dextrose in water (D5W)
    • Hypertonic 3% saline
  • Examples:
    • Albumin (5%, 25%)
    • Plasma protein fraction (5%)
    • Dextran (Dextran 70, Dextran 40)
    • Hetastarch (hydroxyethyl starch)

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient with a history of diabetes mellitus and hypertension visits your clinic. During the consultation, you advise the patient to adopt a diet that reduces fat and salt intake. What type of diet is being recommended to this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Prudent diet

Explanation:

Prudent diet:

  • A temporary diet that adheres to dietary goals.
  • Beneficial for managing diabetes, post-op patients, cardiovascular and renal diseases.
  • Includes:
    • Fat intake: < 20-30% of total energy intake.
    • Saturated fats: < 7% of total energy intake
    • Cholesterol < 200 mg/day
    • Salt intake to <5 gm per day
    • Increase complex carbohydrates and avoid alcohol consumption.
    • Cholesterol: HDL Ratio < 3.5
    • Diet adapted for special needs: pregnancy, lactation, growth etc.

 

Most people consume a staple diet (Option A), which is culturally acceptable depending on the plants native to a region.

A high-protein diet (Option C) emphasizes higher protein intake and is often used for muscle-building or specific weight-loss plans.

Balanced diet (Option D): A diet that includes all the necessary nutrients (carbohydrates, proteins, fats, vitamins, and minerals) in the right proportions. Relevance: While generally healthy, this is too broad a term. It doesn't specifically emphasize reduced fat and salt, which is key in this case.

questions.text: A 26-year-old patient presents to the emergency department with severe pain and tenderness after sustaining an injury from a fall. An X-ray of the region is provided below. Considering the mechanisms of injury, what is the most common cause associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Fall on the shoulder

 

Explanation:

The scenario with X-ray findings points towards a right Clavicular fracture, most commonly caused by a fall directly onto the shoulder.

 

Clavicle or Collarbone:

  • It is a long, slightly S-shaped bone located horizontally at the junction of the neck and trunk. It articulates medially with the sternum and the cartilage of the first rib and laterally with the acromion process of the scapula.
  • Structural features: It is the only long bone that lies horizontally, does not contain a medullary cavity, and remains subcutaneous along its entire length.
  • Ossification:
    • It is the first bone to begin ossifying (between the fifth and sixth week of fetal development) and the last to finish ossification (around 25 years of age).
    • It is the only long bone that ossifies from two primary centers.
    • It primarily ossifies in the membrane, except for its medial end, which ossifies in cartilage (unlike other long bones).

 

Mechanism of Injury:

  • Fall on the shoulder: The most common mechanism is a fall directly onto the point of the shoulder, accounting for 91% of cases.

Direct injury (Option A):
Incorrect because direct trauma (such as a blow or impact over the clavicle) is a less common mechanism than indirect force from a shoulder fall.

Fall onto an outstretched hand (Option B):
Incorrect because this mechanism typically causes scaphoid fractures, distal radius fractures, or shoulder dislocations, not clavicle fractures.

Fall from a height (Option D):
Incorrect because while it can result in clavicle fractures, it is not the most common cause. It usually leads to multiple injuries, and the clavicle is not selectively involved unless the person lands on their shoulder.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman with a history of mitral valve replacement (on warfarin) and trigeminal neuralgia (on carbamazepine) has been prescribed clarithromycin for a chest infection. Her regular medications include amlodipine and atorvastatin. Her INR is 1.3 (target > 3 for mechanical heart valve). Which drug most likely interacted with warfarin to give this INR?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Carbamazepine

Explanation:

  • Carbamazepine is a strong enzyme inducer, particularly of CYP2C9 and CYP3A4, which are responsible for metabolizing warfarin.
     
  • Enzyme induction leads to increased metabolism of warfarin, resulting in reduced plasma levels and a lower INR (as seen in this case: INR 1.3).
     
  • This is dangerous in patients with mechanical heart valves who require INR > 3 to prevent thromboembolic complications.
     

Mechanism table:

Drug

Effect on Warfarin

Mechanism

Carbamazepine

↓ INR (↓ warfarin effect)

CYP inducer → ↑ warfarin metabolism

Clarithromycin

↑ INR (↑ warfarin effect)

CYP inhibitor → ↓ warfarin metabolism

Amlodipine

No significant effect

No major CYP interaction

Atorvastatin

Mild unpredictable changes

Competes with warfarin at CYP enzymes

Pharmacokinetics of Warfarin:

Parameter

Details

Absorption

Oral

Kinetics

Zero-order kinetics at high doses

Excretion

Excreted in bile, safe in renal failure

Protein Binding

99% bound to albumin

Dialysis Removal

Not dialyzable due to high protein binding

Important Drug Interactions with Warfarin:

Enzyme Inhibitors (↑ INR) – Mnemonic: SICKFACES.COM

Drug

Sodium Valproate

Isoniazid

Cimetidine

Ketoconazole

Fluconazole

Alcohol (binge)

Chloramphenicol

Erythromycin

Sulfonamides

Ciprofloxacin

Omeprazole

Metronidazole

Enzyme Inducers (↓ INR) – Mnemonic: CRAP GPS

Drug

Carbamazepine

Rifampin

Alcohol (chronic)

Phenytoin

Griseofulvin

Phenobarbital

Sulphonylureas

 

Amlodipine (Option A): Incorrect. No major effect on INR or warfarin metabolism.
 

Atorvastatin (Option B): Incorrect. May have minor interactions but not a strong inducer/inhibitor.
 

Clarithromycin (Option C): Incorrect. Would increase INR, not decrease it.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male was involved in a high-speed motor vehicle accident. On examination, he has a high-riding prostate on rectal exam, and blood is noted at the urethral meatus. He complains of difficulty in urination, and imaging reveals a pelvic fracture. Retrograde urethrography confirms a complete disruption of the posterior urethra. After initial stabilization, Which of the following is the most definitive method of management for this patient?

choices.text: Immediate Surgical Repair of the Urethra

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Delayed Urethroplasty 3 months post-injury

 

Explanation:

 

Delayed urethroplasty is the gold standard for definitive management of posterior urethral injuries, typically performed 3-6 months after the injury to allow inflammation to subside, Improve surgical outcomes, and reduce the risk of complications.

 

Management & Complications of urethral injuries

 

 

Anterior Urethral Injuries

Posterior Urethral Injuries

Management
  • Minor Injuries: Managed conservatively with catheterization or suprapubic catheter if severe bruising
  • Severe Injuries: Surgical intervention like primary repair, urethroplasty, or end-to-end anastomosis
  • Antibiotics: To prevent infection
  • Initial Management: Suprapubic catheterization for urinary diversion
  • Delayed Urethroplasty (Definitive management): 3-6 months post-injury after inflammation and fibrosis have subsided
  • Primary Realignment: Occasionally attempted if conditions permit
  • Endoscopic Realignment: For selected cases, though often reserved for acute management

Complications
  • Urethral stricture (risk of recurrence)
  • Erectile dysfunction (especially if injury near the penile base)
  • Urinary incontinence (less common)
  • Infection (urethritis or abscess formation)
  • Urethral stricture (most common long-term complication)
  • Urinary incontinence (due to sphincter damage)
  • Erectile dysfunction (common, due to injury near neurovascular structures)
  • Bladder neck contracture
  • Chronic pelvic syndrome

 

Immediate surgical repair (Option A) is generally not recommended due to the high risk of complications like infection and stricture formation. This approach is more suitable for anterior urethral injuries.

 

Suprapubic catheterization (Option B) is a temporary measure for diverting urine and stabilizing the patient, not a definitive treatment.

 

Long-term Foley catheterization (Option D) is also temporary and can lead to complications; definitive surgical repair is usually required.

questions.text: A 37-year-old man is complaining of heart palpitations, nausea, and facial flushing after being bitten by the insect shown in the image. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Chagas disease.

 

Explanation:

  • The image is of the Reduviid bug, and the disease transmitted is Chagas disease.

 

Reduviid bug

Synonyms
  • Cone-nose bugs

Location
  • Mexico, Central America, and South America

Morphology
  • An inch or more in length
  • Adults have wings

Feeding

  • Exclusively on the blood

Habitat
  • Cracks, fissures, and other hiding places in walls, ceilings, and animal habitations

Health impact
  • Transmit Trypanosoma cruzi [a protozoa], the causative agent of Chagas' disease, causes intense itching, nausea, flushed face, and palpitations of the heart.

Control measures
  • Insecticides like HCH or dieldrin

 

Scrub typhus (Option B): Incorrect because it is transmitted by chiggers (larval mites), not Reduviid bugs.

Tularaemia (Option C): Incorrect because it is transmitted by ticks, deer flies, or direct contact with infected animals, not Reduviid bugs.

Sleeping sickness (Option D): Incorrect because it is transmitted by tsetse flies (Glossina species), not Reduviid bugs.

questions.text: A Pap smear from the transformation zone shows cells with blue-green nuclei, orange-red cytoplasm, and pink superficial cells. Which stain components are responsible for the cytoplasmic colors seen?

choices.text: Bismarck brown and light green SF
Orange green 6 and light green SF

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Eosin Y and orange green 6

 

Explanation:

 

Contents of a Pap Stain:

  1. Hematoxylin: Stains nuclei blue.
  2. Eosin Y: Stains acidophilic cytoplasm cells pink to red. 
  3. Bismarck brown: Stains basophilic cells blue-green. 
  4. Orange green 6: Stains keratin and erythrocytes orange-red 
  5. Light green SF: Stains keratin orange-red. 

Eosin Y + Orange G 6 = cytoplasmic stains in Pap smear.

 

Normal Pap Smear

Abnormal Pap Smear
  • Superficial and squamous cells are typically seen in a normal Pap smear.
  • When stained appears as, 
    • Nuclei: Blue
    • Cytoplasm: Orange-red

 
  • Cellular atypia, presents as,
    • Nuclear enlargement
    • Irregular nuclear shape
    • Increased nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratios
    • Abnormal cell arrangements.

questions.text: Renal tubular acidosis that presents with hyperkalemia is?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - RTA 4:

  • RTA 4 occurs secondary to diabetic nephropathy, obstructive uropathy, or chronic tubulointerstitial disease and leads to hypo-reninemic hypoaldosteronism due to damage to Distal tubule. Less aldosterone explains impaired potassium excretion and resultant hyperkalemia.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a history of COPD on medication presented to the ER with complaints of headache and chest pain. His ECG showed ventricular arrhythmia, and he subsequently experienced a seizure. He had recently begun taking the anti-gout medication allopurinol. What medication is he likely using for COPD?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Theophylline

Explanation :

  • Theophylline has a narrow therapeutic index.
  • It is metabolized by the CYP1A2 enzyme. Thus, enzyme inhibitors (eg. allopurinol) increase blood levels of theophylline causing toxicity.

Drugs reducing the effect of theophylline

Drugs increasing the effect of theophylline
  • CYP enzyme inducers
  • Drugs include
    • Griseofulvin
    • Phenobarbitone
    • Phenytoin
    • Rifampicin
  • Smoking and alcohol
  • CYP inhibitors
  • Drugs include
    • Ciprofloxacin
    • Omeprazole
    • Cimetidine
    • Allopurinol
    • Erythromycin

questions.text: Which of the following by-products from the Krebs Cycle is involved in heme synthesis?
questions.solution:
• Succinyl-CoA and glycine are precursors for δ-aminolevulinic acid (ALA), the first step in heme synthesis.
  • In the heme synthesis, succinyl-CoA combines with glycine to form δ-aminolevulinic acid (ALA), the first step.
  • Succinyl-CoA is replenished via anaplerotic reactions involving amino acids like Valine, Isoleucine, and Methionine, which are converted to Propionyl-CoA before forming Succinyl-CoA.
  • Propionyl CoA from odd fatty acid breakdown enters the pathway by converting to Succinyl CoA.

Citrate (Option A) is a 6-carbon molecule formed from acetyl-CoA and oxaloacetate. Citrate serves as an intermediate in the TCA cycle and plays a key role in fatty acid and cholesterol synthesis by transporting acetyl-CoA from the mitochondria to the cytoplasm.

α-Ketoglutarate (Option B) is a 5-carbon molecule involved in amino acid metabolism and serves as an intermediate in the Krebs Cycle.

  • It undergoes a Transamination Reaction to form Glutamate, which is a Reversible reaction.(α-Ketoglutarate ↔ Glutamate)
  • Glutamate is derived from α-ketoglutarate and can be synthesized from Histidine, Proline, Arginine, and Glutamine via transamination and deamination reactions.

Malate (Option D): Malate is an intermediate in the Krebs Cycle, formed from fumarate and converted into oxaloacetate.

  • Malate can be converted to pyruvate by Malic Enzyme, generating NADPH, which is crucial for fatty acid synthesis.
  • It is crucial as pyruvate can yield both Acetyl CoA (Pyruvate dehydrogenase) and Oxaloacetate (Pyruvate carboxylase), enabling their entry into the Citric cycle.

questions.text: A donor cornea is harvested and needs to be preserved for a planned corneal transplant for 10 days. Which of the following storage methods is most appropriate for preserving the donor cornea?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Optisol GS

 

Explanation:

  • Optisol GS is designed for intermediate-term storage, effective for up to 2 weeks, making it suitable for preserving the cornea for up to 10 days.

Storage of Cornea

 

Short-term Storage

(24 to 96 hours)

Intermediate-term Storage

(up to 2 weeks)

Long-term Preservation

(months to years):
  • Moist Chamber Method (Option A): Preserve the whole globe at 4°C in a refrigerator for up to 48 hours.
  • McCarey Kaufman (M-K) Medium (Option B):
    • Pink-colored medium containing TC-199, Dextran-40, HEPES buffer, and gentamicin.
  • Optisol GS:
    • Contains chondroitin sulfate, dextran, ascorbic acid, vitamin B12, ATP precursors, gentamicin, and streptomycin.
  • Other Media: Cornisol, Eusol, and Life-GE medium also available for up to 2 weeks.
  • Glycerine Preservation: Effective for 3-4 weeks.
  • Organ Culture Method: Preserves cornea at 30°C to 37°C for up to 35 days.
  • Cryopreservation (Option D): Preserves corneal button at -70°C for up to 1 year.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old patient presents with erosions, blisters, and crusts in the groin and thigh region as shown below. His blood tests reveal he has antibodies against collagen VII. What is the most probable diagnosis?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Epidermolysis bullosa aquisita

Explanation:

This clinical scenario and the presence of antibodies against collagen VII suggest a diagnosis of epidermolysis bullosa aquisita (EBA).

Epidermolysis bullosa aquisita:

It is a subepidermal blistering disease defined by autoantibodies against type VII collagen. It has two forms:

  1. Mechanobullous variant: Skin fragility, erosions, blisters, crusts, and scars on trauma‐prone areas such as the hands, knuckles, elbows, knees, and toes
  1. Inflammatory variant: present similar to bullous pemphigoid.

HPE examination will show subepidermal blistering with immunofluorescence showing linear deposition of IgG at the dermal-epidermal junction. Patients have antibodies against collagen VII.

Pemphigoid diseases and target antigen:

Disease

Target antigens

Bullous pemphigoid

BP 180, BP 230

Pemphigoid gestationis

BP 180, BP 230

Linear IgA disease

LAD1

Epidermolysis bullosa acquisita

Collagen VII

Bullous systemic lupus erythematosus

Collagen VII

Cicatricial pemphigoid

BP 180

Mucous Membrane Pemphigoid

BP 180, laminin 332

Dermatitis Herpetiformis

Epidermal transglutaminase

 

Incorrect options 

Linear IgA disease (Option A): Characterized by linear deposition of IgA at the basement membrane zone. Common in children (chronic bullous disease of childhood) but also occurs in adults. Not associated with anti-collagen VII antibodies. Typically shows “string of pearls” arrangement of blisters.

Bullous pemphigoid (Option B): Involves IgG antibodies against BP180 (collagen XVII) and BP230, not collagen VII. Causes tense subepidermal blisters, usually in the elderly. Common on trunk and extremities, less often in groin. Not associated with anti-collagen VII antibodies.

Pemphigus vulgaris (Option D): Caused by IgG antibodies against desmoglein 3 (and sometimes desmoglein 1). Leads to intraepidermal (suprabasal) blisters, which are fragile and rupture easily. Mucosal involvement is common. Not associated with collagen VII.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male presents with jaw pain, swelling, difficulty opening his mouth, and trouble chewing after being struck in the face during a fight. What is the most common site for mandibular fractures?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Condylar region

 

Explanation:

The most common site of mandibular fracture is the condylar region.

 

Fracture of Mandible

  • Fractures of the mandible have been classified according to the Dingman classification, as per their location as shown in the figure below,

Fig: Dingman classification

  • The sequence of mandibular fracture sites, from most common to least common, is as follows:
    • Condylar region (weakest part of the mandible) (Option A)
    • Angle of mandible (Option B)
    • Body of mandible (Option D)
    • Symphysis menti. (Option C)
  • Clinical features:
    • Pain and trismus (most common)
    • Malocclusion of teeth and deviation of the jaw to the opposite side on opening the mouth (in case of displaced fragments)

 

Guardsman fracture (Parade ground fracture)

  • A variant of mandibular fracture in which trauma on the symphysis menti results in the bilateral sub-condylar region fracture.

Fig: Guardsman fracture

 

  • Managed by Open reduction with titanium wiring.
  • Complication: TMJ (temporomandibular joint) ankylosis can occur due to prolonged immobilisation from closed reduction performed for more than three weeks for fractures.

questions.text:
Which two of the following statements about serous, mucinous, and mixed glands are correct?


	Serous glands produce a proteinaceous, enzyme-rich watery fluid, while mucinous glands secrete mucopolysaccharides that form a thick, viscous mucus.
	Cells of serous acini are triangular with centrally placed rounded nuclei, whereas cells of mucous acini are tall with flat nuclei at their bases.
	The pancreas is an example of a mixed gland, containing both serous and mucous secreting acini.
	The lumen of mucous acini is typically smaller than that of serous acini.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1 and 2 are correct

Explanation:

Serous gland

Mucous gland

Mixed gland
  • The secretions of serous glands are proteinaceous in nature. Cells secrete an enzyme-rich watery fluid.
  • Cells of serous acini are triangular with a rounded nucleus. Their nuclei are centrally placed.
  • E.g. pancreas.
  • In mucous glands, the secretion contains mucopolysaccharides. Cells secrete mucus which is a thick, viscous, and jelly-like protective lubricant known as mucin.
  • Cells of mucous acini are tall with flat nuclei at their bases.
  • The lumen of these acini is larger than the serous acini
  • E. g. goblet cells, and minor salivary glands of the tongue and palate.
  • The gland contains acini that secrete both mucus and serous secretions
  • E.g. submandibular and sublingual glands.

 

Fig: Histology of serous and mucinous glands

 

 

Fig: Histology of mixed glands

 

 

The other options B, C, and D are incorrect as they either misrepresent the functions or locations of these glands.

questions.text: A baby is delivered at 38 weeks gestation to a mother with a history of Rh incompatibility. The delivery was uneventful, but the neonatologist is concerned about the possibility of hemolytic disease due to the mother's sensitization status. The baby appears slightly jaundiced. Which of the following investigations is most appropriate to perform after birth?

choices.text: MCA peak blood flow measurement via USG Dopp

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Direct Coomb's test

 

Explanation:

 

  • This test is appropriate after birth to assess the newborn’s condition and is used to detect antibodies that are bound to the surface of the baby's red blood cells, which is crucial for diagnosing hemolytic disease of the newborn (HDN).

Erythroblastosis fetalis

Investigations During Pregnancy:

  • Determine the blood group (ABO and Rh) of the fetus:
  • Check the Hb levels and hematocrit of the baby
  • Non-invasive: USG Doppler (Middle cerebral artery peak blood flow) (Option B)
  • Indirect Coomb's test in the mother (to check the sensitization status) (Option D)

Investigations After Birth:

  • Maternal & Neonatal ABO & Rh blood grouping
  • Direct Coomb's test (usually positive for the baby)
  • Anemia
  • Cord blood bilirubin levels (Unconjugated)
  • Peripheral smear (to check for evidence of hemolysis)
  • Increased reticulocyte count
  • Increased LDH

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a chain-breaking antioxidant?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option D- Glutathione Peroxidase

Glutathione Peroxidase is a preventive antioxidant, not a chain-breaking antioxidant.

Antioxidants are substances that help control and reduce lipid peroxidation by neutralizing free radicals, which can cause cellular damage.

Classification of Antioxidants:

1. Preventive Antioxidants:
  • Reduce the rate of chain initiation.
  • Examples:
    • Glutathione Peroxidase (Option D)
    • Catalase
    • Selenium

2. Chain-Breaking Antioxidants (Option A, B and C ruled out):
  • Interfere with chain propagation by stabilizing free radicals.
  • Examples:
    • α-Tocopherol (Vitamin E)
    • β-Carotene (Vitamin A)
    • Vitamin C
    • Superoxide Dismutase (SOD)

questions.text: A 43-year-old man presents with abdominal pain, diarrhea, and progressive numbness in his limbs after consuming food at a barbecue. Over the next few weeks, he develops hair loss and severe neurological deficits, including confusion and muscle weakness. He is non-hypertensive and diabetic. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Thallium poisoning

Explanation:

Thallium poisoning is consistent with the entire clinical picture, including gastrointestinal symptoms, progressive neurological deficits, hair loss, and a history of potential exposure through food.

Characteristic

Description

Symptoms
  • Alopecia (1-2 weeks)
  • Painful polyneuropathy (GBS-like)
  • Butterfly-pattern maculopapular rash
  • Loss of lateral 2/3 of eyebrows (Sign de Sourcil)
  • Mee's lines on nails (Other causes: Arsenic poisoning, selenium poisoning, renal failure and chemotherapy)

Antidote

Prussian Blue (Berlin Blue; potassium ferric hexacyanoferrate) which sequesters thallium ions in the intestine, preventing their absorption

Acute gastroenteritis (Option A): While the initial symptoms of abdominal pain and diarrhea could suggest this, the subsequent neurological deficits and hair loss are not typical for gastroenteritis.

Guillain-Barré Syndrome (Option B): is unlikely because it doesn't typically present hair loss.

Diabetic neuropathy (Option D): Although the patient has diabetes, the acute onset of these symptoms, especially following a specific event, points more towards poisoning rather than chronic diabetic complications.

questions.text: A 67-year-old female with a history of osteoarthritis, significantly affecting her quality of life, is scheduled for knee replacement surgery. After exploring her options, she decides to opt for epidural anaesthesia. All of the following are the disadvantages of epidural anaesthesia, except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) High risk of post-dural headache

Explanation:

Epidural anaesthesia involves a challenging technique, may produce a patchy level of the blockade, has a delayed onset of action, and presents a very low risk of post-dural headache.

 

Advantages and disadvantages of epidural anaesthesia:

Advantages

Disadvantages
  • It can be used for long-duration surgeries (catheter)
  • Low risk of Post dural headache (PDH) (Option A)
  • The level of anaesthesia can be altered (drug volume)
  • Hemodynamic stability
  • Difficult technique (Option D)
  • Patchy (inadequate) level of blockade (due to the presence of fat) (Option C)
  • Accidental dural puncture (severe PDH)
  • Bupivacaine toxicity: Cardiac arrhythmias
  • Lignocaine toxicity: Seizures
  • Not used for emergency surgeries (due to the late onset of anaesthesia) (Option B)

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with polyuria, growth failure, fair skin, blond hair, and photophobia. Slit-lamp examination reveals cystine crystals in the cornea. Which genetic mutation is most likely responsible for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) CTNS

 

Explanation:

  • The scenario is that of Cystinosis.

Cystinosis

Etiology

Mutations in the CTNS gene (Option C) (encoding the protein cystinosin, a cystine transporter) → Defect in cystinosin → Accumulation of cystine crystals in major organs (kidney, liver, eyes, brain)

Clinical Features

  • Renal: Fanconi syndrome, polyuria, polydipsia, rickets, growth failure

  • Skin/Hair: Fair skin, blond hair

  • Eyes: Photophobia, retinopathy, ↓ visual acuity

  • Other: Fever (↓ sweating), hypothyroidism, hepatosplenomegaly, delayed puberty

Diagnosis
  • Detection of cystine crystals in the cornea.
  • Confirmed by measuring increased cystine content in leukocytes.

Treatment
  • Therapy with cysteamine (converts cystine to cysteine)
  • Cysteamine eye drops for ocular involvement.

questions.text: A 45 y/o female has a firm, enlarging swelling below her left ear for 6 months. O/E, the swelling is hard and nodular, with no signs of facial nerve involvement. FNAC shows malignant cells, and imaging reveals a tumour in both lobes of the parotid gland with no distant metastases. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Mucoepidermoid carcinoma

 

Explanation:

  • Mucoepidermoid carcinoma is the correct diagnosis in this scenario.
  • Mucoepidermoid carcinoma is the most common malignant tumour of the parotid gland, particularly in adults.
  • The slow-growing, firm, and nodular swelling in the parotid region, combined with the FNAC findings of malignancy, strongly indicates this type of carcinoma.
  • The absence of facial nerve involvement and the slow progression further support this diagnosis, as these features are typical of low- to intermediate-grade mucoepidermoid carcinoma.
  • High-grade carcinoma typically is locally aggressive and shows nodal metastases.

 

Pleomorphic adenoma (Option A): This is a benign salivary gland tumour and the most common neoplasm of the parotid gland. It typically presents as a painless, mobile, and slow-growing mass.

Adenoid cystic carcinoma (Option C): While adenoid cystic carcinoma is another malignant salivary gland tumour, it is more commonly associated with minor salivary glands and tends to show a propensity for perineural invasion, often leading to early facial nerve involvement.

 

Warthin’s tumor (Option D) or Cystadenoma lymphomatosum, is a benign salivary gland tumor, commonly found in the parotid gland. It typically presents as a painless, cystic mass, often in older males.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child diagnosed with HIV is scheduled to begin therapy with nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs). His baseline laboratory tests reveal a haemoglobin level of 8.8 g/dL. Which of the following drugs should be avoided in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Zidovudine

Explanation:

Zidovudine, a NRTI is known for its hematologic side effects, which include anaemia and neutropenia.

  • 2nd line drug for anemic children is Abacavir

Side Effects of NRTIs

Common side effect


 
  • Bone marrow suppression
  • Alopecia
  • Myopathy
  • Pancreatitis
  • Peripheral neuropathy
  • Hepatic steatosis
  • Lipodystrophy: Obese, type 2 DM
  • Lactic acidosis: Inhibition of human mitochondrial respiration

Zidovudine
(Option C)


 
  • Bone marrow suppression (maximum risk): anaemia, leukopenia
    • Contraindicated: Severe anaemia if Hb <9 gm/dl
    • Treatment: Erythropoietin injections
  • Erythrocytic macrocytosis
  • Nail hyperpigmentation
  • Alopecia, myopathy (due to depletion of mitochondrial DNA)
  • Hepatotoxicity and steatosis
  • Insomnia

Didanosine
  • Pancreatitis (maximum risk)

Stavudine

Maximum risk for:

  • Peripheral neuropathy
  • Hepatic steatosis
  • Lipodystrophy
  • Lactic acidosis

Abacavir
(Option A)
  • Steven-Johnson syndrome (fatal hypersensitivity) with HLAB 5701 (Contraindicated if tested positive)
    • Fever, abdominal pain, and rash within 6 weeks of starting abacavir necessitates immediate discontinuation
  • Myocardial infarction

Emtricitabine
(Option D)
  • Skin hyperpigmentation in sun-exposed areas
  • Exacerbation of hepatitis B with abrupt discontinuation

Lamivudine

(Option B)
  • Exacerbation of hepatitis B with abrupt discontinuation (Safest NRTI)

Never combined NRTIs
  • Increased toxicity: Stavudine, Didanosine and Zalcitabine
  • Cross-resistance:
    • Lamivudine and Emtricitabine
    • Zidovudine and Stavudine

questions.text: A 26 y/o woman presents with cramping and heavy vaginal bleeding at 10 weeks gestation. She had a previous cesarean delivery two years ago. Ultrasound confirms a diagnosis of incomplete abortion with retained products of conception. What is the most appropriate surgical management among the options provided?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Manual Vacuum Aspiration (MVA)

Explanation:

  • MVA is a safe and effective method for surgical management of first-trimester abortions, particularly for gestations up to 12 weeks.

Trimester

Procedure

Description

Image

1st

Manual Vacuum Aspiration (MVA)
  • MVA is an outpatient surgical abortion procedure used up to 12 weeks of gestation.
  • The procedure involves dilating the cervix and inserting a cannula attached to a manual vacuum aspirator or a 60-mL syringe.
  • The cannula is used to remove retained tissue from the uterus.
  • The approximate pressure is around -610 mmHg.

 

Electric Vacuum Aspiration (EVA)
  • EVA is similar to MVA.
  • Instead of a manual syringe, it uses an electric pump to generate suction to remove retained products of conception.

 

 

Dilation and Curettage (D&C)

(Option B)
  • D&C is performed up to 12 weeks of gestation by dilating the cervix and using instruments like curettes and suction cannula.
  • MVA and EVA are preferred over sharp D&C for being safer and more efficient.

 

2nd

Dilation and Evacuation (D&E) (Option C)
  • D&E is a 2nd-trimester abortion method involving cervical dilation using osmotic dilators. Ovum forceps are then used to remove the pregnancy tissue.
  • Draining amniotic fluid before removing the fetus is crucial to minimize the risk of amniotic fluid embolism during the procedure.

 

 

Hysterotomy (Option D)
  • A hysterotomy is a surgical procedure where the uterus is incised to remove the fetus.
  • Reserved for 2nd-trimester abortions where other methods are not feasible or have failed.

questions.text: A 47-year-old male patient with a history of adrenal carcinoma and hypercortisolemia is scheduled for a surgical procedure. The anesthesiology team is evaluating induction agents that suppress adrenal function. Which of the following agents can be used in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Etomidate

Explanation:

Etomidate inhibits 11β-hydroxylase in the adrenal cortex, which is essential for cortisol synthesis. Therefore, it effectively decreases cortisol levels, making it suitable for patients with hypercortisolemia.

Etomidate

Mechanisms of Action
  • Depresses the reticular activating system.
  • Mimics GABA's inhibitory effects by binding to GABA A receptors, particularly the R(+) isomer.

Structure-Activity Relationships
  • Contains a carboxylated imidazole
  • The imidazole ring provides water solubility in acidic solutions and lipid solubility at physiological pH.

Pharmacokinetics

Absorption: Only available for IV use, primarily for induction of anesthesia.

Distribution: Rapid onset due to high lipid solubility; redistribution lowers plasma concentration post-awakening.

Biotransformation: Rapidly hydrolyzed by hepatic microsomal enzymes to an inactive metabolite.

Excretion: Hydrolysis products are excreted in urine.

CNS Effects
  • Induces hypnosis via GABA A receptor modulation (0.3 mg/kg).
  • Reduces cerebral blood flow and cerebral metabolic rate of oxygen without affecting MAP.
  • Decreases intracranial pressure (ICP) by 50% in patients with increased ICP.

Respiratory Effects
  • Minimal impact on ventilation; does not release histamine.
  • May cause brief hyperventilation and mild apnea, with slight PaCO2 increase.

Cardiovascular Effects
  • Minimal impact on sympathetic tone and myocardial function.
  • It may cause mild arterial blood pressure decline without significant changes in cardiac output or contractility.

Endocrine Effects
  • Inhibits 11β-hydroxylase, reducing cortisol and mineralocorticoid production, leading to adrenal suppression. 

Clinical Uses
  • Induction dose: 0.2 to 0.6 mg/kg IV.
  • Suitable for patients with cardiovascular issues and
  • Increased ICP
  • Effective in treating endogenous hypercortisolemia.

Side Effects
  • Associated with postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV),
  • Pain on injection,
  • Myoclonic movements, and
  • Hiccups.

Pre-medication with lidocaine can reduce pain; myoclonus can be lowered with midazolam or magnesium.

Novel Derivatives
  • Methoxycarbonyl etomidate (MOC): Rapidly metabolized, minimal adrenal suppression, similar hypnotic potency.
  • Carboetomidate: Reduces adrenal suppression potency, maintains hypnotic effects, minimal hemodynamic changes.
  • Methoxycarbonyl-carboetomidate: Combines benefits of etomidate without adrenal suppression, longer action duration.
  • CPMM and DMMM: Newer derivatives showing higher potency and rapid recovery post-infusion, promising in animal studies.

Propofol (Option A), Ketamine (Option B), and Thiopental (Option C) do not have specific effects on adrenal hormone synthesis and are not known to inhibit 11β-hydroxylase. They are primarily used for their anesthetic and sedative properties.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old male presents to the emergency department with acute onset right lower quadrant abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. On examination, he has right lower quadrant rebound tenderness and guarding. The doctor decides to take him up for an emergency surgery.

Which inhalation anaesthetic would be best for induction in this patient based on its MAC values and blood gas solubility?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Sevoflurane

Explanation:

  • Sevoflurane has a moderate MAC value (2%) and is also preferred for its additional benefit of rapid induction and recovery times due to its relatively low blood-gas solubility.
  • The patient’s complaints and clinical features point towards the suspicion of Appendicitis. Hence, he is possibly being taken up for an emergency laparoscopic appendicectomy.
  • COMPOUND A of sevoflurane causes renal toxicity

 

MAC Definition:

The concentration of the general anaesthetic in the alveoli of the lung that produces unresponsiveness to the surgical incision in 50% of patients.

 

Nitrous oxide (Option A): It has a very high MAC value (105%) and is not potent enough to be used as a sole anaesthetic agent.

 

Desflurane (Option C): It has a MAC value of around 6%, so it is less potent than sevoflurane. However, it has a very rapid onset and offset, making it suitable for short procedures and outpatient surgeries.

 

Halothane (Option D): It has a very low MAC value (0.75%), indicating high potency, but it is associated with significant side effects, including hepatotoxicity, and is less commonly used today.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female patient came to OPD complaining of swelling on the side of her face. On examination, the swelling was painless, smooth, soft, and non-tender. A CT scan was done to rule out dural attachment and a diagnosis of angular dermoid was made. How will you manage the case?

choices.text: Wide local excision with a 2 cm margin

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Surgical excision

 

Explanation :

  • Angular dermoid is a type of dermoid cyst that commonly occurs as a smooth, non-tender, soft swelling at the fronto-zygomatic suture.
  • The formation of an angular dermoid is due to the sequestration of ectodermal tissue during embryonic development, which gives rise to a cyst containing dermal elements like hair follicles, sebaceous glands, and sweat glands.
  • Angular dermoids are most often located near the lateral canthus, which is the outer corner of the eye where the upper and lower eyelids meet.
    • They may also occur near suture lines of the skull.
  • They are usually asymptomatic unless they become large enough to cause pressure effects on adjacent structures or become infected.
  • Diagnosis and Treatment:
    • Imaging: Ultrasound or CT scans may be used to evaluate the extent of the cyst, especially if deep or orbital involvement is suspected.
    • Surgical Excision: Complete surgical excision is the treatment of choice, especially if the cyst is causing cosmetic concerns or other symptoms. Careful dissection is required to ensure that the cyst is fully removed and to avoid recurrence.
    • If left untreated, angular dermoids sometimes undergo resorption or indentation of the underlying base. CT is done to rule out dural attachments.

questions.text:
Which among the given statements is wrong regarding resuscitation of newborn?

 

a) The recommended pressure of suction is 80 mmHg

b) Correct order of suction: mouth followed by nose.

c) The recommended pressure should never exceed >80 mmHg

d) Correct order of suction: nose followed by mouth
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) c & d are wrong

 

Explanations:

Suction of airways:

  • The correct order of suction: is mouth followed by nose.
  • When suctioning the nose, vagal stimulation may induce the baby to take a deep breath, potentially resulting in aspiration, if oral secretions are present.
  • The recommended pressure of suction is 80 mmHg
  • It should never exceed >100 mmHg

questions.text: A patient with a skin graft is experiencing mild swelling and oozing at the graft site 24 hours after surgery. Which phase of graft take is most likely occurring?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Imbibition

 

Explanation:

  • During the imbibition phase, which occurs within the first 24-48 hours, the graft survives through the diffusion of nutrients and plasma from the recipient bed.
  • The process of skin graft healing is called “Skin graft Take.”
  • The phases of graft take involve a series of 3 steps critical for the successful integration of a graft into the recipient site. These phases are
    1. Serum Imbibition (Plasmatic Circulation):
      • In the first 48 hours, the graft is sustained by plasma exudate from the capillaries in the host bed.
    2. Revascularization (Option C ruled out):
      • After 48 hours, two key processes commence.
      • Neovascularization, where new blood vessels grow from the recipient site into the graft, and inosculation, where graft and host vessels form direct connections.
    3. Organization:
      • This phase begins immediately after grafting, with a fibrin layer forming at the graft-bed interface to stabilize the graft.
      • By day 7, this layer is replaced by fibroblasts, and by days 10 to 14, the graft is typically well-adhered to the underlying bed.

The image is the logo for the National Family Welfare Program

questions.text: A 23-year-old man comes to the dermatology OPD. After examination, a diagnosis of onychomycosis was made, and he was started on oral terbinafine. What is the mechanism of action of this drug?

choices.text: Formation of pore in ergosterol membrane

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Inhibition of squalene epoxidase

Explanation:
 

Aspects

Terbinafine

Mechanism of action

Competitive inhibition of squalene epoxidase (Option C)

↓

Accumulation of squalene within fungal cells

↓

Inhibition of ergosterol synthesis

↓

Disruption of fungal cell membrane integrity

↓

Fungicidal action

Features

It has a high affinity for sebum and thus accumulates in sebum, stratum corneum and nails.

Uses

  • Topical: Used for treating tinea infections (ringworm) and pityriasis versicolor (fungal skin infection).
  • Oral: DOC for onychomycosis (fungal infection of the nails), tinea capitis (scalp ringworm), and extensive fungal lesions.

It is also used in oromucosal candidiasis as an alternative to fluconazole.

Side effects

Taste disturbance and rash; topical application causes dryness, itching and irritation.

Inhibition of thymidylate synthase (Option A)

  • Flucytosine (5-FC) converts into 5-fluorodeoxyuridylic acid within the fungal cell and acts as an inhibitor of thymidylate synthase.
  • It is a narrow-spectrum fungistatic agent active towards Cryptococcus neoformans and chromoblastomyces.

Inhibition of lanosterol 14-methylase (Option B)

  • Azoles inhibit fungal cytochrome P450 enzyme - lanosterol 15-methylase, which results in abnormal membrane formation.\
  • It is a broad-spectrum antifungal agent that is active against dermatophytes, candida and other deep fungal infections (except mucormycosis)

Formation of pore in ergosterol membrane (Option D)

  • Amphotericin B has lipophilic and lipophobic sides, forming micropores in the ergosterol membrane of the fungal wall.
  • It is a broad-spectrum fungicidal agent effective against Candida, Histoplasma, Sporothrix, Blastomycosis, and Leishmania.

questions.text: Which condition is characterised by extensive dystrophic calcification of the gallbladder wall?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Porcelain gallbladder

 

Explanation:

  • Porcelain gallbladder is characterized by extensive dystrophic calcification of the gallbladder wall.
  • This condition is associated with chronic cholecystitis and may lead to an increased risk of gallbladder carcinoma.

 

Porcelain gallbladder (Option A)

Hyalinizing cholecystitis (Option D)

Characterized by extensive dystrophic calcification of the gallbladder wall.

Characterized by complete replacement of the gallbladder wall and mucosa by dense fibrosis, with or without calcification.

Associated with chronic cholecystitis and an increased risk of gallbladder carcinoma

questions.text: A 68 y/o man with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and hypertension hasn't received any vaccines in recent years and is concerned about his increased risk of infections. Which of the following vaccines should be given to him?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) All of the above

Explanation:

Recommended Vaccines for Elderly Individuals

Vaccine Indication Schedule
Influenza Annual vaccination for all individuals ≥ 60 years 1 dose every year
Pneumococcal (PCV13, PPSV23) Prevents pneumococcal pneumonia, especially in chronic conditions PCV13 followed by PPSV23 after 1 year
Tdap/Td Tetanus, diphtheria, pertussis protection Tdap once, then Td booster every 10 years
Herpes Zoster (Zoster vaccine) Prevents shingles in adults ≥ 50 years 2 doses, 2–6 months apart

questions.text: A 32 year old male presents to a primary care clinic with complaints of urethral discharge and dysuria. He reports having unprotected sexual intercourse with multiple partners. On examination, you note purulent discharge from the urethra. Which colour kit would be most appropriate for initial management in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Grey

Explanation:

The grey colour kit in the NACO syndromic management approach is used for urethral discharge in males, which is suggestive of possible gonococcal infection (gonorrhoea).

STI Color Coded Kits under NACP- 2024:

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient is undergoing major abdominal surgery under general anesthesia. After induction of anesthesia, the patient's CVP is measured at 3 cm H2O. The patient’s heart rate is 110/min, blood pressure is 80/50 mmHg. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management step based on the CVP and clinical findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Administer a fluid bolus

Explanation:

Low CVP (3 cm H2O) suggests hypovolemia, which is consistent with the patient's tachycardia and hypotension. Administering a fluid bolus is the first-line treatment to increase preload and improve hemodynamics.

 

Central Venous Pressure (CVP) Monitoring:

CVP measures the pressure in the thoracic vena cava near the right atrium, reflecting right ventricular preload and overall fluid status.

Measurement Method (Invasive):

Central venous catheter placed in large veins (e.g., subclavian or internal jugular), connected to a pressure transducer

Normal Range: 3-8 mmHg.

Low CVP Causes:

  • Hypovolemia (blood loss or dehydration).
  • Venodilation (e.g., in septic shock).

Elevated CVP Causes:

  • Heart failure, fluid overload, valve dysfunction.
  • Increased intrathoracic pressure (e.g., mechanical ventilation, tension pneumothorax).

Clinical Use:

  • Guides fluid resuscitation.
  • Helps assess heart function and venous return.

 

Vasopressors (Option A) may be required if hypotension persists after adequate fluid resuscitation, but not as the initial step.

Blood transfusion (Option C) is not indicated unless there is evidence of blood loss or anemia.

Increasing anesthetic depth (Option D) is inappropriate here, as the patient is likely hypovolemic.

questions.text: A 32-year-old multiparous woman has just delivered a healthy baby boy vaginally. The obstetrician is now managing the third stage of labour and is observing for signs of placental separation. Which of the following signs is the most definitive sign of placental separation?

choices.text: Permanent lengthening of the umbilical cord
A gush of blood from the vagina

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Permanent lengthening of the umbilical cord

Explanation:

When the placenta detaches from the uterine wall, it descends towards the birth canal, pulling on the umbilical cord and causing it to visibly lengthen outside the vagina. This is considered to be the most reliable sign of placental separation.

A gush of blood from the vagina (Option B): This is often seen, especially in the Schultze method of separation, but it's not the surest sign. Some blood loss can occur before complete separation.

Rising of the uterine fundus (Option C): This sign, also known as the 'rising sign', suggests placental separation but can be affected by factors like bladder fullness or uterine tone.

Uterus becoming firm and globular (Option D): The uterus becoming firm and globular during the third stage of labour indicates uterine contraction and preparation for placental expulsion. It is the earliest sign of placental separation.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct about the Philadelphia chromosome?

choices.text: Balanced translocation between long arms of chromosome 9 and 22
Balanced translocation between short arms of chromosome 9 and 22
Unbalanced translocation between long arms of chromosome 9 and 22
Unbalanced translocation between short arms of chromosome 9 and 22

questions.solution: Correct answer is a: Balanced translocation between long arms of chromosome 9 and 22

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a diagnosis of schizophrenia has been on antipsychotic medication for over a decade. Her family has noticed that she has been experiencing involuntary movements for the past few months, including repetitive facial grimacing, lip-smacking, and jerky motions of her arms and legs. What is the drug of choice for treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
The scenario is diagnosed as medication-induced Tardive dyskinesia, for which the drug of choice is Valbenazine.

 

Tardive dyskinesia

Description

A delayed effect (abnormal involuntary movements) of antipsychotics typically occurs until after 6 months of treatment.

Cause

Supersensitization of dopamine (D) receptors due to prolonged exposure to antipsychotic medications.

Manifestations

Abnormal, involuntary movements such as:

  • Lip smacking
  • Chewing
  • Darting, twisting, and protrusion of the tongue (catching fly)
  • Choreiform hand movements (playing piano)
  • Facial grimacing
  • Finger movements and hand clenching
 

In Severe cases:

  • Torticollis (twisting of neck muscles to one side)
  • Retrocollis (neck extension)
  • Trunk twisting
  • Pelvic thrusting

Management

Prevention: Using antipsychotic medications only when indicated and in the lowest effective doses.

 

Regular monitoring: Patients taking antipsychotics should be regularly assessed for any signs of abnormal movements.

 

Treatment:

  • Reducing antipsychotic drugs (or stop if possible)
  • Switching the medication to clozapine (least EPS-causing) or atypical antipsychotics
  • VMAT (Vesicular Monoamine Transporter type 2) receptor inhibitor:
    • Valbenazine (drug of choice) (Option D)
    • Tetrabenazine- Lesser efficacy, more sedation than Valbenazine (Option C ruled out)

 

Propranolol (Option A) is a non-selective beta-blocker primarily used to treat hypertension, anxiety, and certain types of tremors. While it can help alleviate symptoms of akathisia and anxiety, it is ineffective for treating tardive dyskinesia.

 

Clonazepam (Option B) is a benzodiazepine used to treat anxiety disorders, panic disorders, and certain types of seizures but is not effective in managing tardive dyskinesia.

questions.text: A 45 year out female presents with persistent ear discharge, hearing loss, and a feeling of fullness in the ear. Upon examination, the otolaryngologist performs an otoscopic examination, which reveals an abnormal growth in the ear canal. Which diagnostic test is most useful for assessing the extent of her condition and guiding surgical planning?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) High-resolution CT

 

Explanation:

  • Based on the symptoms described-persistent ear discharge, hearing loss, a feeling of fullness in the ear, and the finding of abnormal growth in the ear canal, the most probable diagnosis is a cholesteatoma.
  • High-resolution CT (HRCT) is critical for assessing the severity of the cholesteatoma, evaluating any osseous damage, and aiding in surgical planning.
  • HRCT provides detailed imaging of bony structures and helps identify the extent of the cholesteatoma.

 

Investigations for cholesteatoma:

  • Otoscopic Examination:
    • Direct inspection of the eardrum using otoscopy, video-otoscopy, otomicroscopy, or video-telescopy.
  • Radiological Examination:
    • CT Scan:
      • Primary imaging technique to assess disease severity, osseous damage, and malformations.
      • High-resolution CT (HRCT) is often used before surgery.
    • MRI:
      • Provides detailed tissue distinction with different pulse sequences.
      • Cholesteatomas typically appear hyperintense on T2WI and hypointense/isointense on T1WI.
  • Tympanometric and Audiometric Tests:
    • Assess hearing loss; audiometry identifies conductive deficiencies.
    • Rinne’s and Weber's tests differentiate between conductive and sensorineural hearing loss.
  • Cholesteatoma is diagnosed using a combination of otoscopic examination, CT, MRI, and ancillary tests like tympanometry and audiometry.

 

Video-Otoscopy (Option A) is useful for visualizing the ear canal and eardrum directly but does not provide detailed information on the extent of disease or bony structures.

 

Rinne Test (Option C) is an audiometric test used to differentiate between conductive and sensorineural hearing loss but does not provide information on the extent of cholesteatoma or guide surgical decisions.

 

Diffusion-weighted MRI (Option D) helps detect recurrence or residual cholesteatoma, particularly after surgery, but HRCT is the primary imaging tool for pre-surgical assessment of the disease extent.

questions.text: Which of the following Connexin mutations is associated with cataracts?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Connexin 50


 

Explanation:

 

Connexin 46 and 50 mutations lead to cataracts.

 

Connexons:

  • Structures that form the gap junction present in the membrane of each cell.
  • 1 Connexon = 6 connexins

 

Connexins:

  • Protein subunits, which together form connexons.
  • They surround a channel.
  • When lined up with the channel in the corresponding connexon in the adjacent cell, it permits substances to pass between the cells without entering the ECF.

 

Mutated Connexins and associated diseases:

 

Mutated Connexin

Disease

Connexin 30

Clouston syndrome

Connexin 30.3 and 31

Erythrokeratoderma Variabilis

Connexin 26,30 and 31

Inherited deafness

Connexin 36

Predisposition to Myoclonic Epilepsy

Connexin 37

Predisposition to Arteriosclerosis

Connexin 46 and 50

Cataract

Connexin 40

Idiopathic Atrial fibrillation

Connexin 32

Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease

Connexin 26 (GJB2): Associated with non-syndromic sensorineural hearing loss, NOT cataracts. Most common cause of inherited deafness. (Option A)

Connexin 30 (GJB6) :Also linked to hearing loss, often in conjunction with Connexin 26. No established link to cataracts.(Option B)

Connexin 40 (GJA5): Found in the heart, particularly in the atria. Associated with cardiac conduction abnormalities (e.g., atrial fibrillation), not cataracts. (Option C)

questions.text: A 12y/o girl comes to the OPD with her parents complaining of multiple small, erythematous, scaly plaques on the trunk with a characteristic raindrop appearance 10 days after a streptococcal throat infection. An image of her lesions is given below. What is the appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Penicillin

Explanation:

  • The presentation is classical of guttate psoriasis, often seen in children and adolescents.
     
  • It typically occurs 1–3 weeks after a streptococcal pharyngitis or upper respiratory tract infection.
     
  • The appropriate treatment includes:
     
    • Eradication of the triggering streptococcal infection using penicillin (or amoxicillin).
       
    • Topical therapies (like corticosteroids or emollients) may help skin symptoms but do not address the underlying cause.
       
    • Reassurance may be needed, but antibiotic therapy is essential in acute, post-streptococcal guttate psoriasis.
       

Clinical Features of Guttate Psoriasis:

Feature

Description

Age group

Common in children and young adults

Trigger

Post-streptococcal pharyngitis (esp. Streptococcus pyogenes)

Lesion morphology

Multiple, small (<1 cm), erythematous, scaly plaques ("drop-like")

Distribution

Trunk, proximal limbs

Course

May resolve spontaneously or evolve into chronic plaque psoriasis

 

 

Topical corticosteroids (Option A):
 

  • Incorrect as first-line monotherapy in acute guttate psoriasis post-infection.
     
  • Can be used adjunctively, but antibiotic therapy is essential to treat the underlying streptococcal cause.
     

Reassurance (Option B):
 

  • Incorrect as sole treatment. Although guttate psoriasis may be self-limited, reassurance alone is not adequate when a recent streptococcal infection is present.
     

Doxycycline (Option D):
 

  • Incorrect because it is not the first-line agent against streptococcal infection in children.
     
  • Penicillin or amoxicillin is preferred.

questions.text: 30-year young female is diagnosed as having IBS. Which of the following is not a feature of irritable bowel syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is D: Nocturnal diarrhoea

  • Nocturnal diarrhoea does not occur in IBS. Night time sleep in not interrupted in IBS. Altered bowel habits and altered GI motility are features of IBS and leads to recurrent abdominal pain.

Rome IV Diagnostic Criteria for Irritable Bowel Syndrome

  • Recurrent abdominal pain, on average, at least 1 day per week in the last 3 months, associated with $\geq 2$ of the following criteria:
    • Related to defection
    • Associated with a change in frequency of stool
    • Associated with a change in form (appearance) of stool
  • Criteria fulfilled for the last 3 months with symptom onset at least 6 months prior to diagnosis.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presents to his cardiologist with complaints of exertional chest pain and shortness of breath. His family history is significant for the sudden cardiac death of his brother at the age of 28. Physical examination reveals a harsh systolic murmur and irregular heart sounds. Which of the following genes is most commonly involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Beta-myosin heavy chain

 

Explanation:

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM):

  • HCM is an autosomal dominant condition that occurs due to a mutation in the beta-myosin heavy chain.
  • In HCM, hypertrophy can occur in any part of heart but ir occurs maximally in the interventricular septum.
  • Due to hypertrophy of interventricular septum, left ventricle is narrowed and starts looking like a banana-shaped cavity.
    • Left ventricle is responsible for pumping blood to the body which will be affected due to this narrowing.
    • So in conditions like heavy physical activity, where body wants more blood, it can lead to sudden collapse and sometimes death of patient.
  • Under microscopic examination during autopsy, cardiac muscle fibres shows the classical halter-salter appearance (haphazardly arranged cardiac muscle fibres)

Titin (Option A): Titin mutations are seen in dilated cardiomyopathy.

questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic feature of Transfusion-Related Acute Lung Injury (TRALI)?

choices.text: Non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema within 6 hours of transfusion
Cardiogenic pulmonary edema within 24 hours of transfusion
Acute onset of fever and chills without respiratory symptoms
Gradual onset of jaundice and anemia several days after transfusion

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema within 6 hours of transfusion


 

Explanation :

TRALI is characterised by acute onset of respiratory distress and non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema occurring within 6 hours of a blood transfusion. It is caused by an immune reaction to donor antibodies or bioactive substances in the transfused blood.

 

Characteristics:

  • Onset: TRALI typically occurs within 6 hours of transfusion.
  • Symptoms:
    • Sudden onset of dyspnea (shortness of breath).
    • Hypoxemia (low blood oxygen levels)
    • Fever.
    • Hypotension.
    • Bilateral pulmonary infiltrates on a chest X-ray, indicating fluid accumulation in the lungs without cardiac cause.

 

 

TACO is a transfusion reaction with respiratory distress and cardiogenic pulmonary edema within 24 hours due to circulatory fluid overload. (Option B).

 

 

Febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reactions present with acute fever and chills without respiratory distress. (Option C)

 

 

Delayed hemolytic transfusion reactions present days to weeks later with gradual jaundice and anemia. (Option D)

questions.text: Which of the following statements about suicide inhibition is incorrect?

choices.text: The inhibitor covalently binds to the enzyme after being converted to a reactive intermediate.
Suicide inhibition is a reversible form of enzyme inhibition.
Suicide inhibitors resemble the enzyme's natural substrate.
Allopurinol acts as a suicide inhibitor of xanthine oxidase to manage gout.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Suicide inhibition is a reversible form of enzyme inhibition.

Explanation:

Suicide inhibition, is a special type of irreversible enzyme inhibition.

 

Process of Suicide Inhibition:

 

Examples of Suicide Inhibition:

 

Enzyme

Inhibitor

Mechanism

Clinical Application

Ornithine Decarboxylase (ODC)

Difluoromethylornithine (DFMO)

DFMO binds to ODC, is converted to a reactive form, and irreversibly inactivates the enzyme.

Treats trypanosomiasis by stopping polyamine synthesis in Trypanosoma parasites.

Xanthine Oxidase (Option D)

Allopurinol

Allopurinol is oxidized to alloxanthine, which forms an irreversible complex with xanthine oxidase.

Manages gout by reducing uric acid levels.

Cyclo-oxygenase (COX)

Aspirin

Aspirin acetylates a serine residue in COX, irreversibly inhibiting the enzyme.

Reduces inflammation and pain, and prevents heart attacks and strokes.

Examination reveals a slightly sunken fontanelle, dry mucous membranes, normal heart rate, prolonged capillary refill of 3 seconds, and slow skin recoil but of <2 seconds. What is the most likely assessment of this infant's hydration status?
questions.solution:
