questions.text: A 65-year-old man with a history of chronic heart failure presents for a follow-up appointment. He has been on digoxin therapy for several years. During the consultation, the cardiologist discusses the importance of therapeutic drug monitoring (TDM) to ensure optimal digoxin levels for effective treatment. TDM is NOT done in which of the following?

choices.text: Detect drug levels in case of poisoning levels.
Use of aminoglycosides in patients with renal failure.
Drugs with a narrow therapeutic index.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Drugs with irreversible action.

Therapeutic drug monitoring (TDM) is the measurement of plasma drug concentration.

It is expensive and is only done in:

  • Drugs with low safety margin, e.g., Digoxin, Anticonvulsants, Antiarrhythmics, theophylline, aminoglycoside antibiotics, lithium, and tricyclic antidepressants. (Option C)
  • If individual variations are large, e.g., Antidepressants, Lithium.
  • Nephrotoxic drugs used in renal failure, e.g., Aminoglycoside antibiotics and vancomycin. (Option B)
  • In case of poisoning, detect drug levels and initiate treatment. (Option A)
  • In case of failure of response, e.g., Antimicrobials.
  • To check patient compliance, e.g., Phenytoin.

TDM is not done in

  • Drugs whose response is easily measurable, e.g., Antihypertensives, hypoglycemics, diuretics, oral anticoagulants, and inhalational general anaesthetics.
  • Drugs activated in the body, e.g., Levodopa.
  • 'Hit and run drugs' (whose effect lasts much longer than the drug itself), e.g., reserpine, guanethidine, MAO inhibitors, omeprazole.
  • Drugs with irreversible action, e.g., Organophosphate anticholinesterases, phenoxybenzamine.

questions.text: A 65 y/o patient with a history of complete heart block presents for follow-up. The patient's ECG shows an idioventricular rhythm with a ventricular rate of 30 beats per minute. What is the most likely location of the pacemaker driving the patient's idioventricular rhythm?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer:D) Purkinje Fibres

Explanation:

In a complete heart block with a very slow ventricular rate, the pacemaker is often located in the Purkinje fibers, resulting in rates around 30 beats per minute or slower.

While the Bundle of His can be involved in conduction, Purkinje fibers are more likely at this low rate (Option C).

Sinoatrial (SA) Node vs. Atrioventricular (AV) Node

  • Role in Heart Block:
    • Conduction Disruptions can occur between the SA and AV nodes or within the AV node, leading to heart block.
    • Complete Heart Block: SA node signal doesn't reach ventricles; ventricles beat independently at a slower rate driven by a ventricular pacemaker.
    • Ventricular Pacemaker Location: Determines idioventricular rhythm rate.

Key Differences and Functions

 

Aspect

SA Node

AV Node

Intrinsic Rhythmicity

60-80 beats per minute(can go upto 100) (natural pacemaker of the heart) (Option A)

40-60 beats per minute (Option B)

Location

The upper wall of the right atrium

The lower wall of the right atrium

Function

The primary pacemaker; initiates the heart's rhythmic contractions

Delays impulses from atria; ensures coordinated contractions

Action Potential

Calcium-driven, slower conduction

Prepotentials

Present - Slow, gradual depolarizations observed

Parasympathetic Modulation

Acetylcholine decreases the firing rate

Ach decreases the firing rate by hyperpolarizing nodal cells, increasing potassium conductance, slowing the "funny" current (Ih), and reducing cAMP levels.

Sympathetic Modulation

Norepinephrine increases the firing rate

Norepinephrine: Increases firing rate by binding to β1 receptors, raising cAMP levels, and facilitating L-type calcium channel opening, accelerating depolarization.

Role in Heart Block

Fastest intrinsic rate, so normally unaffected

It can be a site of conduction disruption leading to heart block

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents to the psychiatrist with complaints of unusual sexual desires. He reports feeling intense sexual gratification when inflicting pain on his partner during consensual intimate encounters. He denies any interest in other forms of sexual activity and mentions that causing pain is the primary source of his sexual arousal. What is the most likely paraphilic disorder?
questions.solution:
Answer: A) Algolagnia

 

Explanation:

 

Algolagnia is a paraphilic disorder characterized by deriving sexual pleasure from inflicting pain on a partner

 

Category

Description

Sadism/Algolagnia

Getting satisfaction by giving pain to a partner.

Masochism/

Passive Algolagnia

Getting satisfaction by receiving pain from a partner.

Bondage

Combination of Sadism and Masochism.

Lust Murder

Murder acts as a stimulus for sexual arousal.

Urolagnia/Undinism/

Urophilia

Sexual arousal from urine smell, touch, or sight.

Uranism

Sexual gratification by fingering, fondling, licking, or sucking the genitalia of the opposite sex (Option B)

Coprophilia

Sexual arousal from fecal smell and touch.

Sexual Oralism
  • Fellatio: Oral stimulation of male genitalia.
  • Cunnilingus: Oral stimulation of female genitalia (Option D)

Exhibitionism

Showing private parts.

  • Streaking: Running naked in public.
 
  • Mooning: Showing bare buttocks (Mnemonic: Moon resembles buttocks) (Option C)
  • Flashing: Momentarily exposing body parts by quickly moving clothing (Mnemonic: like a flashlight)

Necrophilia

Sexual activity with a dead body.

Necrophagia

Eating parts of a dead body.

questions.text: A 35-year-old HIV-positive male presents to the clinic with a two-week history of profuse, watery diarrhoea and weight loss. His CD4 count is 150 cells/mm³, and stool examination reveals oocysts. What is the drug of choice used for treating this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Nitazoxanide

Explanation:

  • The patient has HIV with CD4 <200 and presents with chronic watery diarrhoea and oocysts in stool, suggestive of Cryptosporidium parvum infection.
     
  • Nitazoxanide is the drug of choice for cryptosporidiosis in immunocompetent individuals, and it is also used in immunocompromised patients, though its effectiveness may be reduced.
     
  • ART (antiretroviral therapy) is essential for immune reconstitution in such patients for optimal recovery.
     

Cryptosporidiosis in HIV Patients

Feature

Details

Causative Agent

Cryptosporidium parvum (protozoan parasite)

Common Symptoms

Profuse watery diarrhoea, weight loss, abdominal cramps

Stool Findings

Acid-fast oocysts

Risk Factors

CD4 count <200 cells/mm³

Treatment of Choice

Nitazoxanide

Adjunctive Measures

ART initiation/improvement, hydration, nutritional support

 

Benznidazole (Option A):
Incorrect. Used for Chagas disease (Trypanosoma cruzi), not for cryptosporidiosis.
 

Nifurtimox (Option B):
Incorrect. Also used for Chagas disease, not for Cryptosporidium infections.
 

Paromomycin (Option D):
Incorrect. An aminoglycoside with some activity against Cryptosporidium but less effective than nitazoxanide. Sometimes used in refractory cases or as adjunct.

questions.text: What is the primary purpose of applying toluidine blue to the anogenital area during the examination of rape victim?

choices.text: To enhance the visibility of foreign objects
To check for signs of infection

questions.solution:
Answer: B) To identify areas of micro-injury

 

Explanation:

 

Toluidine blue is a contrast agent used to highlight micro-injuries in the anogenital area, aiding in the forensic examination.

 

BNSS Section 184 - Medical examination of Victim of Rape

 

Step

Details

Request for Examination
  • Any police officer can request it within 24 hours.

Consent
  • Must obtain consent from the woman
  • Examination supervised by a female RMP.

Initial Examination
  • Ask the victim to remove clothing.
  • Examine and collect evidence from clothes.
  • Look for foreign objects (hairs, seminal stains) (Option A)
  • Search for physical injuries.

Detection of Micro Injuries
  • Apply toluidine-blue contrast to the anogenital area.

Swabs Collection
  • 4 swabs:
    • Smear: Prepare a smear for microscopic examination.
    • Sperm: Use saline for motility testing.
    • DNA Profiling (Option D)
    • Chemical Tests: Acid phosphatase, creatinine phosphokinase, lactate dehydrogenase.

Examination Position
  • Examine in lithotomy position under good lighting.

Hymen Examination
  • Use Glaister-Keene rods or hymenoscope
  • Look for tears (usually posterior at 5-7 o'clock position).

Vaginal Examination
  • Use a speculum for vaginal examination.

Cervical Examination
  • Use a colposcope for cervical examination.

Post-Examination Care
  • Treat STDs, injuries, or potential pregnancy.
  • Provide psychological support.

 

To check for signs of infection (Option C): Infection assessment typically involves clinical evaluation

questions.text: An ultrasound scan image of a 30-year-old woman who presented for a routine ultrasound at 6 weeks of gestation is shown below. What is the most significant ultrasound finding in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Lambda sign

 

Explanation:

  • USG shows the lambda sign or twin peak sign, which is characterized by two gestational sacs separated by a thick membrane, and a prominent triangular extension of the chorionic tissue at the junction of the two sacs.
  • This finding is indicative of a dichorionic-diamniotic twin pregnancy.

 

Twin pregnancy:

Placenta’s membrane status

Timing of cleavage

Diamniotic–Dichorionic

< 72 hours

Diamniotic–Monochorionic

Days 4–7

Monoamniotic–Monochorionic

Days 8–12

Conjoined

Day >13

Note: In dichorionic twin- The lambda sign or twin peak sign is seen. (Option A ruled out)

 

Snowstorm appearance (Option C):

  • It is typically associated with a molar pregnancy.

Pseudogestational sac (Option D):

  • It appears as a fluid-filled structure within the uterus that lacks the double decidua sign and typically has an irregular outline.
  • It is commonly associated with ectopic pregnancies or early pregnancy loss.
  • Hence, this option is incorrect.

questions.text: Given below are a few statements regarding the receiver operating curve. Which among the following is a false statement?

choices.text: The best investigation is the one whose curve is most upward and left
The test with the minimum surface area under the cure is the most effective
Can be used for comparing two or more diagnostic tests
Can be used for deciding optimal cut-off points

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) The test with the minimum surface area under the curve is the most effective

Explanation:

The test with the maximum surface area under its curve is the most effective in the receiver operating curve -  incorrect and is the false statement 

  • The Area Under the Curve (AUC) ranges from 0.5 to 1.

    • AUC = 0.5: Test is no better than chance.

    • AUC = 1: Perfect test.

  • A larger AUC means better diagnostic accuracy.

  • Therefore, the test with the maximum AUC is the most effective — not the one with the minimum area.

  • The ROC curve illustrates the performance of a diagnostic test by plotting sensitivity (true positive rate) against 1 – specificity (false positive rate) for various threshold values.

 

Incorrect options 

The best investigation is the one whose curve is most upward and left (Option A): True .A curve that bows most towards the upper left corner represents a test with high sensitivity and specificity, i.e., an excellent diagnostic test. The closer the curve is to the top-left corner, the better the test's discriminative ability.

Can be used for comparing two or more diagnostic tests(Option C): True. ROC curves are commonly used to compare the performance of two or more diagnostic tests. You can visually and statistically compare the AUCs of different tests to see which is superior.

Can be used for deciding optimal cut-off points (Option D): True. ROC curves help in identifying the threshold value that balances sensitivity and specificity. The optimal cut-off is often selected using the Youden index (sensitivity + specificity - 1), which maximizes test accuracy.

questions.text: A 34 year old woman presents with severe dysmenorrhea and chronic pelvic pain despite taking NSAIDs due to endometriosis. She desires fertility preservation. On examination, tender nodules are palpable on the uterosacral ligaments, and imaging confirms endometrioma on the left ovary. Given the clinical scenario, which of the following medications is most appropriate for the initial management of this patient's endometriosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Leuprolide

 

Explanation:

  • The patient’s complaint of severe dysmenorrhea and chronic pelvic pain despite initial management with NSAIDs, along with nodules and endometrioma, points towards severe endometriosis.
  • Irrespective of the size of the cyst, expectant management is done as the patient wants to conceive.
  • GnRH agonists (such as leuprolide) are a first-line treatment for moderate to severe endometriosis. They work by inducing a hypoestrogenic state, suppressing ovarian function, and reducing symptoms such as pelvic pain and dysmenorrhea.

 

GnRH Agonists:

  • Administered in depots or continuous forms, such as Leuprorelin, Naferelin, and Goserelin.
  • They cause desensitisation and downregulation of pituitary receptors, leading to endometrium atrophy. They are also referred to as medical hypophysectomy.
  • If GnRH agonists are to be administered for more than six months, an "Add-Back" regimen is recommended, which includes low-dose estrogens and raloxifene, a selective estrogen receptor modulator.

 

Danazol (Option B) is a synthetic androgen that suppresses ovarian function and reduces estrogen levels. It is effective in treating endometriosis-related pain but has androgenic side effects and is less commonly used due to its side effects and long-term risks.

 

Combined oral contraceptives (Option C) are used primarily for symptom relief and menstrual cycle regulation in mild cases of endometriosis.

 

Letrozole (Option D) decreases estrogen, leading to a loss of negative feedback on GnRH, which in turn increases FSH and LH, leading to the formation of cysts. Hence, it is combined with OCP / Progesterone and not given alone in severe cases.

questions.text: Which of the following is also known as the final impact indicator in the National family planning program?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Net Reproductive Rate (NRR)

Explanation: Net Reproductive Rate (NRR) is also the final impact factor in the National family planning program.

National Family Planning Program:

  • For a country's population to stabilise, a TFR of 2.1 is required.
  • It explains that every couple is giving birth to 2 children.
  • TFR is the most important epidemiological indicator of family planning 
  • For TFR to be 2.1, NRR (Net Reproductive Rate) must equal 1(Final impact indicator)
  • NRR equals 1 when the couple protection rate is >60%.
  • The couple protection rate is >60% when females of reproductive age undergo sterilisation.

questions.text: A 55 y/o male presents with flushing, diarrhea, and recurrent episodes of bronchospasm. Imaging reveals multiple masses in the ileum. Laboratory tests show elevated serotonin levels. What is the most likely type of tumor responsible for his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Midgut Carcinoid Tumor

 

Explanation:

  • Midgut carcinoid tumors develop in the jejunum, ileum, appendix, or right colon and are known for their high secretion of serotonin.
  • This hormone is responsible for the symptoms of carcinoid syndrome, such as flushing, diarrhea, and bronchospasm.
  • The presence of multiple masses in the ileum and elevated serotonin levels strongly suggest a midgut carcinoid tumor as the underlying cause.

questions.text: A 15 years old female who had a tonsillectomy 16 hours ago is currently under post-op monitoring, suddenly begins to bleed from the mouth and is noted to have hypotension with tachycardia. What is the most likely cause of this bleeding?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Slipping of ligature

 

Explanation:

  • The most likely cause of bleeding in this scenario is the slipping of a ligature. During tonsillectomy, ligatures control bleeding from the tonsillar bed.
  • If a ligature slips or becomes dislodged, it can lead to sudden bleeding, often occurring within the first 24 hours post-operatively (Reactionary hemorrhage). This can result in hypotension and tachycardia due to blood loss.

 

Hemorrhage is the most common complication post-tonsillectomy and is of 3 types based on the duration:

Type of Hemorrhage

Primary Hemorrhage

Reactionary Hemorrhage

Secondary Hemorrhage

Duration of occurrence

Immediate complication, occur at the time of surgery.

Happens within first 24 hours post surgery (Immediate complication)

Seen between 5th to 10th postoperative day.

Causes

Inadequate hemostasis or injury to the vessels (Option C)

Slipping of ligature (Option D), hypertension or the dislodging of clot.

Infection (Option B) or premature separation of the membrane (Option A)

Management

Application of pressure, ligation or electrocoagulation of the bleeding vessels.

Initially, remove the clot and apply pressure or use a vasoconstrictor. If these measures are ineffective, proceed with ligation or electrocoagulation of the bleeding vessels.

Initially by Antibiotics, if bleeding persists re-exploration is done.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with dark, hard nodules along his scalp hair, which he mistakenly believes to be lice nits. Upon microscopic examination, branched hyphae and arthrospores are observed. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his condition?
questions.solution:
Answer: B) Piedraia hortae

 

Explanation:

Piedraia hortae is the causative agent of black piedra, characterized by dark nodules on scalp hair and the presence of branched hyphae and arthrospores upon microscopic examination.

Piedra Infection

  • Superficial fungal infection affecting hair shaft.
  • Characterized by nodules.
  • Two main types: Black Piedra and White Piedra.

Black Piedra

Aspect

Details

Etiology

Caused by Piedraia hortae (dematiaceous fungus) (Option B).

Characteristics

Affects scalp hair; it is common in individuals with long hair and poor hygiene.

Clinical Features

Hard, black nodules that may resemble lice nits; complex structure of filamentous hyphae and spores; examined using KOH shows branched hyphae and arthrospores.

Diagnosis

Direct microscopic examination:

Branched hyphae and arthrospores

Culture:

Sabouraud dextrose agar shows dark colonies.

Treatment

Antifungal shampoos or systemic antifungals; treatment efficacy may be compromised by nodules' compact nature.

 

White Piedra

Aspect

Details

Etiology

Caused by Trichosporon species, commonly Trichosporon beigelli, Trichosporon inkin (Option A ruled out).

Characteristics

Affects facial, axillary, and pubic hair; typically asymptomatic.

Clinical Features

Whitish, loosely adherent nodules consisting of arthroconidia and blastoconidia.

Diagnosis

KOH examination and culture reveal yeast-like colonies.

Treatment

Topical antifungals such as ketoconazole shampoo.

 

 

Mixed Piedra

  • Rare condition involving both black and white piedra
  • Presents with both dark and light nodules
  • Requires careful mycological examination for accurate diagnosis

Candida albicans (Option C): Candida albicans do not cause superficial fungal infections of the hair shaft like piedra. Microscopy shows Candida yeast with pseudohyphae. This option is incorrect.

 

Malassezia furfur (Option D): Malassezia furfur do not cause piedra. It primarily affects the skin and is involved in conditions related to skin oiliness rather than hard nodules along the hair shaft. Microscopy shows yeast cells grouped in a “grape bunch” format with short, branched filaments or spaghetti and meatball appearance. This option is incorrect.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with confusion and lethargy. Blood tests show elevated levels of ammonia, suggesting hyperammonemia. Further tests indicate liver dysfunction. Which of the following best describes the process of oxidative deamination in amino acid metabolism?

choices.text: Removal of an amino group from an amino acid, resulting in the corresponding keto acid and ammonia.
Involves only transamination reactions in the cytoplasm.
Generates ammonia, which is directly excreted by the kidneys.
Predominantly occurs in the liver cytoplasm, producing glutamine.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Removal of an amino group from an amino acid, resulting in the corresponding keto acid and ammonia.

 

Explanation:

  • Oxidative deamination removes the alpha-amino group from an amino acid, producing a keto acid and ammonia.
  • This reaction, catalysed by glutamate dehydrogenase in liver mitochondria, is essential for ammonia detoxification and nitrogen balance.
  • The ammonia formed is detoxified in the form of glutamate.
  • The ammonia generated is processed through the urea cycle for excretion. (Option C)

 

 

Oxidative Deamination:

  • Process: Removes alpha-amino group from an amino acid, producing a keto acid and ammonia.
  • Common Amino Acid: Glutamic acid.
  • Enzyme: Glutamate dehydrogenase (GDH).

 

Transdeamination:

  • Step 1: Transamination (all organs) in cytoplasm forms glutamate. (Option D)
  • Step 2 (Oxidative decarboxylation): In liver mitochondria, GDH removes the amino group from glutamate, producing alpha-ketoglutarate and ammonia. (Option B)
  • Significance: It ensures efficient ammonia disposal, funnelling ammonia into the liver for detoxification via the urea cycle.

 

Minor deamination Pathways:

  • Involve enzymes like L-amino acid oxidase and D-amino acid oxidase.
  • Non-oxidative deamination targets specific amino acids, releasing ammonia.

 

L-Amino Acid Oxidase:

  • It deaminates L-amino acids in the kidney.
  • It generates hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) and ammonia as by-products.
  • H2O2, a reactive oxygen species (ROS), is broken down into O2 and H2O by catalase to mitigate damage from ROS.

questions.text: Which embryonic structure is the fascia of Denonvilliers derived from?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Cloaca

Explanation:

The fascia of Denonvilliers, also known as the rectoprostatic fascia (males) and rectovaginal fascia (females), originates from the embryonic cloaca, which later differentiates into components of the urogenital and digestive systems. It forms a distinct layer between the prostate and the rectum.

  • It is a continuation of the peritoneum from the pouch of Douglas (rectouterine pouch in females).
  • In males, it separates the rectum posteriorly from the bladder and the prostate anteriorly.
  • It does not originate from the prostate but descends from the peritoneal reflection.
  • It is composed of connective tissue, not smooth muscle.

 

Urogenital sinus (Option A) is an embryonic structure that gives rise to parts of the lower urinary tract and the internal genitalia in both males and females

Mesonephric duct (Option C), also known as the Wolffian duct, contributes to developing male internal genital structures, such as the vas deferens and seminal vesicles.

Paramesonephric duct (Option D), or Müllerian duct, develops into female internal genital structures, such as the fallopian tubes, uterus, and the upper part of the vagina.

questions.text: Which maternal health initiative launched by the National Health Mission focuses on improving the quality of care in labor rooms and maternity operation theaters?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) LaQshya

 

Explanation:

LaQshya—Labour Room Quality Improvement Initiative—focuses on decreasing preventable maternal and newborn deaths, illnesses, and stillbirths by enhancing the quality of care during labor and delivery and ensuring respectful maternity care.

 

Objectives include:

  • Managing complications like APH, PPH, preterm labor, and sepsis
  • Improving care during delivery and the postpartum period
  • Ensuring prompt referrals
  • Promoting patient satisfaction and respectful treatment for all pregnant women in public health facilities

questions.text: What is the type of torture mentioned in the image given below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Wet Submarine

 

Explanation:

The given image depicts a Wet Submarine

 

Torture: Defined as deliberate, systemic or wanton infliction of physical or mental suffering by one or more persons acting alone or on the orders of any authority to force another person to yield information or for any other reason.

 

Physical torture subtypes

Types of torture

Description

Wet Submarine

(Option A)

  • Fecal matter and other debris in the airways.

Black Slave

(Option B)

  • Hot metal skewer is inserted up the anus of the victim.
  • Perianal and rectal burns were seen.

Iron Chair/Confession chair /Interrogation chair

(Option C)
  • The victim is tied to an iron chair equipped with either wooden or iron spikes, which could be heated from below.

 

Judas cradle

(Option D)
  • The victim is first stripped and then suspended over a pointed pyramid.
  • The torture using ropes and pulleys, used to raise and lower the victim so that the point would penetrate the anus, vagina or scrotum.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient with ulcerative colitis presents with severe abdominal distension, pain, fever, and tachycardia. Abdominal X-ray shows colonic dilatation >6 cm. Ultrasound show no free fluid in peritoneal cavity. What is the first-line medical management for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is A: intravenous corticosteroids

  • The first-line medical management for a patient with severe colonic dilatation (>6 cm) on X-ray in the context of ulcerative colitis is intravenous corticosteroids, typically methylprednisolone 40 to 60 mg daily. This treatment quickly reduces severe colonic inflammation and systemic toxicity. Note that our patient does not have perforation of bowel as there is no free fluid in peritoneal cavity
  • If there is no improvement within this period, escalation to second-line medical therapies such as infliximab or cyclosporine may be tried to avoid surgery.
  • Early surgical consultation is recommended to prepare for intervention if medical therapy fails.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents with complaints of a sudden, profuse, and offensive vaginal discharge. On examination, her vulva is inflamed and her vaginal walls are red and inflamed with small, punctate, hemorrhagic spots as shown in the image. Which of the following statements is true in this scenario?

choices.text: Male sexual partners to be treated at the same time

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Male sexual partners to be treated at the same time

Explanation:

The presence of motile, pear-shaped flagellated trichomonas on wet mount microscopy is a characteristic feature of Trichomonas vaginalis. Trichomoniasis is a sexually transmitted infection, so the patient's sexual partner should also be treated.
 

Feature

Trichomonas vaginalis vaginitis

Candida albicans vaginitis (Moniliasis)

Bacterial Vaginosis (BV)

pH

≥ 4.5 

< 4.5

≥ 4.5

Other Symptoms

Itching and irritation in and around vaginal opening, dysuria

Intense vulvovaginal pruritus (out of proportion to the discharge), dyspareunia, splash dysuria

Generally not accompanied by itching or inflammation but may be associated with complications such as PID and pregnancy complications

Diagnosis

Motile trichomonads on wet mount microscopy

Identification of mycelia, pseudohyphae, and spores by direct smear and staining (methylene blue)

Amsel's four diagnostic criteria (three of four are sufficient): (1) Homogenous vaginal discharge, (2) Vaginal pH > 4.5, (3) Positive whiff test, (4) Clue cells

Microscopy

Motile, pear-shaped, flagellated organisms

Hyphae and buds, spores

Clue cells (>20% of cells)

questions.text: A 28-year-old man with a history of asthma is undergoing elective surgery. He is induced with isoflurane and given succinylcholine for muscle relaxation. Within minutes, the surgical team observes that he has developed severe muscle rigidity, a rapid heart rate, and a notable increase in body temperature. Which drug/s is/are most likely responsible for the onset of these symptoms in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Both isoflurane and succinylcholine

 

Explanation:

  • In this case, the diagnosis of malignant hyperthermia is typically made based on the presence of characteristic clinical signs—such as muscle rigidity, tachycardia, and hyperthermia—following exposure to certain anaesthetic agents.
  • Both isoflurane (an inhaled anaesthetic) and succinylcholine (a depolarizing muscle relaxant) are well-known triggers for malignant hyperthermia.
  • The combination of these agents heightens the risk of developing this serious condition, which is indicated by the rapid onset of symptoms in the patient after their administration.

 

Triggers of Malignant Hyperthermia:

  • Inhaled general anesthetics
    • Ether
    • Halothane
    • Enflurane
    • Isoflurane
    • Desflurane
    • Sevoflurane
  • Depolarizing muscle relaxant
    • Succinylcholine
  • Prior exercise, even just an hour before anaesthesia induction, intensifies the severity and accelerates the onset of rigidity.

 

Initial Indicators of Malignant Hyperthermia (MH) During Anesthesia:

  • Muscle rigidity
  • Masseter spasm
  • Tachycardia
  • Unexplained hypercarbia
  • Increased temperature

 

Other Features:

  • Cyanosis, metabolic acidosis, hypertension, fever, sweating,
  • Hyperkalemia, Hyperphosphatemia, Myoglobinemia, Myoglobinuria, Cardiac Arrest, DIC, etc.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department with signs of infection. The physician discusses the components of his immune system that are involved in the initial defence against pathogens. Which of the following is NOT a component of innate immunity, as explained by the physician?
questions.solution:
Correct option- D) Classical complement pathway

Classical complement pathways are part of acquired immunity, while the alternative and mannose-binding pathways are part of innate immunity.

Components of Innate Immunity

  • Anatomical and Physiological Barriers: Skin, mucosal surfaces, body temperature, pH, and secretions act as first-line defenses against microbes.
  • Phagocytes: Neutrophils, macrophages, and monocytes engulf and destroy microbes in three steps—engulfment, lysosome fusion, and microbial killing. (Option B ruled out)
  • Natural Killer (NK) Cells: These lymphocytes target and kill virus-infected and tumor cells. (Option C ruled out)
  • Other Lymphocyte Classes: Includes γδ T cells, NK-T cells, B-1 cells, and marginal-zone B cells, which bridge innate and adaptive immunity.
  • Mast Cells: Found in mucosal linings; release histamine and cytokines upon activation to trigger inflammation.
  • Dendritic Cells: Initiate inflammation and transport antigens to lymph nodes to activate T cells, linking innate and adaptive immunity.
  • Complement Pathways: Alternative and mannose-binding pathways mediate microbial lysis, inflammation, and stimulate acquired immunity. (Option A ruled out)
  • Inflammatory Response: Involves vasodilation, plasma leakage, phagocyte recruitment, and destruction of microbes at infection sites.
  • Normal Resident Flora: Competes with pathogens for resources and produces antibacterial substances.
  • Cytokines: Includes TNF-α, interleukins, interferons, and TGF-β, which mediate immune responses to infections.
  • Acute Phase Reactant Proteins (APRs): Proteins like C-reactive protein, complement proteins, and fibrinogen increase during inflammation to support immune defense.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with clear, watery nasal discharge that increases when she bends forward. She denies any history of allergies and reports having undergone nasal surgery a few weeks ago. Which biochemical test is the most appropriate to confirm the diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Beta-2 transferrin test

Explanation:

In this case, the patient’s symptoms of clear, watery nasal discharge that worsens when bending forward after nasal surgery are classic indicators of CSF rhinorrhea. The Beta-2 transferrin test is highly specific and sensitive for detecting CSF in nasal discharge, making it the best confirmatory test for this patient’s symptoms.

CSF Rhinorrhea - Biochemical Tests

Glucose estimation test

Beta-2 Transferrin test

Beta trace protein test
  • Rapid but unreliable test using glucose oxidase paper.
  • Not specific for the site or side of the leak.
  • A protein unique to CSF, not found in nasal discharge.
  • Its presence is a specific and sensitive test for CSF rhinorrhea.
  • Requires only a few drops of CSF for testing.
  • Found in CSF, perilymph, and aqueous humor.
  • The best test for confirming CSF in nasal fluid, but doesn’t localize the leak.
  • Another protein-specific test to detect CSF.
  • Secreted by the meninges and choroid plexus.
  • Also known as prostaglandin D synthase.
  • High sensitivity and specificity.
  • Present in other tissues (testes, heart) and altered in conditions like renal failure and CNS diseases.
  • But, facilities to test these are not easily available. (Option D)

Glucose oxidase paper test(Option A): This test is unreliable for detecting CSF rhinorrhea due to potential false positives from other substances and false negatives if glucose levels in CSF are low or if there is active meningitis.

Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) test(Option C): LDH is a non-specific enzyme that is not suitable for diagnosing CSF rhinorrhea as it does not differentiate between CSF and other fluids in the nasal cavity.

questions.text: A 37-year-old male presents with sudden onset fever and a rapidly enlarging tender lymph node in the left axilla. Considering the clinical history of plague, which of the following is false regarding the vector responsible for transmission of this infection?

choices.text: Pathogens undergo multiplication within the vector
Pathogen undergoes development within the vector.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) None of the above 

Explanation:

A rat flea infected with Yersinia pestis is a biological vector for plague, within which the Yersinia bacilli undergo multiplication (Propagative transmission).

 

Mechanical vector

Biological vector

  • Infectious agent is mechanically transported on the feet or proboscis of the agent
  • It can also get passively excreted unchanged from the agent GIT 

Infectious agents are taken up by the vector, where they can undergo a necessary development cycle (Option B)

An agent does not undergo multiplication or development within the vector.

E.g., the spread of bacillary dysentery by houseflies.

Agent undergoes

  • Multiplication (propagative) - plague bacilli in fleas (Option A)
  • Development (cyclo-developmental) - microfilariae in culex mosquito.
  • Both (cyclo-propagative) - malaria parasites in Anopheles.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman with a history of schizophrenia has been on antipsychotic treatment for three years. After being prescribed a new medication, she developed unusual muscle contractions in her neck and jaw within a week, resulting in difficulty controlling her head movements, which often twist to one side. Which pathway is primarily responsible for these symptoms?
questions.solution:
• The symptoms described in this case are indicative of Acute dystonia, a type of extrapyramidal side effect often seen with antipsychotic medications.
  • This condition occurs when there is a disruption in the nigrostriatal pathway, which is primarily responsible for motor control.

 

Acute Dystonia:

  • It refers to brief, sudden muscle contractions that lead to abnormal movements or postures.
  • Clinical manifestations:
    • Oculogyric crises (upward rolling of eyes)
    • Tongue protrusion
    • Trismus (jaw muscles)
    • Torticollis (neck muscles twisting to one side)
    • Laryngospasm
    • Dysarthria, Dysphasia (glossopharyngeal symptoms)
    • Dystonic postures of the limbs and trunk.
  • Management:
    • It can be effectively managed using anticholinergics.
    • Parenteral (IV or IM) is for immediate treatment, while oral anticholinergics are used for prophylaxis to prevent future episodes.
    • Drugs include Benztropine, Diphenhydramine, and Promethazine.

Neural pathways:

Pathway

Extent

Manifestations

Nigrostriatal pathway

(Option C)

A decrease in dopamine leads to abnormal movement symptoms like tremors, rigidity, dystonias, etc.

Mesolimbic pathway

(Option A)

An increase in dopamine levels leads to positive symptoms such as:

  • Delusion
  • Hallucination

Mesocortical pathway

(Option B)

A decrease in dopamine levels leads to negative symptoms such as:

  • Anhedonia (loss of interest)
  • Avolition (loss of will)
  • Affective blunting (inability to express emotions).
  • Asociality (decrease in drive to socialise).
  • Alogia (decrease in verbal communication).
  • Attention deficits
  • Apathy (lack of concern).

Tuberoinfundibular pathway

(Option D)

A decrease in dopamine levels leads to hyperprolactinemia, which manifests as:

  • Decreased libido (sex drive)
  • Decreased sexual dysfunction
  • Galactorrhea and amenorrhea (females)

questions.text: A 75-year-old male with a history of gout presents to the clinic with increased frequency of gout attacks. His daily medications include rosuvastatin, low-dose aspirin and losartan for hypertension. He has been advised to avoid certain medications that can exacerbate his gout. Which of the following drugs should be avoided in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Aspirin

Explanation:

Aspirin affects renal handling of uric acid in two ways:

  • High doses (>3 g/day): Uricosuric effect (blocking urate reabsorption).
  • Low doses (<2 g/day): Uric acid retention (inhibiting urate secretion).

Gout triggers can include alcohol, red meat, and certain medications. 

Drugs causing gout

Drugs beneficial in gout

Mnemonic – PAINED

  • P: Pyrazinamide
  • A: Aspirin (Normal dose <2 gms)
  • I: Immunosuppressive: Cyclosporine
  • N: Niacin
  • E: Ethambutol
  • D: Diuretic like loop diuretics, thiazides

Mnemonic – FALSe

  • F: Fenofibrate
  • A: Aspirin in toxic dose >5 gm
  • L: Losartan (OPTION B)
  • Se: Statins (Pravastatin, rosuvastatin) (OPTION D)

questions.text: During the active management of the third stage of labor, which intervention is recommended to prevent postpartum hemorrhage primarily due to uterine atony?

choices.text: Immediate IV administration of 20 units of undiluted oxytocin
Vigorous fundal massage combined with a uterotonic agent
Controlled cord traction with immediate removal of the placenta

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Vigorous fundal massage combined with a uterotonic agent

 

Explanation:

Vigorous fundal massage helps to maintain uterine tone and prevent uterine atony, a common cause of postpartum hemorrhage. Combining it with a uterotonic agent like oxytocin further enhances uterine contraction, reducing the risk of excessive bleeding.

 

 

Active Management of the Third Stage of Labor (AMTSL) for PPH:

  • Uterine Massage:
    • Always palpate the uterine fundus after placental delivery.
    • Vigorous fundal massage, combined with a uterotonic agent, is recommended to prevent PPH due to uterine atony.
    • During immediate PPH, perform uterine massage while evaluating for other bleeding sources and administering uterotonic agents.
  • Oxytocin:
    • Recommended by WHO as a first-line prophylactic treatment for postpartum hemorrhage.
    • Administer 20 units of oxytocin in 1,000 mL of crystalloid solution intravenously at 10 mL/min for a dose of 200 mU/min. (Option A)
    • Never administer oxytocin as an undiluted bolus due to risks of severe hypotension or cardiac arrhythmias. 
    • Intravenous oxytocin is also a first-line treatment for uterine atony.
    • Oxytocin 10 units can be given IM with the delivery of the anterior shoulder (Option B)
  • Delayed Cord Clamping/Controlled Cord Traction (CCT):
    • If placental separation is evident, perform expression via fundal pressure or controlled cord traction.
    • If the placenta is not separated, perform manual removal under general anesthesia.
    • Delivery of the placenta by cord traction before placental separation especially in an atonic uterus may cause uterine inversion. (Option D)

questions.text: In a 65 y/o male with COPD showing signs of a bacterial respiratory infection, the sputum sample undergoes culture and sensitivity testing using the Epsilometer (E-test). Following incubation, an elliptical zone of inhibition is observed around the antibiotic strip. What is the primary advantage of using the E-test in this clinical context?

choices.text: It identifies the specific bacterium causing the infection.
It determines the bacterium's resistance to all known antibiotics.
It provides a visual and precise measurement of the minimum inhibitory concentration of the antibiotic.
It allows for the immediate administration of antibiotics without further testing.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) It provides a visual and precise measurement of the minimum inhibitory concentration of the antibiotic.

Explanation:

The primary advantage of the E-test is that it provides a clear, visual indication of the MIC, which is the lowest concentration of an antibiotic that inhibits the growth of the bacterium. This helps clinicians choose the most effective antibiotic and dosage for treatment.

Image showing E-test

 

Step

Description

Setup

An absorbent strip with a gradient of antibiotic concentrations is placed on a culture plate inoculated with the bacterium.

Process

The strip releases the antibiotic, creating a gradient in the medium. An elliptical zone of inhibition forms around the strip after incubation.

Determination

The MIC is identified at the point where the edge of the ellipse intersects with the strip, representing the lowest concentration of the antibiotic that inhibits bacterial growth (MIC). (Option C)

Advantages

Allows for the simultaneous testing of multiple antibiotics on a single plate and provides a visual, precise measurement of the MIC, enhancing accuracy compared to traditional disk diffusion methods.

 

It identifies the specific bacterium causing the infection (Option A): The E-test assesses bacterial susceptibility to antibiotics but does not identify the specific bacterium. Additional tests like culture characteristics, biochemical tests, or molecular methods are needed for bacterial identification.

It determines the bacterium's resistance to all known antibiotics (Option B): The E-test measures the MIC for specific antibiotics tested, not for all known antibiotics. Multiple E-tests with different antibiotics can be performed to get a broader resistance profile, but each test is specific to one antibiotic.

It allows for the immediate administration of antibiotics without further testing (Option D): While the E-test provides valuable information, it still requires incubation and interpretation time. Immediate administration of antibiotics is typically guided by clinical judgment and empirical therapy, not solely by the results of the E-test.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with a history of recurrent episodes of jaundice, fatigue, and abdominal pain. Physical examination reveals splenomegaly. The child's blood work shows the presence of spherocytes on the peripheral blood smear. An osmotic fragility test is performed. Identify the correct statement about this test.

choices.text: In thalassemia patients, low osmotic fragility leads to a right shift on the graph.
In HS patients, high osmotic fragility leads to a right shift on the graph.
Normally, RBC lysis begins at 0.7% NaCl.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) In HS patients, high osmotic fragility leads to a right shift on the graph.


 

Explanation:

The correct statement regarding the osmotic fragility test is high osmotic fragility leads to a right shift on the graph in patients with HS.

 

Osmotic Fragility Test:

  • Assesses RBC susceptibility to hemolysis in hypotonic saline.
  • Used for screening HS and thalassemia.
  • RBCs are incubated in hypotonic saline of varying osmolarities.
  • Measures hemolysis as saline enters RBCs, causing swelling and lysis.

Normal RBC Response:

  • It begins to lyse around 0.5% NaCl concentration. (Option D)
  • Maintain shape due to balance between membrane integrity and osmotic pressure.

Hereditary Spherocytosis (HS):

  • RBCs are more fragile due to reduced surface-to-volume ratio.
  • The osmotic fragility curve shifts to the right.
  • More susceptible to hemolysis at higher saline concentrations.

Thalassemia:

  • Characterized by smaller and more rigid RBCs.
  • The osmotic fragility curve shifts to the left. (Option B)
  • Lyses at lower saline concentrations compared to normal RBCs.

  • However, this test is just a screening method, and the Eosin-5-maleimide (EMA) binding test is the gold standard for diagnosing hereditary spherocytosis. (Option A)

questions.text: The diagram given below depicts a mechanism of separation of the placenta. What is this mechanism called?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Schultz

Explanation:

 

 

                                                                                    

Feature

Central Separation (Schultze)

Marginal Separation (Mathews-Duncan)

Initiation

Starts at the center of the placenta

It starts at the margin of the placenta

Relation with uterine contractions

Detachment occurs as uterine contractions increase

Detachment occurs as uterine contractions increase

Blood Accumulation

Leads to retroplacental hematoma

-

Mechanism

Weight of the placenta and blood facilitate detachment

Marginal areas are unsupported, leading to separation

Frequency

Less common

More common

questions.text: A 15-year-old male is undergoing puberty and starts experiencing physical and hormonal changes associated with this developmental stage. Which hormonal changes and effects are typical during puberty in males?

choices.text: Elevated FSH enlarges penis and scrotum.

questions.solution:
Answer: B) Increased LH boosts testosterone production.

 

Explanation:

During puberty, increased LH stimulates Leydig cells in the testes to produce more testosterone, leading to the development of secondary sexual characteristics.

Puberty and Male Reproductive System Changes

Increased Testosterone Production
  • Surge in testosterone by Leydig cells in testes. Stimulated by LH from anterior pituitary. (Option B)

Primary Sexual Characteristics
  • Growth of penis, scrotum, and testes. (Option C)

Secondary Sexual Characteristics
  • Body Hair: Increased growth on pubic area, face, chest, etc.
  • Voice Changes: Deeper voice due to larynx hypertrophy.
  • Skin Changes: Thicker skin, increased sebaceous secretion, acne.
  • Muscle Development: Increased muscle mass (50% greater than females). (Option A)
  • Bone Growth: Enhanced thickness, calcium retention.
  • Metabolic Effects: Increased basal metabolic rate (5-10%), potential increase in red blood cells.

Spermatogenesis
  • Sperm production begins and continues throughout life within seminiferous tubules of testes.

Role of Hormones in Spermatogenesis
  • FSH: Stimulates Sertoli cells for sperm support.
  • Testosterone: Essential for germ cell growth.
  • Inhibin: Produced by Sertoli cells to regulate FSH and spermatogenesis rate. (Option D)

Sperm Maturation and Storage
  • Immature sperm mature in the epididymis, gaining motility (suppressed until ejaculation), stored for at least a month.

 

Hypothalamic-Pituitary-Testicular Axis

questions.text: Which of the following laser procedures are used for Open angle glaucoma (OAG) and angle closure glaucoma (ACG) respectively?

choices.text: Argon laser iridotomy for open-angle glaucoma and selective laser trabeculoplasty (SLT) for angle closure glaucoma
Selective laser trabeculoplasty for open-angle glaucoma and laser iridotomy for angle closure glaucoma
Laser iridoplasty for open-angle glaucoma and argon laser iridotomy for angle closure glaucoma
Laser iridotomy for open-angle glaucoma and laser iridoplasty for angle closure glaucoma

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Selective laser trabeculoplasty for open-angle glaucoma and laser iridotomy for angle closure glaucoma

 

Explanation:

Selective Laser Trabeculoplasty (SLT)

  • It is commonly used for open-angle glaucoma.
  • SLT improves aqueous humor outflow by targeting the trabecular meshwork, which helps lower intraocular pressure over time.

Laser Iridotomy

  • It is used for angle closure glaucoma.
  • This procedure creates a small hole in the peripheral iris to allow better fluid drainage and relieve the blockage of the anterior chamber angle.

Argon laser iridotomy (Option A) is used for angle closure glaucoma, not open-angle glaucoma.

  • Also, SLT is not typically used for angle closure glaucoma.

Laser iridoplasty (Option C) is used for some cases of angle closure glaucoma, particularly when the angle is very narrow or if iridotomy is not feasible.

  • However, argon laser iridotomy is the more common procedure for angle closure glaucoma. 

Laser iridotomy (Option D) is not used for open-angle glaucoma; it is used for angle-closure glaucoma.

  • Similarly, laser iridoplasty is a treatment for angle closure glaucoma, not open-angle glaucoma.

questions.text: A 55-year-old healthcare worker with rheumatoid arthritis is started on immunosuppressive therapy. What is the most appropriate reason to perform a two-step tuberculin skin test (TST) before initiating treatment?

choices.text: To assess the patient's baseline immunity against tuberculosis
To confirm a recent positive TST result
To differentiate between a boosted reaction and a new infection
To monitor the effectiveness of immunosuppressive therapy on latent tuberculosis

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) To differentiate between a boosted reaction and a new infection

Explanation:

Before starting immunosuppressive therapy, a two-step tuberculin skin test  is used to distinguish between a boosted reaction from prior exposure to tuberculosis and a new infection. This approach helps confirm a positive TST result, preventing unnecessary treatment for latent tuberculosis due to misinterpretation.

  • 1st test - read within 48 to 72 hours
    • If positive, consider the patient infected.
    • If negative, 2nd test after 3 weeks.
  • 2nd test - read within 48 to 72 hours - done after 3 weeks.
    • Positive - infected
    • Negative - uninfected

  • To assess the patient's baseline immunity against tuberculosis(Option A): The TST does not assess "immunity" in the protective sense, but rather latent infection. Immunity would relate more to BCG vaccination or T-cell responses.

  •  To confirm a recent positive TST result(Option B): That would be a repeat single TST, not a two-step test.

  • To monitor the effectiveness of immunosuppressive therapy on latent tuberculosis(Option D): TST is not used to monitor treatment effectiveness. Also, immunosuppression can cause false negatives in TST.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient presents with intermittent chest pain and dysphagia. A barium swallow study is performed as part of the diagnostic workup. Which of the following radiographic findings is most characteristic of diffuse esophageal spasm (DES) as shown in the image?

choices.text: Bird-beak appearance of the distal esophagus
Corkscrew or rosary bead appearance of the esophagus
Smooth, tapered narrowing of the mid-esophagus
Saccular outpouchings along the entire length of the esophagus

questions.solution:
Answer: B) Corkscrew or rosary bead appearance of the esophagus

Explanation:

  • The image shows corkscrew or rosary bead appearance of esophagus.
  • This appearance of the esophagus, although seen in less than 5% of cases, is a characteristic finding of diffuse esophageal spasm (DES) on barium swallow studies.

Diffuse esophageal spasm (DES)- Radiographic findings

Imaging Modality

Radiographic Findings

Description

Fluoroscopy (Barium Swallow)
  • "Corkscrew esophagus" or "rosary bead esophagus"
  • Non-peristaltic contractions pushing contrast in two directions
  • Normal appearance possible
  • 60% show abnormalities
  • <5% show "corkscrew esophagus"
  • Non-peristaltic contractions may be the only feature in some cases

CT
  • Circumferential wall thickening of the distal 5 cm of the esophagus
  • Seen in 20% of patients
  • Wall thickening ranges from 5 to 15 mm

 
  • Simultaneous contractions in the distal esophagus
  • Normal peristalsis interrupted by non-propulsive contractions
  • Gold standard for diagnosis
  • Not strictly a radiographic modality, but included for completeness

 

Manometry pressures of various motility disorders:

Esophageal Motility Disorder

LES Resting Pressure

LES Relaxation

Peristalsis

Contraction Amplitude

Normal

10-45 mmHg

Complete relaxation occur i.e ≤8 mmHg)

Coordinated peristalsis throughout

Normal amplitude is <180 mmHg

Achalasia

Elevated (>45 mmHg)

Incomplete relaxation (>8 mmHg)

Absent in the esophageal body

N/A

Diffuse Esophageal Spasm (DES)

Normal (≤45 mmHg)

Normal (≤8 mmHg)

Uncoordinated in >20% of swallows

Often high (>180 mmHg) in distal esophagus

Nutcracker Esophagus (Jackhammer Esophagus)

Normal (≤45 mmHg)

Normal (≤8 mmHg)

Normal

Very high (>220 mmHg)

Bird-beak appearance (Option A) is more characteristic of achalasia.

Smooth, tapered narrowing (Option C) is not typically associated with DES and might suggest a benign stricture.

Saccular outpouching along the entire esophagus (Option D) suggests diffuse esophageal diverticulosis. It is not a characteristic finding of DES, although some sacculations may be present.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents with swelling in her right calf and foot, which has gradually worsened over the past few years. She reports that the swelling started in her teenage years and has become more pronounced with time. What is the diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Lymphedema praecox

Explanation:

  • The above clinical scenario is a case of Lymphedema praecox, a type of primary lymphedema.

Types of primary lymphedema:

Lymphedema Praecox (Option B)
  • M/C type of primary lymphedema (>90% of cases).
  • Age: 1 to 35 years.
  • M/C seen in females.
  • Usually U/L.
  • Involves calf and foot
  • Familial version of lymphedema praecox - known as Meig's disease.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with a persistent dry cough and shortness of breath. A CT scan of the chest reveals localized airway obstruction at the level of the terminal bronchioles. Based on Weibel's classification of the respiratory system, which generation of airways is most likely affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Generation 16


Explanation:
Weibel's classification of the respiratory system organizes the airways into 23 generations, starting from the trachea (Generation 0) down to the alveolar sacs (Generation 23).

  • The terminal bronchioles are found at generation/division 16, marking the end of the conducting zone and the beginning of the respiratory zone.
    • This level is critical as it is the last portion of the airways involved in conducting air before gas exchange begins in the respiratory bronchioles.
  • Division number 0 to division number 16 is known as the conducting zone of the airway .
    • Division number 1 to 10 are known as Bronchi. (Option A & B ruled out)
    • Division numbers 11 to 16 are known as terminal bronchioles. (Option C)
  • Division number 17 to division number 23 are responsible for gas exchange and are known as the exchange zone of alveoli. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: A child presented with a sore throat, fever, and swollen lymph nodes in the neck. Throat culture was subjected to Albert's stain and revealed bacilli arranged in a Chinese letter pattern. The patient's condition deteriorates rapidly, with signs of severe respiratory distress. Which of the following mechanisms is primarily responsible for the clinical manifestations seen in this patient?

choices.text: Cleavage of nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide by Diphtheria Toxin (DT).
Inactivation of elongation factor 2 (EF-2) by Exotoxin A.
Binding of fragment B to human cell receptors by Diphtheria Toxin (DT).
Secretion of toxins by Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Binding of fragment B to human cell receptors by Diphtheria Toxin (DT).

Explanation:

The child's symptoms of sore throat , fever and swollen lymph nodes along with Albert’s stain revealing bacilli arranged in Chinese letter pattern points to a diagnosis of Diptheria caused by C.diptheriae

  • In diphtheria caused by C. diphtheriae, Diphtheria Toxin (DT) is primarily responsible for the severe clinical manifestations.
  • Fragment B of DT binds to specific receptors on human cells (Option C) → facilitating the entry of fragment A into the cytoplasm (Option B ruled out)→ fragment A ADPribosylates elongation factor 2 (EF-2), halting protein synthesis → leading to cell death.
  • This mechanism contributes significantly to the respiratory distress and other severe symptoms observed in diphtheria patients.

Cleavage of nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide by Diphtheria Toxin (DT) (Option A): The primary toxic action involves the ADP-ribosylation of elongation factor 2 (EF-2), which results from the toxin's enzymatic activity using NAD as a substrate.

Secretion of toxins by Pseudomonas aeruginosa (Option D): It refers to a different bacterium and a different set of toxins. Pseudomonas aeruginosa is not the causative agent of diphtheria, and its toxins are not involved in the pathogenesis of this disease.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents with malodorous vaginal discharge for the past week. There is no itching. On examination, there is white discharge coating the vaginal walls. Based on the clinical and microscopic findings (below), what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Bacterial Vaginosis

Explanation:

Bacterial Vaginosis is characterised by a thin, greyish-white discharge with the presence of clue cells (vaginal epithelial cells coated with bacteria).

Bacterial Vaginosis:

  • The most common cause of vaginal discharge in reproductive-age women. 
  • Caused by: Hemophilus (Gardnerella) vaginalis. Less common: Prevotella, Mobiluncus, and Bacteroides

The image below shows Normal vaginal flora and clue cells in bacterial vaginosis.

Candidiasis (Option A) typically presents with thick, white, cottage cheese-like discharge and itching.

Trichomoniasis (Option B) presents with frothy, greenish-yellow discharge and often causes itching.

Chlamydia (Option D) is often asymptomatic but can cause mucopurulent discharge and other symptoms.

questions.text: A patient came with complaints of discoloration of his left leg as shown in the image. He has a history of deep vein thrombosis and has been inconsistent on medication. What is the possible diagnosis here?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Post-thrombotic leg


 

Explanation:

The scenario here points to a post-thrombotic leg due to the history of previous DVT and non-compliance to oral anticoagulants

 

Post-thrombotic syndrome:

Post-thrombotic syndrome (PTS), also called postphlebitic syndrome and venous stress disorder is a medical condition that may occur as a long-term complication of deep vein thrombosis (DVT).

  • Chronic venous insufficiency patients may have superficial vein incompetence with or without perforator incompetence or having previous DVT with complete obliteration or partial recanalisation with incompetence.
  • Develop in 20% to 50% of patients after DVT.
  • Symptoms:
    • Leg pain
    • Sensation of leg heaviness, pulling or fatigue
    • Limb swelling
  • Signs:
    • Leg edema
    • Redness
    • Dusky cyanosis
    • Perimalleolar or more extensive telangiectasia
    • New varicose vein
    • Stasis hyperpigmentation
    • Lipodermatosclerosis
    • Leg ulcer

 

Venous gangrene (Option A): Presents with blackish discoloration, blebs and edema.

 

Venous ulcer (Option B): Long saphenous vein perforator incompetence is often associated with venous ulcers, typically on the medial aspect of the ankle, and is often seen in long-standing varicose veins.

Atrophic blanche (Option C): It is localized white atrophic skin surrounded by hyperpigmentation and dilated capillaries associated with varicose veins.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman with a travel history to South America presents to the clinic with complaints of fatigue, mild chest pain, and palpitations. She reports a history of fever, malaise, and swelling around her right eye 11 months ago, which resolved spontaneously. On examination, her heart rate is irregular, and she has mild cardiomegaly on chest X-ray. Which treatment options are most appropriate for her at this stage?
questions.solution:
This patient's presentation is consistent with chronic Chagas disease, caused by the protozoan parasite Trypanosoma cruzi. The history of fever and eyelid swelling points to a possible acute phase of the infection, while her current symptoms of fatigue, chest pain, palpitations, and cardiomegaly are typical complications of chronic Chagas disease.

Benznidazole is one of the two mainstays of treatment for Chagas disease. It is effective in both the acute and chronic phases, particularly when cardiac symptoms are present. Early treatment can help reduce the risk of progression to severe cardiac disease and complications. The recommended treatment duration is typically 60 days.

Nifurtimox (Option B) is another option for treating Chagas disease, but it is often associated with more significant side effects, including gastrointestinal issues and neurotoxicity. It is reserved for cases where benznidazole is contraindicated or not tolerated.

Supportive care and monitoring (Option C): While essential for managing symptoms and potential complications of Chagas disease (such as arrhythmias), this approach does not address the underlying infection.

Antiarrhythmic medications only (Option D) can help manage the arrhythmias associated with Chagas-related cardiomyopathy, E.g., beta-blockers and digoxin.

Supportive treatment such as pacemakers to manage arrhythmias and surgery for correction of megaesophagus and megacolon may be useful.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is having difficulty in near vision. The ophthalmologist has prescribed him a convex lens and informed him that it is an age-related physiological condition. Which of the following is an age-related change that would have caused his condition?

choices.text: Decrease in elasticity of lens capsule

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) All of the above

 

Explanation:

The scenario is that of presbyopia

 

Accommodation

The mechanism by which the eyes focus diverging rays from a near object on the retina

Mechanism

When looking at a near object from a far object:

Ciliary muscles contract →Zonules relax→Lens becomes more convex anteriorly

Presbyopia

Physiological insufficiency of accommodation, causing worsening near vision after the age of 40

Causes
  • Decrease in elasticity of lens capsule (Option A)
  • Sclerosis of lens substance (Option B)
  • Reduced ciliary muscle power (Option C)

Treatment

  • Convex glasses for near-work
  • A guide for powers required at various ages:
    • 45 years: + l to +l.25D
    • 50 years: +1.5 to +1.75D
    • 55 years: +2 to +2.25D
    • 60 years: +2.5 to +30D

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman comes to the emergency department due to a throbbing headache. On vital examination, BP is 210/140 mm Hg. She is started on a Nitroprusside IV drip. After 8 hours, develop lactic acidosis and neurological symptoms. She is diagnosed with nitroprusside-induced cyanide toxicity. Which of the following drug combinations is used to treat this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Sodium nitrite + sodium thiosulfate + hydroxocobalamin

 

Explanation:

Sodium nitrite + sodium thiosulfate + hydroxocobalamin is the combination of choice for the management of cyanide toxicity.

  • Haemoglobin combines with sodium nitrite to form methemoglobin, which has a higher affinity for cyanide than haemoglobin.
  • This results in the formation of cyanmethemoglobin. But this can easily dissociate into cyanide again, thus, sodium thiosulfate is given, which will result in the formation of sodium thiocyanate which is more stable and is excreted into the urine.
  • Hydroxocobalamine also has a very high affinity for cyanide leading to formation of cyanocobalamin, which gets excreted into the urine.

Option A: Pralidoxime + atropine

  • This combination of drugs serves as an antidote for organophosphate poisoning.
  • Atropine is used for atropinization of all the nicotinic and muscarinic receptors thus preventing their further stimulation, while pralidoxime is used to reverse the inhibited acetylcholinesterase and reactivate the enzyme .

Option C: Activated charcoal + N-acetyl cysteine

  • This combination of drugs is used to treat acetaminophen/paracetamol poisoning.
  • Activated charcoal binds to the unabsorbed paracetamol present in the gut which can be flushed out using a lavage, while N-acetyl cysteine serves to replenish the glutathione stores which binds to the toxic metabolite of paracetamol N-acetyl-p-benzoquinoneimine.

Option D: Sodium nitrite only

  • If only sodium nitrite is used, the cyanmethemoglobin formed will dissociate back into cyanide and methemoglobin before being excreted out of the body.

Correct Answer: A) Felty's syndrome

 

Explanation:

  • The unknown joint and bone condition the patient is suffering from is most likely Rheumatoid arthritis based on the presence of characteristic hand deformities (swan neck and boutonniere deformities).
  • Felty's syndrome is a severe extra-articular manifestation of long-standing rheumatoid arthritis (RA), characterized by the triad of RA, splenomegaly, and neutropenia.
  • This syndrome predisposes patients to infections due to neutropenia.

 

Clinical features of Rheumatoid arthritis:

  • Symmetrical polyarthritis, polysynovitis with soft-tissue swelling- Pain and morning stiffness in multiple joints usually lasting more than 30 minutes.
  • Generalized myopathy or neuropathy, tiredness, and loss of weight.
  • As the disease progresses, joint deformity, joint instability, and tendon rupture.

 

Joints affected

Common
  • MP joints of the hand
  • PIP joints of fingers
  • Wrists, knees, elbows, ankles

Less common
  • Hip joint
  • Temporo-mandibular joint
  • Spares sacroiliac joint and distal inter phalangeal joints.


 

Deformities in Rheumatoid arthritis

Hand
  • Ulnar deviation of the hand
  • Swan neck deformity
  • Boutonniere deformity

Elbow

  • Flexion deformity

 

Knee
  • Valgus deformity

Ankle

  • Equinus deformity

Foot
  • Hallux valgus

 
  • Hammer toe

 

Extra-articular manifestations of Rheumatoid arthritis:

  • Vasculitis
  • Rheumatoid nodules- Subcutaneous, over bony prominences, in the synovium, on tendons, in the sclera, and the viscera. Size is increased by methotrexate.
  • Serositis
  • Felty's syndrome: Severe splenomegaly + neutropenia + RA. (Option A)


 

Psoriatic arthropathy (Option B):

  • It is a chronic inflammatory arthritis associated with psoriasis.
  • It can cause joint pain, swelling, and deformities, but it is typically associated with nail changes like pitting, and dactylitis causing sausage-shaped fingers. 

 

Kashin-Beck disease (Option C):

  • It is a rare polyarticular form of osteoarthritis commonly seen in regions of China.
  • It primarily affects growing children and causes joint deformities, leading to dwarfism.
  • It is not associated with neutropenia, splenomegaly, and typical hand deformities as seen in this patient. 

 

Pseudogout (Option D):

  • It is caused by the deposition of calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate crystals in the joints, leading to sudden and painful joint inflammation.
  • It does not cause swan neck and boutonniere deformities, neutropenia, and splenomegaly.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old diabetic patient underwent coronary angiography for suspected triple vessel disease. After the procedure he develops oliguria and rising serum creatinine. Labs are


	Baseline serum creatinine: 1.5 mg/dL
	Current serum creatinine: 3.0 mg/dL
	Urine output: 0.35 mL/kg/hr for 18 hours


According to KDIGO criteria, what is the stage of acute kidney injury in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Stage 2:

  • KDIGO AKI staging

Stage

Serum Creatinine

Urine Output

1

1.5 -1.9 x baseline or ≥ 0.3 mg/dL increase

<0.5 mL/kg/hr for 6-12 hr

2

2.0 - 2.9 x baseline

<0.5 mL/kg /hr for ≥ 12 hr

3

≥ 3 x baseline or ≥4 mg/dL increase or initiation of RRT

<0.3 mL/kg/hr for ≥24 hr or anuria ≥12 hr

questions.text: Which of the following international declarations or charters is primarily associated with outlining the principles and strategies for health promotion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Ottawa Charter

Explanation:

The Ottawa Charter is the foundational document for health promotion, outlining key strategies and principles such as building healthy public policy, creating supportive environments, strengthening community action, developing personal skills, and reorienting health services.

The Declaration of Alma-Ata (Option A), adopted in 1978, aimed to achieve Health for All by 2000 through Primary Health Care (PHC). Key points include:

  • PHC is essential, accessible, and community-based health care.
  • Recognition of health as a human right with a focus on equity.
  • Emphasis on community participation and inter-sectoral collaboration.
  • Call for global support and cooperation to strengthen health systems, especially in developing countries.

The Jakarta Declaration on Health Promotion (Option B) (1997) set a vision for health promotion in the 21st century, emphasizing that the determinants of health include peace, shelter, education, social security, social relations, food, income, women's empowerment, a stable ecosystem, sustainable resource use, social justice, human rights, and equity.

Helsinki Declaration (Option D) is primarily concerned with ethical principles for medical research involving human subjects, not health promotion strategies.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman presents with complaints of severe menstrual pain, heavy bleeding, and passage of tissue-like structures along with menstrual blood. Her symptoms have been worsening over the past few months. What is the likely condition?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Membranous Dysmenorrhea

 

Explanation:

Membranous Dysmenorrhea is a rare type of dysmenorrhea characterised by the shedding of the endometrium as casts during menstruation, accompanied by painful uterine cramps.

 

Spasmodic Dysmenorrhea (Option A) involves menstrual pain, but it typically doesn't include the passage of tissue-like structures.

 

Uterine fibroids (Option B) are benign tumours of the uterus, and they are not associated with the passage of endometrial casts during menstruation.

 

Ovarian Cyst torsion (Option C) can cause sudden pelvic pain and slight vaginal spotting, but dysmenorrhea is unlikely.

questions.text: A patient on long-term lithium therapy visits with complaints of frequent urination and increased thirst. He was diagnosed with nephrogenic diabetes insipidus based on urine analysis and plasma ADH levels. He was prescribed a combination of amiloride and hydrochlorothiazide. What is the reason for the use of thiazide diuretics in nephrogenic DI?

choices.text: Thiazides reduce urine output by increasing free water absorption in proximal tubules
Thiazides directly increase the sensitivity of the kidneys to ADH.
Thiazides help to increase lithium excretion, reducing its nephrotoxic effects.
Thiazides decrease the risk of hypokalemia when used with amiloride.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Thiazides reduce urine output by increasing free water absorption in proximal tubules

 

Explanation:

  • Thiazide diuretics reduce polyuria in nephrogenic diabetes insipidus by inducing mild hypovolemia.

Mechanism of Action in Nephrogenic DI:

Drug

Mechanism

Thiazide diuretics

Induce mild volume depletion → ↑ proximal tubular reabsorption of water and sodium → ↓ urine output

Amiloride

Blocks ENaC channels in collecting ducts → ↓ lithium uptake → renal protection

Lithium

Causes nephrogenic DI by damaging ADH-sensitive pathways in collecting ducts

 

Thiazides directly increase the sensitivity of the kidneys to ADH (Option B):
Incorrect because nephrogenic DI is due to ADH resistance, and thiazides do not improve ADH sensitivity.
 

Thiazides help to increase lithium excretion, reducing its nephrotoxic effects (Option C):
Incorrect; thiazides actually increase lithium levels by reducing its clearance, potentially worsening toxicity.
 

Thiazides decrease the risk of hypokalemia when used with amiloride (Option D):
Incorrect because while amiloride reduces potassium loss, this is not the main reason for thiazide use in DI.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with progressive hearing loss in his left ear over the past few years. Audiometry shows hearing loss predominantly in lower frequencies, and otoscopic examination reveals a normal tympanic membrane. The patient denies experiencing tinnitus or vertigo. The patient’s hearing loss is mild and not significantly affecting his daily life. What is the most appropriate initial management strategy for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Observation and monitoring

 

Explanation:

This presentation is consistent with Stapedial otosclerosis.

In mild cases of stapedial otosclerosis where hearing loss is not significantly impacting daily life, observation with regular hearing tests is the preferred initial approach.

 

Medical Management of Otosclerosis

Management is individualized based on whether the otosclerosis is stapedial (middle ear) or cochlear (inner ear), focusing on hearing loss and quality of life.

 

For Stapedial Otosclerosis

  • Observation & Monitoring: (Option C)
    • Recommended for mild cases or when hearing loss is not severe.
    • Regular audiograms track hearing loss progression.
  • Hearing Aids:
    • Effective for conductive hearing loss due to the fixed stapes.
    • Non-invasive option to improve sound transmission.

 

For Cochlear Otosclerosis

  • Hearing Aids:
    • May help but are less effective for severe sensorineural hearing loss.
  • Symptom Management:
    • Tinnitus: Managed with sound or tinnitus retraining therapy.
    • Vertigo: May improve with hearing treatment; other therapies could be needed.

 

Medications for otosclerosis:

Treatment

Mechanism

Duration

Benefits

Sodium Fluoride (NaF) (Option D)

Stabilizes hearing thresholds and vestibular symptoms. Combined with calcium carbonate and vitamin D for enhanced effect.

At least 6 months

Delays worsening tinnitus

Reduces conductive and sensorineural hearing loss

Bisphosphonates (Option B)

Stabilizes hearing loss, reduces dizziness and tinnitus.

At least 6 months

Stabilizes hearing loss

Relieves vestibular symptoms

 

Immediate stapedectomy surgery (Option A): Surgery is considered in more advanced or symptomatic cases. In case of bilateral otosclerosis the worse ear is operated first and a wait time of 6 months is warranted before next surgery. C/I: Positive Schwartz sign, Pregnancy, active infection, only hearing ear, flying, diving and working at height.

questions.text: A 65 y/o male is undergoing chemotherapy for the treatment of non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. During his treatment, he developed pancytopenia, characterized by anemia, leukopenia, and thrombocytopenia. The oncologist reviews the patient's medication list to determine which drug might be responsible for the patient’s lab results. All of the following drugs could be responsible for the patient’s condition except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Vincristine

Explanation:

The patient’s pancytopenia is probably due to bone marrow suppression caused by his anti-cancer drugs.

  • Vincristine, a vinca alkaloid, specifically targets cells during the M phase (mitosis).
  • It binds to tubulin and inhibits microtubule formation.
  • This disruption primarily affects cells with high mitotic activity but has a preferential effect on neural tissues due to their microtubule-dependent processes and has very little effect on bone marrow cells.

Other anticancer drugs which do not cause bone marrow suppression include:

  • Asparaginase
  • Bleomycin
  • Chlorambucil

Cyclophosphamide (Option A) is an alkylating agent very well known to cause bone marrow suppression.

MOA of Alkylating agents causing cell death:

 

Methotrexate (Option B) is a folate analog that inhibits dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR) needed for DNA synthesis and repair, causing bone marrow suppression.

Doxorubicin (Option C) causes bone marrow suppression by DNA Intercalation, Topoisomerase II Inhibition, and free radical formation causing DNA damage.

 MOA:

questions.text: Which of the following statements are false?

choices.text: Ribosome is an example of ribozyme
Both ribozymes and protein enzymes exhibit specificity
Ribozymes exhibit greater structural complexity compared to protein enzymes
rRNA is directly involved in catalyzing the formation of peptide bonds

questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option C- Ribozymes exhibit greater structural complexity compared to protein enzymes

Ribozymes are RNA molecules that can act as catalysts, accelerating biochemical reactions.

A well-known example of a ribozyme is the ribosome, a complex found in all living cells responsible for protein synthesis. (Option A ruled out)

rRNA is directly involved in catalysing the formation of peptide bonds which makes it a ribozyme (Option D ruled out)

Ribozyme

Protein enzymes

Key similarities

Both act as catalysts

Both exhibit specificity, meaning they act on specific molecules (substrates) and catalyse specific reactions. (Option B ruled out)

Both types of enzymes work by lowering the activation energy of reactions

Key differences

Made up of RNA molecules

Made up of amino acids

Lesser structural complexity

Greater structural complexity

Less diverse in terms of the types of reactions

More diverse in terms of the types of reactions

questions.text: 28-year-old man presents to the emergency department after ingesting a large quantity of over-the-counter cough syrup in a suicide attempt. He complains of severe abdominal pain and confusion. ABG shows high anion gap metabolic acidosis. Urinalysis microscopy is shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Fomepizole:

  • The clue in the question is the image “dumbbell-shaped crystals” which are characteristic of calcium oxalate monohydrate.
  • Calcium oxalate crystalluria suggests ethylene glycol poisoning which can be present in over-the-counter local company manufactured cough syrups.
