The metabolites like glycolate will cause severe metabolic acidosis that causes CNS depression due to high anion gap metabolic acidosis. The antidote is fomepizole.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy has been recently diagnosed with atopic dermatitis(AD). Which of the following is not a minor feature of AD?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Red dermatographism

 

Explanation:

Among the given options, red dermatographism is not considered a minor feature of atopic dermatitis (AD). It describes the presence of red streaks on the skin upon stroking as shown below and is commonly associated with urticaria.

 

White dermatographism refers to a white line on the stroking of the skin due to vasoconstriction as seen in AD.


 

Black dermatographism is due to metal deposition in the skin surface, as shown below.



 

Minor features of AD include:

 

Eye:

  • Periorbital dermatitis
  • Hertoghe’s sign - lateral madarosis due to continuous rubbing
  • Dennie Morgan fold - extra infraorbital fold of skin
  • Allergic shiners
  • Papillary conjunctivitis
  • Anterior subcapsular cataract
  • Keratoconus

Skin:

  • Cheilitis & perioral dermatitis - lip inflammation surrounded by area of pallor, and perioral dermatitis (headlight sign)
  • Ichthyosis (dry skin)
  • Keratosis pilaris - due to occluded hair follicles, with coiled hair
  • White dermatographism - white line on stroking of skin due to vasoconstriction
  • Hyperlinear palms and soles

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient presents with a chronic cough and night sweats. A sputum sample was collected and sent to the laboratory for testing. Acid-fast staining reveals red-coloured bacilli consistent with Mycobacterium tuberculosis. Who is credited with the original development of the acid-fast stain technique?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Paul Ehrlich

Explanation:

  • The acid-fast stain was discovered by Paul Ehrlich, who found that after staining with aniline dyes, tubercle bacilli resist decolourisation with acids.
  • It was later modified by Ziehl and Neelsen, and is now called the Modified Ziehl-Neelsen (ZN) stain.

Achievements of Paul Ehrlich:

  1. Bacteria Ehrlichia is named after him.
  2. Received the Nobel prize for the discovery of Toxin-antitoxin standardisation.
  3. Father of chemotherapy
  4. Gave the acid-fast staining procedure.

questions.text: A 35-year-old obese woman has been trying to conceive for over a year without success. She reports a history of irregular menstrual cycles. She has no history of pelvic inflammatory disease and USG shows no uterine abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her infertility?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Ovulatory dysfunction

Explanation:

Ovulatory Dysfunction (PCOS) is the most common cause of female infertility in this patient with a history of irregular menstrual cycles and obesity.

Causes of Female Infertility:

1. Ovarian
  • Anovulation: PCOD (most common), hyperprolactinemia.
  • Kallman syndrome
  • Premature ovarian failure: Radiation, chemotherapy, galactosemia

2. Tubal (Blockage)
  • Recurrent PID, TB pelvis, Salpingitis
  • Endometriosis
  • Tubectomy
  • Kartagener syndrome

3. Uterine
  • Fibroid (M/C: Submucosal): Endometrial polyp
  • Ashermann syndrome
  • Chronic endometritis (Clamydia)
  • Diethylstilbestrol (DES): T shape uterus
  • Septate uterus

4. Cervical
  • Cervicitis
  • Cervical stenosis
  • Antisperm antibodies

5. Vaginal
  • Atresia, transverse vaginal septum

6. Miscellaneous
  • Alcohol (Option D), Smoking

  • Fibroid (Option C): No uterine abnormalities detected on ultrasound.

  • Premature ovarian failure (Option A): History of estrogen deficiency symptoms and amenorrhea; elevated FSH levels suggest Primary Ovarian Failure.

questions.text: 60 year old obese man is having osteoarthritis and he is taking ibuprofen daily for the past 3 months. He developed epigastric pain and occult GI bleeding. Which of the following is correct about the cause?

choices.text: PGE2 and prostacyclin production reduced with decreased mucosal barrier
Increased acid production due to ibuprofen
PGE1 and prostacyclin production reduced with decreased mucosal barrier
Mucosal injury due to inhibition of COX-2

questions.solution:
Correct answer is A: PGE2 and prostacyclin production reduced with decreased mucosal barrier

  • Ibuprofen is a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) that inhibits cyclooxygenase enzymes (COX-1 and COX-2). This inhibition decreases the synthesis of protective prostaglandins, especially PGE2 and prostacyclin (PGI2), in the gastric mucosa.

questions.text:
A 45 y/o male undergoes an imaging study for evaluation of flank pain. A CECT scan reveals a renal cyst with multiple hairline thin septa and minimal wall thickening. The cyst shows thick nodular calcifications but no measurable enhancement after contrast administration. Based on the Bosniak classification, which of the following management options is most appropriate for this patient?

 



{{caption_text}}

choices.text: No follow-up is needed; continue routine monitoring.
Follow-up imaging every 6 months for 1 year.
Surgical excision or ablation of the cyst.
Follow-up imaging every 6 weeks for 1 year.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Follow-up imaging every 6 months for 1 year.

 

Explanation:

The CT findings describe a renal cyst with multiple hairline thin septa, minimal wall thickening, and thick nodular calcifications. These features are consistent with Category IIF of the Bosniak classification. The recommended management for this category includes close follow-up with imaging every 6 months for 1 year to monitor any changes.

Bosniak Classification of Renal Cysts & Management

 

Category

Description

Management

Category I

• Simple cyst, fluid density, hairline thin wall.

• No septa, calcifications, or solid components.

• No enhancement post-intravenous contrast.

CT showing a simple cyst.

• No follow-up is required.

Category II

• Cyst with some hairline thin septa, and fine calcifications.

• Uniformly high-density (<3 cm).

• No measurable enhancement.

CT showing hairline septa and fine calcifications

• No follow-up is required.

• US or CT may be sufficient for characterisation.

Category IIF

• Multiple hairline thin septa, minimal wall/septa thickening.

• Thick nodular calcifications or uniformly high-density (>3 cm).

• Malignancy Risk: ~20%

• Follow-up:

◦ Every 6 months for 1 year with CT or MRI.

◦ Followed by Imaging done annually for at least the next 5 years.

◦ May progress to Category III or IV.

Category III

• Thickened, irregular, or smooth enhancing walls/septa.

• Malignancy Risk: ~50%

CT showing thickened septa

• Treatment: Surgical excision/ablation due to high malignancy risk.

• Imaging:

◦ Contrast-enhanced triphasic CT for follow-up.

Category IV

• Same as Category III with additional soft-tissue components independent of walls/septa.

• Malignancy Risk: ~90%

CT showing thickened septa with additional soft tissue components

• Treatment: Surgical excision/ablation is recommended.

• Imaging: Same protocol as Category III for imaging with triphasic CT.


No follow-up needed; continue routine monitoring (Option A): Inappropriate because follow-up is needed due to the presence of septa and calcifications.

Surgical excision or ablation of the cyst (Option C): Surgical excision is not typically indicated for Category IIF cysts given the lower risk of malignancy.

Follow-up imaging every 6 weeks for 1 year(Option D): This is an excessively frequent follow-up schedule, making it an unrealistic and incorrect option.

questions.text: 30-year-old man presents with dull aching bilateral flank pain. BP is 160/100 mmHg. Family history reveals that his father died of brain haemorrhage at age 60. What is the first investigation that should be done in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Ultrasound abdomen:

  • The first differential diagnosis is ADPKD. It is associated with berry aneurysm at Circle of Willis bifurcations. USG abdomen should be done to evaluate corticomedullary differentiation and number of cysts in each kidney (Ravine criteria).
  • CT and MRI can detect smaller cysts but apart from radiation expose the patient to radio-contrast-that causes the risk of contrast induced nephropathy.
  • Radionuclide scans (DTPA/MAG3) are used to assess split renal function and diagnosis

questions.text: A patient’s cell culture exhibits distinct cytopathic effects characterised by the formation of syncytia (multinucleated giant cells). Based on these observations, which virus is most likely responsible for the infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Measles virus

 

Explanation:

  • Syncytia formation is a characteristic cytopathic effect associated with measles virus infection, distinguishing it from other viruses.
  • This occurs due to the fusion of infected cells, resulting in multinucleated giant cells.
  • While the Herpes simplex virus can also cause syncytia, measles is more characteristically associated with this effect in cell cultures.
  • Adenovirus and enterovirus typically do not exhibit syncytia formation.

 

Detection of Virus Growth in Cell Cultures:

  • Cytopathic Effect (CPE) refers to the morphological changes induced by a virus in a cell line, which can be observed using a light microscope.
  • While not all viruses cause CPE, those are known as cytopathic viruses.
  • Each virus has a unique type of CPE that helps to identify:
    • Enteroviruses (Option B): Rapid CPE with cell crenation and degeneration.
    • Measles virus: Syncytium formation (RSV or respiratory syncytial virus).
    • Herpesvirus: Discrete focal degeneration, ballooning and syncitium formation.
    • Adenovirus (Option A): Large granular clumps resembling bunches of grapes.
    • SV40 or Simian virus 40 (Option D): Prominent cytoplasmic vacuolation.
  • Metabolic Inhibition: Cellular metabolism produces acid in normal cultures, causing a colour change in the medium's pH indicator (phenol red).
  • When viruses grow, metabolism gets inhibited, leading to reduced acid production and a colour change.
  • Hemadsorption: Hemagglutinating viruses, such as influenza, can be detected by adding guinea pig erythrocytes to the culture.
    • If the viruses replicate, the erythrocytes will adsorb onto the cell surfaces.
  • Interference: The presence of a non-cytopathogenic virus inhibits the growth of a subsequent challenge with a known cytopathogenic virus.
  • Transformation: Oncogenic viruses can induce cell transformation, leading to loss of contact inhibition and the formation of microtumors in culture.

Other Methods for Detecting Viral Growth:

  • Direct Immunofluorescence Assay detects viral antigens on the surface of cells.
  • Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) is used to detect viral genes.
  • Electron Microscopy allows visualisation of viruses within infected cell lines.
  • Shell Vial Technique: For viruses like CMV, which require several weeks to exhibit CPE, the shell vial technique offers a quicker detection method (1-2 days).

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents after being bitten by a dog. He completed a full rabies vaccination series 5 months ago following a previous bite. What is the appropriate post-exposure prophylaxis?

choices.text: Administer a full course of rabies vaccine again (4 doses).
Administer two doses of rabies vaccine on days 0 and 3.
No rabies vaccine is needed due to recent vaccination.
Administer rabies immunoglobulin (RIG) and a full course of rabies vaccine (4 doses).

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Administer two doses of rabies vaccine on days 0 and 3.

Explanation:

The management of re-exposure depends on the timing and nature of previous vaccinations.

1. Re-Exposure Prophylaxis within 3 Months:

If a patient who has been bitten by an animal suspected to be rabid has completed a full rabies vaccination series within the last three months.

  • No Further Vaccination Required:
    • The immune response from the initial series is still strong, providing sufficient protection.
    • If necessary, only the wound should be cleaned thoroughly, and tetanus prophylaxis should be considered.

 

2. Re-Exposure Prophylaxis After 3 Months:

  • Wound Care on day 0
  • Administration of Two Booster Doses of the rabies vaccine.
    • Day 0: first dose.
    • Day 3: Second dose.
    • This booster regimen helps to reinforce the patient's immunity, ensuring continued protection against the rabies virus.
  • Rabies Immunoglobulin (RIG):
    • RIG is not required for patients who have previously completed a rabies vaccination series.
    • RIG is typically reserved for those who have never been vaccinated or have incomplete vaccination histories.

questions.text: A 65 y/o patient presents with sudden dizziness, difficulty swallowing, ipsilateral loss of temperature sensation on the face, contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in the trunk, ipsilateral ataxia, and giddiness. Which anatomical structure is responsible for the ipsilateral loss of temperature sensation on the face of this patient?

choices.text: Spinal nucleus and tract of the trigeminal nerve

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Spinal nucleus and tract of the trigeminal nerve

 

Explanation:

The patient is diagnosed with Wallenberg Syndrome due to the presence of ipsilateral loss of temperature sensation on the face, contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in the trunk, difficulty swallowing, ipsilateral ataxia, and giddiness.

The spinal nucleus and tract of the trigeminal nerve are responsible for the ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation over the face, which is a hallmark feature of Wallenberg Syndrome.

 

Wallenberg Syndrome (Lateral Medullary Syndrome)

  • Due to stroke or infarction in the lateral part of the medulla oblongata.
  • Mainly due to occlusion of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA), a branch of the vertebral artery. Sometimes the vertebral artery directly supplies the lateral brainstem.
  • Affects the dorsolateral aspect of the medulla and the inferior surface of the cerebellum.

 

Anatomical structure affected and features:

  1. Spinothalamic tract: Contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation of the trunk. (Option A ruled out)
  2. Spinal nucleus and tract of the trigeminal nerve: Ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation of the face.
  3. Nucleus ambiguus: Ipsilateral paralysis of muscles of the palate, pharynx, and larynx.
  4. Inferior cerebellar peduncle and cerebellum: Ipsilateral ataxia. (Option C ruled out)
  5. Vestibular nuclei: Giddiness. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text:
An infant with leukocoria presents with recurrent gastrointestinal infections and developmental regression. Bilateral eye examination revealed the following.



Choose the most appropriate next step in evaluation.

choices.text: Serum estimation of glucose, calcium, and phosphorous levels
Estimation of antibody titers for infections
Urine assay for the presence of reducing substances

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Urine assay for the presence of reducing substances

 

Explanation:

Given clinical scenario is indicative of Classical galactosemia.

 

Description
  • Inborn error of galactose metabolism.

Description and types

  • Classical Galactosaemia: deficiency of galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase (GPUT).
  • Non-classical type: Galactokinase deficiency

Characteristic Features
  • Frequently leads to bilateral cataract formation.
  • Cataracts often present as oil droplet central lens opacities.
  • Recurrent infections with Escherichia coli.
  • Mental retardation/developmental delay.

Management and prognosis
  • Avoidance of milk and milk-based products.
  • Cataract changes are reversible.

 

Biochemical analysis:



 

Blood analysis
  • Levels of blood glucose, calcium and phosphorus to rule out Hyperglycemia and Hypocalcemia. (Option A)
  • Red blood cell transferase and galactokinase levels - for Galactosemia.
  • Antibody titres for infections such as toxoplasmosis, rubella, cytomegalovirus and herpes simplex virus (TORCH) and hepatitis B virus. (Option B)
 

Urine analysis
  • Urine assay for reducing substances - for Galactosaemia. (Option D)
  • Screening for amino acids in the urine - if Lowe syndrome is suspected. (Option C)
  • Blood in urine - Alport syndrome
  • Estimation of copper in urine - Wilson disease

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents with dysphagia, throat pain, and a palpable neck mass. Laryngoscopy reveals a lesion on the epiglottis. Further investigations lead to the diagnosis of Laryngeal carcinoma.Which of the following is not a typical characteristic of this condition?

choices.text: Bilateral lymph node metastases are common but occurs late
Hoarseness is usually a late symptom
The most common histological type is squamous cell carcinoma
It may spread to the pre-epiglottic space

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Bilateral lymph node metastases are common but occurs late

 

Explanation:

The involvement of epiglottis in laryngeal carcinoma is indicative of supraglottic laryngeal carcinoma, in which nodal metastases occur early and are commonly bilateral.

Supraglottic Laryngeal Carcinoma:

Incidence

Less frequent than glottic cancer; about 30-35% of all laryngeal cancers

Site

Majority on epiglottis, false cords, followed by aryepiglottic folds

Vocal cord involvement

Usually late; vocal cords often spared in early stages

Lymphatic spread
  • Early and often bilateral
  • Upper and middle jugular nodes commonly involved
  • Cancer of infrahyoid epiglottis & anterior ventricular band may extend into pre-epiglottic space (Option D)

Symptoms
  • Early: Often silent, dysphagia, throat pain
  • Late: Hoarseness, weight loss, respiratory obstruction, halitosis (Option B)

Histopathology
  • 90-95% squamous cell carcinoma (Option C)
  • Others include verrucous carcinoma, spindle cell carcinoma
  • Highly anaplastic

Prognosis

Generally worse than glottic cancer due to:

  • Late diagnosis
  • High rate & early lymph node metastasis
  • Anaplastic nature

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents with continuous, painless vaginal bleeding for two months following 7 weeks of amenorrhea. She previously experienced heavy menstrual bleeding. Examination reveals a slightly enlarged uterus. A biopsy of the endometrium is shown below. Which is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Metropathia hemorrhagica

 

Explanation: The clinical presentation and the biopsy revealing Swiss cheese endometrium suggest Metropathia hemorrhagica, which is a specialised form of anovulatory AUB, typically affecting women aged 40-45 and is characterised by continuous, painless vaginal bleeding, often following a period of amenorrhea.

  • The uterus may be slightly enlarged.
  • This condition can mimic abortion or ectopic pregnancy if preceded by amenorrhea but without pain.
  • Endometrial biopsy: Hyperproliferative endometrium - Cystic Glandular Hyperplasia (CGH), also known as the Swiss cheese endometrium

questions.text: 50-year-old man presents with complaints of blood and mucus in thin ribbon like stool, tenesmus and weight loss. MRI abdomen shows bowel wall thickening in descending colon and perirectal fat thickening and enlarged lymph nodes. First differential diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is A: Colorectal cancer

  • The presence of blood and mucus in thin ribbon-like stools, along with tenesmus (feeling of incomplete evacuation) and weight loss, are classical symptoms suspicious for a colorectal malignancy.
  • MRI findings supporting colorectal cancer include:
    • Bowel wall thickening which represents tumour mass.
    • Perirectal fat thickening indicative of tumour extension beyond the bowel wall.
    • Enlarged lymph nodes, which likely represent nodal metastases
  • Microscopic colitis is a chronic inflammatory condition of the colon that causes persistent, non-bloody watery diarrhea. There are two main types of microscopic colitis collagenous and lymphocytic colitis.
  • Crohn’s disease can cause bowel wall thickening and lymphadenopathy but often shows skip lesions rather than continuous involvement and is usually associated with other signs such as strictures, fistulas, or creeping fat rather than primarily perirectal fat thickening

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents to the emergency department after a motor vehicle accident. He has an inability to urinate and perineal pain. Physical examination reveals a high-riding prostate on digital rectal examination, and imaging confirms extravasation of urine around the bladder and prostate. What is the most likely site of urethral injury?

choices.text: Can be any of the above

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Membranous urethra

 

Explanation:

  • If the rupture occurs above the urogenital diaphragm, urine escapes into the deep perineal pouch and may spread upward around the prostate and bladder into the extraperitoneal space (deep extravasation).
  • Here, the membranous urethra is located above the urogenital diaphragm.
  • A high-riding prostate could be further suggestive of posterior urethral injury, though not a reliable indicator.

Urethral Injury Causes

Posterior Urethra

Membranous Urethra

Instrumentation, pelvic fracture with urethral distraction defects

Prostatic Urethra

Instrumentation, radiation therapy for prostate cancer (external beam radiation therapy, brachytherapy)

Bladder Neck

Instrumentation, radiation therapy for prostate cancer (external beam radiation therapy, brachytherapy)

Penile urethra (Option B) and Bulb of the penis (Option C) (Bulbar urethra) lie below the urogenital diaphragm, and thus, urine leaks into the superficial perineal pouch and spreads over the scrotum, penis, and anterior abdominal wall beneath the membranous layer of the superficial fascia (superficial extravasation).

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy requires an amputation due to severe trauma to his ankle. The surgeon discusses two options: Syme’s amputation and Boyd’s amputation. Which statement accurately describes a key feature of each procedure?

choices.text: Syme’s allows for full weight-bearing; Children benefit greatly from Boyd’s.
Syme’s involves talectomy and fusion; Boyd’s preserves the distal physis.
Boyd’s involves talectomy and fusion; Syme’s uses a posterior flap.
Syme’s offers stabilization of the heel pad; Boyd’s is performed above the ankle.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Boyd’s involves talectomy and fusion; Syme’s uses a posterior flap.

 

Explanation:

Boyd’s amputation involves talectomy and calcaneotibial arthrodesis, while Syme’s amputation uses a long posterior flap.

 

Syme’s Amputation

Boyd’s amputation
  • Syme’s amputation is performed above the ankle. (Option D ruled out)
  • The level of bone section is 0.6 cm proximal to the ankle joint.
  • It preserves the distal physis, providing good function.
  • Children benefit greatly from this procedure. (Option A ruled out)
  • Men generally accept it well, but women may find it cosmetically unappealing.
  • The indications for the surgery are limited and it is technically difficult.
  • A long posterior flap is used, including the heel skin and fat pad.
  • The bones are cut just above the malleoli for stability.
  • Boyd’s amputation involves
    • Removal of the talus (talectomy)
    • The fusion of the calcaneus to the tibia (calcaneotibial arthrodesis). (Option B ruled out)
  • It enables full weight-bearing.
  • It offers stabilization of the heel pad while providing support for a prosthesis.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old diabetic patient presents with a non-healing ulcer on their heel that has persisted for 4 months despite regular dressing changes and offloading. The image showing the wound is given below.



Based on this clinical scenario, which of the following statements is incorrect?

choices.text: Chronic wound is a wound that persists beyond 4-12 weeks from its first appearance
Delay in healing most commonly occurs due to prolonged inflammatory phase
Pain is initially severe, but disappears with time due to nociceptor damage
Examples of chronic wounds include vascular ulcers, diabetic ulcers, and pressure sores

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Pain is initially severe, but disappears with time due to nociceptor damage

Explanation:
Chronic wounds commonly present with sharp chronic pain which increases with time. In fact, pain is one of the factors in deciding the treatment protocol.

 

Chronic wound

Definition

Any wound which persists beyond 4-12 weeks (Option A)despite conservative treatment (dressing)

Pathophysiology
  • Wounds that fail to progress through normal stages of wound healing
  • Most commonly prolonged phase is the Inflammatory phase (Option B)
  • Formation of microbial biofilms on wound

Treatment
  • Conservative treatment- Tried first, though mostly requires aggressive treatment (surgical)
  • Surgical treatment- Debridement, control of infection and inflammation
  • Surgical treatment is done when the patient suffers from intractable pain

Examples
  • Vascular ulcers (Option D)
  • Diabetic ulcers
  • Pressure sores

questions.text:
Near your home, there is an overhead water tank that needs disinfection. The sanitation officer decides to prepare a solution using high-test hypochlorite.

Which of the following is true regarding high-test hypochlorite?

choices.text: A single tablet of 0.5 g is sufficient to disinfect 20 liters of water.
It is available as Nesfield's and Bursoline's tablets.
It is no longer recommended for water disinfection.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) It contains 60-70% available chlorine

Explanation:

  • High-Test Hypochlorite(HTH) or Perchloron is a calcium compound that contains 60-70% of available chlorine.
  • It is more stable than bleaching powder and deteriorates much less in storage
  • Solutions prepared from HTH are also used for water disinfection.

A single tablet of 0.5 g is sufficient to disinfect 20 liters of water (Option A): A single Chlorine (not HTH) tablet of 0.5g is sufficient to disinfect 20 liters of water. 

It is available as Nesfield's and Bursoline's tablets (Option C): Nesfield's and Bursoline's tablets are Iodine tablets. Iodine is used for emergency disinfection of water. 2 drops of 2% ethanol solution of iodine will suffice for one liter of clear water, contact time of 20-30 min.

It is no longer recommended for water disinfection (Option D): HTH is still recommended for water disinfection. Rather, Potassium permanganate, a powerful oxidizing agent, once widely used for disinfection, is now no longer recommended.

questions.text:
An 80-year-old female patient came with complaints of gradual progressive diminution of vision for 2 years in both her eyes. She reports that over the last year, she noticed an improvement in her ability to read without glasses. The following finding is seen on slit lamp examination over the right eye and the left eye has similar opacity.



Choose the most appropriate course of management for this patient.

choices.text: Advise lifestyle modification and review after 3 months.
Recommend corticosteroids eye drops and reassess in 6 months.
Prescribe her rigid gas-permeable contact lenses.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Plan for Phacoemulsification.

Explanation:

Gradual, progressive loss of vision along with improvement in near vision (referred to as “second sight”), combined with characteristic slit-lamp findings, is suggestive of Nuclear Cataract, for which phacoemulsification is the treatment of choice.

  • Management:
    • Surgical measures: Mainstay of treatment.
    • Cataract surgeries:
      • ICCE (not preferred now)
      • ECCE
      • SICS (Small Incision Cataract Surgery)
      • Phacoemulsification (most preferred)
    • Followed by IOL implantation: PC-IOL (Posterior chamber-intraocular lens) is preferred.

Advise lifestyle modification and review after 3 months (Option A) would not address the cataract directly and would not improve the visual acuity.

Recommend corticosteroids eye drops and reassess in 6 months (Option B): The use of topical corticosteroids after cataract surgery reduces postoperative noninfectious inflammation but it is not used as the treatment for nuclear cataract.

Prescribe her rigid gas-permeable contact lenses (Option D): Rigid gas-permeable contact lenses are indicated for early-stage keratoconus with astigmatism.

questions.text: Under which initiative in India are children screened for common health conditions such as birth defects, deficiencies, developmental delays, and diseases up to the age of 18 years?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK)

Explanation:

Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK) is an initiative promoting school health

  • Comprehensive health care for children aged from birth to 18 years by screening them for birth defects, diseases, deficiencies, and developmental delays.
  • Children identified with these conditions receive early intervention and follow-up care provided free of cost including surgeries.

questions.text: A 29-year-old pregnant woman in her third trimester is evaluated by her obstetrician for routine prenatal care. She reports occasional palpitations and mild shortness of breath but has no significant past medical history. The physician explains that these symptoms can be related to normal cardiac changes in pregnancy. Which of the following is a physiological cardiac change typically observed during pregnancy?

choices.text: Decreased cardiac output due to reduced blood volume
Increased systemic vascular resistance leading to hypertension
Increased cardiac output primarily due to increased heart rate and stroke volume
Decreased heart rate due to increased vagal tone

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Increased cardiac output primarily due to increased heart rate and stroke volume


Explanation:
During pregnancy, the heart rate increases by up to 17%, and the stroke volume increases by up to 27%. As a result of this, Cardiac Output increases as

  • Cardiac Output = Heart Rate x Stroke Volume.

Decreased cardiac output due to reduced blood volume (Option A): Cardiac output is not decreased, but it is increased in pregnancy

Increased systemic vascular resistance leading to hypertension (Option B): There is a decrease in systemic vascular resistance, so BP falls during pregnancy.

Decreased heart rate due to increased vagal tone (Option D): There is increase in heart rate during pregnancy.

questions.text: A 74-year-old man was diagnosed with squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder. Which of the following is the most likely risk factor for this type of bladder cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) History of schistosomiasis.

 

Explanation:

 

Histologic Type of Bladder Carcinoma

Risk Factors

Transitional cell carcinoma (>97%)
  • Smoking
  • Occupational exposure (aromatic hydrocarbons):
    • Rubber, paint and dyes, gas and tar industries
    • Hairdressers, plumbers, and painters (Option C)
  • Environmental carcinogens: Arsenic in drinking water
  • Schistosomiasis (SCC >> transitional cell Ca)
  • Drugs: Phenacetin, Cyclophosphamide (Option D)
  • Pelvic radiotherapy

Squamous Cell Carcinoma (1-7%)
  • Schistosomiasis (Option A)
  • Secondary to chronic infections:
  • Indwelling catheter
  • Bladder stone
  • Recurrent infections

Adenocarcinoma (2%)
  • Urachus
  • Augmentation enterocystoplasty (Option B)
  • Bladder exstrophy repair

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl with a history of recurrent urinary tract infections presents with lethargy and muscle weakness. Laboratory tests reveal a serum potassium level of 6.8 mEq/L. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of her condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Obstructive uropathy

Explanation:

  • The history of recurrent urinary tract infections suggests the possibility of an underlying urological abnormality.
  • Obstructive uropathy can lead to impaired renal potassium excretion, resulting in hyperkalemia.
  • Normal serum potassium level: 3.5-5.5 meq/L.
  • Hyperkalemia is defined as a serum potassium level above 5.5 mEq/L.

 

HYPERKALEMIA

Etiology:

  • Decreased renal excretion (acute kidney injury, chronic kidney disease, obstructive uropathy)
  • Transcellular shifts (acidosis, cell lysis, rhabdomyolysis)
  • Excessive intake (rare in children with normal renal function)
  • Pseudohyperkalemia (hemolysis during blood draw)
  • Endocrine disorders (adrenal insufficiency, hypoaldosteronism)

 

Clinical features:

  • Muscle weakness
  • Fatigue
  • Paralysis (in severe cases)
  • Cardiac arrhythmias
  • Often asymptomatic in mild cases

 

Treatment:

Prevent further progression of hyperkalemia

Discontinue Potassium-Containing Substances

Stabilize the Myocardial Membrane
  • To prevent cardiac arrhythmias, administer IV calcium gluconate (10% solution) at a dose of 0.5-1 mL/kg over 5-10 minutes, with continuous cardiac monitoring.
  • If bradycardia occurs, discontinue the infusion.

Enhance Potassium Uptake into Cells:
  • Regular Insulin and Glucose: Administer 0.3 units of regular insulin per gram of glucose IV over 2 hours.
  • Sodium Bicarbonate: Infuse 1-2 mEq/kg body weight of sodium bicarbonate IV over 20-30 minutes.
  • Beta-Adrenergic Agonists: Use nebulized or IV beta-agonists (e.g., salbutamol, terbutaline) to drive potassium into cells.

Eliminate Potassium from the Body:
  • Sodium Polystyrene Sulfonate (Kayexalate): Administer 1 g/kg orally or via rectal enema, with a maximum dose of 15 g, mixed in 20-30% sorbitol.
  • Diuretics: Consider loop or thiazide diuretics if renal function is adequate.
  • Renal Replacement Therapy: For severe hyperkalemia, especially in cases of renal impairment or tumor lysis syndrome, hemodialysis or peritoneal dialysis may be required.
  • For Hypoaldosteronism: Administer maintenance doses of steroids and fludrocortisone.
  • For severe hyperkalemia (K+ >7.0 mEq/L) or when ECG changes (e.g., tall peaked T waves) are present, immediate treatment is necessary, starting with IV calcium gluconate, followed by sodium bicarbonate, insulin-glucose infusion, and/or nebulized beta-agonists.
  • In refractory cases, hemodialysis may be needed.
  • Mild hyperkalemia (5.5-6.5 mEq/L) should be managed by stopping potassium intake, discontinuing potassium-sparing drugs, and addressing the underlying cause.

 

Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (Option A):

  • While this condition can cause electrolyte imbalances, it typically results in hypokalemia due to aldosterone deficiency.
  • It's unlikely to cause hyperkalemia.

 

Excessive potassium intake (Option C):

  • This is rarely a cause of hyperkalemia in children with normal renal function.
  • The history doesn't suggest excessive intake.

 

Rhabdomyolysis (Option D):

  • While this can cause hyperkalemia due to the release of intracellular potassium, it's typically associated with a history of trauma, severe exercise, or certain medications.
  • The clinical presentation doesn't suggest rhabdomyolysis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a bilateral agency?
questions.solution:
The World Bank is not a bilateral agency, it is a multilateral agency.

 

Multilateral agencies are formed by 3 or more countries to work on issues. Examples include the UN, WHO, World Bank, and the International Monetary Fund.

 

World Bank

  • Headquarters - Washington.
  • Objective - Help less developed countries to raise living standards by lending money (Bank for countries)

Bilateral agencies:

Formed between 2 countries, provides funds to developing countries

 

Agencies

Headquarters

Services in India

Option A:

United States Agency for International Development (USAID)

Washington
  • Malaria eradication
  • Medical and nursing education
  • Health education
  • Water supply and sanitation
  • Nutrition and Family Planning
  • Control of Communicable Diseases

Option C:

Swedish International Development Agency (SIDA)

Sweden

Assisting the National TB Control Program

Option D:

Danish International Development Agency (DANIDA)

Denmark

Assisting the National Blindness Control Programme

Image 2- SIDA

Image 3- DANIDA

questions.text: An infant on examination has decreased breath sounds over the right lower side of the chest, which is dull on percussion. A chest X-ray shows as follows. Which of the following is true about this condition?

choices.text: The abnormal lung tissue is attached to the bronchial tree.
Blood returns to the right side of the heart from this lesion.
Chest X-ray is not a reliable diagnostic test in this case.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Blood returns to the right side of the heart from this lesion.

 

Explanation:

The clinical scenario and X-ray point to the diagnosis of pulmonary sequestration from which the blood returns to the right side of the heart.
 

Pulmonary sequestration

Definition

 

Rare congenital lung anomaly where abnormal lung tissue is detached from the normal bronchial tree and receives blood from a systemic artery, usually a branch of the aorta. (Option A ruled out)

Types

Intrapulmonary: within the visceral pleura

Extrapulmonary: outside the visceral pleura

Pathophysiology
  • Systemic Arterial Supply: Receives blood from a systemic artery (e.g., aorta) instead of the pulmonary artery. Blood returns to the right side of the heart. (Option B)
  • Extra-pulmonary type drains through IVC and
    intrapulmonary through the pulmonary veins.
  • Lack of Bronchial Connection: No connection to the bronchial tree; does not participate in gas exchange but may rupture into an airway, potentially leading to infection.
  • Collateral Ventilation: This can occur via the pores of Kohn in intrapulmonary sequestration.

Etiology

There are two theories

  • Embryological Origin
  • Acquired Lesion Theory (Recurrent infection/inflammation ➜ cystic changes and hypertrophy of the feeding artery).

Clinical features
  • Dullness to Percussion
  • Decreased Breath Sounds over the affected area
  • Crackles: Indicate possible infection (Option C ruled out)
  • Continuous or systolic murmur from turbulent blood flow

Investigations
  • Chest X-ray: Initial detection of abnormal opacity or mass. (Option D ruled out)

  • CECT: Confirms diagnosis, details size, location, and blood supply.

 
  • MR Angiography: Visualizes abnormal blood vessels.
  • Ultrasonography: Rules out other conditions and visualizes systemic artery

Treatment
  • Surgical resection: Preferred treatment to remove the abnormal tissue and preserve the systemic artery.
  • Coil sequestration: Minimally invasive alternative, blocks the feeding artery to shrink the sequestration.

Complications of sequestration
  • Pneumonia
  • Abscess Formation
  • Respiratory Distress
  • Sepsis

questions.text: Which of the following is most accurate regarding in vitro fertilization (IVF) for women with bilateral tubal blockage?

choices.text: IVF is ineffective for women with bilateral tubal blockage.
Bilateral salpingectomy is always required before IVF in cases of tubal blockage.
ICSI is used to fertilize the egg in all IVF cases, regardless of sperm quality.
Preimplantation genetic testing (PGT) is necessary for women of advanced maternal age.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Preimplantation genetic testing (PGT) is necessary for women of advanced maternal age.
 

Explanation:

IVF provides a solution for women with bilateral tubal blockage, a condition in which both fallopian tubes are blocked, preventing natural conception.

  • Mechanism: IVF bypasses the fallopian tubes by directly retrieving eggs from the ovaries, fertilizing them in a lab, and transferring the embryos into the uterus.
  • Surgical Considerations: Women with severe tubal damage may undergo bilateral salpingectomy (removal of both fallopian tubes) to improve IVF success rates by avoiding complications from dysfunctional tubes. (Option B ruled out)
  • Success Rates: IVF success in cases of bilateral tubal blockage depends on factors like age, overall reproductive health, and egg/embryo quality.
    • Despite these variables, IVF remains a highly effective treatment. (Option A ruled out)
  • The main steps of IVF include:
  1. Controlled Ovarian Hyperstimulation:
    • Most often done using injectable gonadotropins.
    • After about 36 hours from a trigger shot or HCG injection, egg retrieval is performed using transvaginal ultrasound-guided aspiration.
  2. Fertilization:
    • Retrieved eggs are placed in a special medium, and normal sperm is added for insemination.
    • If sperm abnormalities are present, intracytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI) is used, where a single sperm is injected directly into the egg's cytoplasm. (Option C ruled out)
  3. Embryo Assessment:
    • After fertilization, embryos are assessed and graded.
    • Transfer usually occurs on Day 3 or Day 5.
  4. Preimplantation Genetic Testing (PGT):
    • It’s a procedure used to detect genetic mutations, chromosomal translocations, or aneuploidy (abnormal number of chromosomes).
    • It’s especially useful in cases of advanced maternal age, recurrent IVF failures, recurrent pregnancy loss, or unexplained infertility. (Option D)

questions.text: In a clinical trial for a new hypertension drug, the null hypothesis states: "The new drug does not affect blood pressure." If researchers commit a Type 1 error, which of the following is true?

choices.text: Drug lower BP, but it was concluded that it has no effect.
Drug has no effect, but it was concluded as it lowers BP.
Drug raises BP, but it was concluded that it has no effect.
Drug has no effect, and it was correctly concluded.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Drug has no effect, but it was concluded as it lowers BP

Explanation: A Type 1 error, also known as a "false positive," occurs when we reject the null hypothesis when it is true. In this case:

  • Null hypothesis: The drug does not affect blood pressure.
  • Type 1 error: Rejecting this true null hypothesis and accepting an alternative hypothesis.

Key points:

  • In a Type 1 error, the truth aligns with the null hypothesis (the drug truly has no effect).
  • The error lies in the researchers' conclusion, which incorrectly rejects the null hypothesis.
  • This error leads to a false claim of a significant effect when there isn't one.

Criteria

Type I Error

Type II Error

Definition

Rejecting a true null hypothesis

Accepting a false null hypothesis

Also Known As

False positive.

False-negative.

Implication

Concluding there is an effect when there is none.

Concluding there is no effect when there is one.

Probability Notation

Alpha (α)

Beta (β)

Consequences

Believing a result is significant when it is not.

Missing a significant result.

Example

Concluding a drug has an effect when it does not.

Concluding a drug does not have an effect when it does.

Testing Goal

Minimise α to reduce the Type I error rate.

Minimise β to reduce the Type II error rate.

Drug lowers BP, but it was concluded that it has no effect (Option A): This would be a Type II error: failing to reject H₀ when it is false.

Drug raises BP, but it was concluded that it has no effect (Option C):  Again, H₀ is false (it raises BP), but we accept it — a Type II error.

Drug has no effect, and it was correctly concluded (Option D): This is a correct decision, not an error at all.

questions.text:
Match the following sections of the BSA (Bhartiya Sakshya Act) with their corresponding explanations or provisions:


	
		
			
			BSA Section
			
			
			Provision
			
		
		
			
			1. 157
			
			
			a) A magistrate or judge can ask you a question at any point of time
			
		
		
			
			2. 146
			
			
			b) The sequence of examination (Oath-CH-CR-RE)
			
		
		
			
			3. 168
			
			
			c) Leading question
			
		
		
			
			4. 143
			
			
			d) Questions by the party to his/her own witness
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 1-d, 3-a, 2-c, 4-b

 

Explanation:

Sections of BSA (Bhartiya Sakshya Act)

Section of BSA (Bhartiya Sakshya Act)

Explanation/Provision

143 BSA

The sequence of examination (Oath-CH-CR-RE)

146 (1) (2) (3) BSA

Leading question

157 BSA

Questions by the party to his/her own witness

168 BSA

A magistrate or judge can ask you a question at any point of time
 

124 BSA

  

A competent witness is one who has the capacity and ability to understand the questions put to him by the court. If he has the understanding of questions and the ability to give rational answers, then he is a competent witness.

(Common Witness)

39 BSA

A person especially skilled in foreign law, science

or art is an Expert witness

questions.text: A 3-y/o child is brought to the emergency department with symptoms of severe fatigue, vomiting, and episodes of hypoglycemia. Blood tests reveal low glucose levels without elevated ketone bodies, as indicated by a negative Rothera and Benedict tests. Further examination indicates a fatty liver. The child's mother gives h/o acute fatty liver during her pregnancy with the child. Which of the following deficiencies is most likely responsible for these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct answer : Option B- Long-Chain 3-Hydroxyacyl-CoA Dehydrogenase Deficiency 

  • The scenario describes a child with severe fatigue, vomiting, nonketotic hypoglycemia, and fatty liver, alongside a maternal history of acute fatty liver of pregnancy (AFLP).
  • These features are characteristic of Long-Chain 3-Hydroxyacyl-CoA Dehydrogenase Deficiency.
    • This condition affects fatty acid oxidation and can manifest in both the child and mother, particularly with AFLP during pregnancy.
  • Other deficiencies listed do not specifically present with this combination of symptoms and maternal history.

 

FATTY ACID OXIDATION DEFECTS

CONGENITAL DEFECTS

ACQUIRED DEFECTS

1. CPT-I Deficiency:

  • Site: Liver
  • Pathophysiology: Leading to decreased fatty acid oxidation and ketogenesis, which can result in hypoglycemia (Option A ruled out)
 

2. CPT-II Deficiency:

  • Site: Primarily affecting skeletal muscle and potentially the liver in severe cases
 

3. Defects in β-oxidation Enzymes: 2 types:

 
  • Long and Short-Chain 3-Hydroxyacyl-CoA Dehydrogenase Deficiency: Can cause nonketotic hypoglycemia, coma, and fatty liver. May also contribute to acute fatty liver during pregnancy
 
  • 3-Ketoacyl-CoA Thiolase and HMG-CoA Lyase Deficiency: These deficiencies not only disrupt fatty acid oxidation but also affect the breakdown of leucine, a ketogenic amino acid.

1. Carnitine Deficiency:

  • Common in preterm babies
  • Cause:
    • Inadequate biosynthesis or renal leakage.
    • Hemolysis
  • Pathophysiology:
    • Impaired fatty acid oxidation→hypoglycemia & Lipid accumulation→muscular weakness (Option D ruled out)
 

2. Jamaican Vomiting Sickness:

 
  • Cause: Consuming unripe ackee fruit containing the toxin hypoglycin,
  • Pathophysiology: This condition inhibits medium- and short-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase, leading to hypoglycemia (Option C ruled out)

CLINICAL FEATURES
  • Hypoglycemia
  • Nonketotic Hypoglycemia
  • Lipid Accumulation
  • Dicarboxylic Aciduria
    • Marked by the excretion of C6—C10 ω-dicarboxylic acids and non-ketotic hypoglycemia
    • It arises from a lack of mitochondrial medium-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase.
  • Muscular Weakness due to the buildup of lipids in muscles
  • Coma
  • Fatty Liver
  • Acute Fatty Liver of Pregnancy: Due to Long-chain 3-hydroxyacyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency indicating a potential role of hormonal changes influencing enzyme activity.
  • Neurological Symptoms: Defects impacting fatty acid oxidation, especially those also affecting the breakdown of leucine.

 

Differential Diagnosis:

  1. DKA (Benedict+, Rothera+): This would present with high blood glucose and elevated ketone bodies, which is not the case here.
  2. Starvation ketosis (Benedict-, Rothera+): This can also cause non-ketotic hypoglycemia, but without the fatty liver findings.
  3. Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD): This amino acid disorder can impact fatty acid oxidation and cause hypoglycemia, but would likely present with a different pattern of symptoms.
  4. Type 1 Glycogen Storage Disease: This can also lead to fasting hypoglycemia, but would not typically involve fatty liver changes

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents following a fall from a ladder. The patient exhibits specific neurological symptoms: loss of pain and temperature sensation in the left leg, difficulty identifying the position of the right leg with eyes closed, and complete loss of sensation at the T12 level of the trunk on the right. Which of the following statements is false for this condition?

choices.text: Loss of proprioception in the right leg occurs due right dorsal column.
Loss of pain in the left leg occurs due to the left spinothalamic tract.
Damage to the ventral nerve roots at the T12 level results in loss of sensation.
Spastic paralysis of the right leg

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Loss of pain in the left leg occurs due to the left spinothalamic tract.

 

Explanation:

 

  • The patient's presentation is consistent with Brown-Séquard Syndrome, resulting from a hemisection of the spinal cord.
  • In Brown-Séquard syndrome, pain, and temperature sensations are lost on the opposite side of the body from the lesion due to the crossing of the spinothalamic tract fibers.
  • Therefore, loss of pain in the left leg would be due to damage to the right spinothalamic tract, not the left.

 

Brown-Sequard syndrome

 

Below the Level of Lesion:

  • Ipsilateral Upper Motor Neuron Paralysis: Due to damage to the pyramidal tract (corticospinal tract) (Option D ruled out).
  • Ipsilateral Loss of Conscious Proprioceptive Sensations: Caused by damage to the posterior white column (Option A ruled out).
  • Contralateral Loss of Pain and Temperature Sensations: Due to damage to the lateral spinothalamic tract and anterior spinothalamic tract.

At the Level of Lesion: (Option C ruled out)

  • Ipsilateral Lower Motor Neuron Paralysis: Resulting from damage to the ventral nerve roots.
  • Ipsilateral Anesthesia Over the Skin of the Segment: Due to injury to the ventral nerve roots.

Above the Level of Lesion:

  • Ipsilateral Hyperesthesia: Resulting from irritation of the dorsal nerve roots.
